27747558060.0;Hubble Supernova Bubble Resembles Holiday Ornament;"A delicate sphere of gas
column2: photographed by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope
column3: floats serenely in the depths of space. The pristine shell
column4: or bubble
column5: is the result of gas that is being shocked by the expanding blast wave from a supernova. Called SNR 0509-67.5 (or SNR 0509 for short)
column6: the bubble is the visible remnant of a powerful stellar explosion in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC)
column7: a small galaxy about 160
column8: 000 light-years from Earth.

column1: Ripples in the shell's surface may be caused by either subtle variations in the density of the ambient interstellar gas
column2: or possibly driven from the interior by pieces of the ejecta. The bubble-shaped shroud of gas is 23 light-years across and is expanding at more than 11 million miles per hour (5
column3: 000 kilometers per second).

column1: Astronomers have concluded that the explosion was one of an especially energetic and bright variety of supernovae. Known as Type Ia
column2: such supernova events are thought to result from a white dwarf star in a binary system that robs its partner of material
column3: takes on much more mass than it is able to handle
column4: and eventually explodes.

column1: Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys observed the supernova remnant on Oct. 28
column3: with a filter that isolates light from glowing hydrogen seen in the expanding shell. These observations were then combined with visible-light images of the surrounding star field that were imaged with Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3 on Nov. 4

column1: With an age of about 400 years as seen from Earth
column2: the supernova might have been visible to southern hemisphere observers around the year 1600. However
column3: there are no known records of a "new star" in the direction of the LMC near that time. A more recent supernova in the LMC
column4: SN 1987A
column5: did catch the eye of Earth viewers and continues to be studied with ground- and space-based telescopes
column6: including Hubble.

33733503852.0;Hubble Takes Close-up Portrait of Jupiter;"On April 3
column3: as Jupiter made its nearest approach to Earth in a year
column4: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope viewed the solar system’s largest planet in all of its up-close glory. At a distance of 415 million miles (668 million kilometers) from Earth
column5: Jupiter offered spectacular views of its colorful
column6: roiling atmosphere
column7: the legendary Great Red Spot
column8: and it smaller companion at farther southern latitudes dubbed “Red Spot Jr.”

column1: The giant planet is now at “opposition
column2: ” positioned directly opposite the Sun from the Earth. This means that the Sun
column3: Earth
column4: and Jupiter line up
column5: with Earth sitting between the Sun and the gas giant. Opposition also marks Jupiter’s closest point to us
column6: and the planet appears brighter in the night sky than at any other time in the year.

column1: This positioning allowed a team led by Amy Simon of NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt
column2: Maryland
column3: to observe Jupiter using Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3. Hubble photographed exquisite details in Jupiter’s atmosphere
column4: as small as about 80 miles (129 kilometers) across.

column1: With its immense and powerful storms and hundreds of smaller vortices
column2: the atmosphere of Jupiter is divided into several distinct
column3: colorful bands
column4: parallel to the equator. These bands
column5: with alternating wind motions
column6: are created by differences in the thickness and height of the ammonia ice clouds; the lighter bands rise higher and have thicker clouds than the darker bands. The bands are separated by winds that can reach speeds of up to 400 miles (644 kilometers) per hour.

column1: Jupiter is best known for the Great Red Spot
column2: an anticyclone that has raged for at least 150 years. This famous storm is larger than Earth. However
column3: the Great Red Spot is slowly shrinking — a trend seen since the late 1800s. The reason for this phenomenon is still unknown. Hubble will continue to observe Jupiter in hopes of solving this mysterious riddle.

column1: The images are part of the Outer Planets Atmospheres Legacy program or OPAL. This program provides yearly Hubble global views of the outer planets to look for changes in their storms
column2: winds
column3: and clouds. It began in 2014 with Uranus
column4: and has been studying Jupiter and Neptune since 2015. In 2018
column5: it will begin viewing Saturn.

column1: The team timed the Hubble observation to coincide with when NASA’s space probe Juno would be near its closest point to Jupiter
column2: so that scientists could get concurrent observations.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/0806ae5b033c4631798f0c3e858b7853;2017-04-07;985.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33733503852/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 27415515533.0;Hubble Rocks with a Heavy-Metal Home;"This 10.5-billion-year-old globular cluster
column2: NGC 6496
column3: is home to heavy-metal stars of a celestial kind! The stars comprising this spectacular spherical cluster are enriched with much higher proportions of metals — elements heavier than hydrogen and helium
column4: are in astronomy curiously known as metals — than stars found in similar clusters.

column1: A handful of these high-metallicity stars are also variable stars
column2: meaning that their brightness fluctuates over time. NGC 6496 hosts a selection of long-period variables — giant pulsating stars whose brightness can take up to
column3: and even over
column4: a thousand days to change — and short-period eclipsing binaries
column5: which dim when eclipsed by a stellar companion.

column1: The nature of the variability of these stars can reveal important information about their mass
column2: radius
column3: luminosity
column4: temperature
column5: composition
column6: and evolution
column7: providing astronomers with measurements that would be difficult or even impossible to obtain through other methods.

column1: NGC 6496 was discovered in 1826 by Scottish astronomer James Dunlop. The cluster resides at about 35
column2: 000 light-years away in the southern constellation of Scorpius (the Scorpion).

column1: Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA; Acknowledgement: Judy Schmidt
Text credit: European Space Agency

28191313931.0;Hubble Views a Stubborn Dwarf Galaxy;"The fuzzy collection of stars seen in this NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image forms an intriguing dwarf galaxy named LEDA 677373
column2: located about 14 million light-years away from us.

column1: Dwarf galaxies are small
column2: faint collections of stars and gas. Their diverse properties make them intriguing objects to astronomers
column3: but their small size means that we can only explore those that lie closest to us
column4: within the Local Group
column5: such as LEDA 677373.

column1: This particular dwarf galaxy contains a plentiful reservoir of gas from which it could form stars. However
column2: it stubbornly refuses to do so. In a bid to find out why
column3: Hubble imaged the galaxy’s individual stars at different wavelengths
column4: a method that allows astronomers to figure out a star’s age. These observations showed that the galaxy has been around for at least six billion years — plenty of time to form more stars. So why has it not done so?

column1: Rather than being stubborn
column2: LEDA 677373 seems to have been the unfortunate victim of a cosmic crime. A nearby giant spiral galaxy
column3: Messier 83
column4: seems to be stealing gas from the dwarf galaxy
column5: stopping new stars from being born.

column1: Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA
Text credit: European Space Agency

View the full press release here.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/5a32e901992960b7259439f0301e05bd;2016-07-04;738.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28191313931/in/album-72157667717916600;leda677373

column2: Chinese astronomers took notice of a “guest star” that was
column3: for nearly a month
column4: visible in the daytime sky. The “guest star” they observed was actually a supernova explosion
column5: which gave rise to the Crab Nebula
column6: a six-light-year-wide remnant of the violent event.

column1: With an apparent magnitude of 8.4 and located 6
column2: 500 light-years from Earth in the constellation Taurus
column3: the Crab Nebula can be spotted with a small telescope and is best observed in January. The nebula was discovered by English astronomer John Bevis in 1731
column4: and later observed by Charles Messier who mistook it for Halley’s Comet. Messier’s observation of the nebula inspired him to create a catalog of celestial objects that might be mistaken for comets.

column1: This large mosaic of the Crab Nebula was assembled from 24 individual exposures captured by Hubble over three months. The colors in this image do not match exactly what we would see with our eyes but yield insight into the composition of this spectacular stellar corpse. The orange filaments are the tattered remains of the star and consist mostly of hydrogen. The blue in the filaments in the outer part of the nebula represents neutral oxygen. Green is singly ionized sulfur
column2: and red indicates doubly ionized oxygen. These elements were expelled during the supernova explosion.

column1: A rapidly spinning neutron star (the ultra-dense core of the exploded star) is embedded in the center of the Crab Nebula. Electrons whirling at nearly the speed of light around the star’s magnetic field lines produce the eerie blue light in the interior of the nebula. The neutron star
column2: like a lighthouse
column3: ejects twin beams of radiation that make it appear to pulse 30 times per second as it rotates.

column1: 27747553890.0;The Complexity of a Nebula - NGC 5189;"NASA's Hubble Space Telescope photographed a nearby planetary nebula called NGC 5189. The intricate structure of this bright gaseous nebula resembles a glass-blown holiday ornament with a glowing ribbon entwined. Planetary nebulae represent the final brief stage in the life of a medium-sized star like our Sun. While consuming the last of the fuel in its core
column2: the dying star expels a large portion of its outer envelope. This material then becomes heated by the radiation from the stellar remnant and radiates
column3: producing glowing clouds of gas that can show complex structures
column4: as the  ejection of mass from the star is uneven in both time and direction.

column1: A spectacular example of this beautiful complexity is seen in the bluish lobes of NGC 5189. Most of the nebula is knotty and filamentary in its structure. As a result of the mass-loss  process
column2: the planetary nebula has been created with two nested structures
column3: tilted with respect to each other
column4: that expand away from the center in different directions.

column1: This double bipolar or quadrupolar structure could be explained by the presence of a binary companion orbiting the central star and influencing the pattern of mass ejection during its nebula-producing death throes. The remnant of the central star
column2: having lost much of its mass
column3: now lives its final days as a white dwarf. However
column4: there is no visual candidate for the  possible companion. The bright golden ring that twists and tilts through the image is made up of a large collection of radial filaments and cometary knots. These are usually formed by the combined action of photo-ionizing radiation and stellar winds.

column1: This image was taken with Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3 on July 6
column3: in filters tuned to the specific colors of fluorescing sulfur
column4: hydrogen
column5: and oxygen atoms. Broad filters in the visible and near-infrared were used to capture the star colors.

column1: 33874042362.0;Starbursts in Virgo;"Despite all efforts
column2: galaxy formation and evolution are still far from being fully understood. Fortunately
column3: the conditions we see within certain galaxies — such as so-called starburst galaxies — can tell us a lot about how they have evolved over time. Starburst galaxies contain a region (or many regions) where stars are forming at such a breakneck rate that the galaxy is eating up its gas supply faster than it can be replenished!

column1: NGC 4536 is such a galaxy
column2: captured here in beautiful detail by Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3). Located roughly 50 million light-years away in the constellation of Virgo (the Virgin)
column3: it is a hub of extreme star formation. There are several different factors that can lead to such an ideal environment in which stars can form at such a rapid rate. Crucially
column4: there has to be a sufficiently massive supply of gas. This might be acquired in a number of ways — for example by passing very close to another galaxy
column5: in a full-blown galactic collision
column6: or as a result of some event that forces lots of gas into a relatively small space.

column1: Star formation leaves a few tell-tale fingerprints
column2: so astronomers can tell where stars have been born. We know that starburst regions are rich in gas. Young stars in these extreme environments often live fast and die young
column3: burning extremely hot and exhausting their gas supplies fairly quickly. These stars also emit huge amounts of intense ultraviolet light
column4: which blasts the electrons off any atoms of hydrogen lurking nearby (a process called ionization)
column5: leaving behind clouds of ionized hydrogen (known in astronomer-speak as HII regions).";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/55185764dd7f09cc5ef8dccda3644c18;2016-10-26;1159.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33874042362/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4536

column1: 31451928372.0;A transformation in Virgo;"The constellation of Virgo (the Virgin) is especially rich in galaxies
column2: due in part to the presence of a massive and gravitationally bound collection of over 1300 galaxies called the Virgo Cluster. One particular member of this cosmic community
column3: NGC 4388
column4: is captured in this image
column5: as seen by the Hubble Space Telescope’s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3).

column1: Located some 60 million light-years away
column2: NGC 4388 is experiencing some of the less desirable effects that come with belonging to such a massive galaxy cluster. It is undergoing a transformation
column3: and has taken on a somewhat confused identity.

column1: While the galaxy’s outskirts appear smooth and featureless
column2: a classic feature of an elliptical galaxy
column3: its center displays remarkable dust lanes constrained within two symmetric spiral arms
column4: which emerge from the galaxy’s glowing core — one of the obvious features of a spiral galaxy. Within the arms
column5: speckles of bright blue mark the locations of young stars
column6: indicating that NGC 4388 has hosted recent bursts of star formation.

column1: Despite the mixed messages
column2: NGC 4388 is classified as a spiral galaxy. Its unusual combination of features are thought to have been caused by interactions between NGC 4388 and the Virgo Cluster. Gravitational interactions — from glancing blows to head-on collisions
column3: tidal influencing
column4: mergers
column5: and galactic cannibalism — can be devastating to galaxies. While some may be lucky enough to simply suffer a distorted spiral arm or newly triggered wave of star formation
column6: others see their structure and contents completely and irrevocably altered.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/e18f006de6f029289c4307164285111a;2016-12-05;733.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/31451928372/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4388

column1: 32274594653.0;Astronomical cooperation;"The events surrounding the Big Bang were so cataclysmic that they left an indelible imprint on the fabric of the cosmos. We can detect these scars today by observing the oldest light in the universe. As it was created nearly 14 billion years ago
column2: this light — which exists now as weak microwave radiation and is thus named the cosmic microwave background (CMB) — has now expanded to permeate the entire cosmos
column3: filling it with detectable photons.

column1: The CMB can be used to probe the cosmos via something known as the Sunyaev-Zel’dovich (SZ) effect
column2: which was first observed over 30 years ago. We detect the CMB here on Earth when its constituent microwave photons travel to us through space. On their journey to us
column3: they can pass through galaxy clusters that contain high-energy electrons. These electrons give the photons a tiny boost of energy. Detecting these boosted photons through our telescopes is challenging but important — they can help astronomers to understand some of the fundamental properties of the universe
column4: such as the location and distribution of dense galaxy clusters.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope observed one of most massive known galaxy clusters
column3: seen in this image
column4: as part of the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (CLASH). This observation of the cluster
column5: 5 billion light-years from Earth
column6: helped the  Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile to study the cosmic microwave background using the thermal Sunyaev-Zel’dovich effect. The observations made with ALMA are visible as the blue-purple hues.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/2dbf9ba8eda4e82d56fa73713b6e8399;2017-02-14;971.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/32274594653/in/album-72157667717916600;rxj13475‚Äì1145

column1: 34020799382.0;Blowing cosmic bubbles;"This entrancing image shows a few of the tenuous threads that comprise Sh2-308
column2: a faint and wispy shell of gas located 5200 light-years away in the constellation of Canis Major (the Great Dog).

column1: Sh2-308 is a large bubble-like structure wrapped around an extremely large
column2: bright type of star known as a Wolf-Rayet star — this particular star is called EZ Canis Majoris. These type of stars are among the brightest and most massive stars in the universe
column3: tens of times more massive than our own Sun
column4: and they represent the extremes of stellar evolution. Thick winds continually poured off the progenitors of such stars
column5: flooding their surroundings and draining the outer layers of the Wolf-Rayet stars. The fast wind of a Wolf-Rayet star therefore sweeps up the  surrounding material to form bubbles of gas.

column1: EZ Canis Majoris is responsible for creating the bubble of Sh2-308 — the star threw off its outer layers to create the strands visible here. The intense and ongoing radiation from the star pushes the bubble out further and further
column2: blowing it bigger and bigger. Currently the edges of Sh2-308 are some 60 light-years apart!

column1: As beautiful as these cosmic bubbles are
column2: they are fleeting. The same stars that form them will also cause their death
column3: eclipsing and subsuming them in violent supernova explosions.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/9797e25628a6d9893993da5b258914a2;2016-10-19;1063.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/34020799382/in/album-72157667717916600;ezcanismajoris sh2308

column1: 31339441186.0;Spotlight on IC 3583;"This delicate blue group of stars — actually an irregular galaxy named IC 3583 — sits some 30 million light-years away in the constellation of Virgo (the Virgin).
It may seem to have no discernable structure
column2: but IC 3583 has been found to have a bar of stars running through its center. These structures are common throughout the universe
column3: and are found within the majority of spiral
column4: many irregular
column5: and some lenticular galaxies. Two of our closest cosmic neighbors
column6: the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds
column7: are barred
column8: indicating that they may have once been barred spiral galaxies that were disrupted or torn apart by the gravitational pull of the Milky Way.

column1: Something similar might be happening with IC 3583. This small galaxy is thought to be gravitationally interacting with one of its neighbors
column2: the spiral Messier 90. Together
column3: the duo form a pairing known as Arp 76. It’s still unclear whether these flirtations are the cause of IC 3583’s irregular appearance — but whatever the cause
column4: the galaxy makes for a strikingly delicate sight
column5: glimmering in the blackness of space
column6: in this Hubble Space Telescope image.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/fb25970d1cb5f6ef6c0a3eb9611635ea;2016-11-28;1026.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/31339441186/in/album-72157667717916600;ic3583

column1: 30952176712.0;A subtle swarm;"This Hubble image shows NGC 4789A
column2: a dwarf irregular galaxy in the constellation of Coma Berenices. It certainly lives up to its name — the stars that call this galaxy home are smeared out across the sky in an apparently disorderly and irregular jumble
column3: giving NGC 4789A a far more subtle and abstract appearance than its glitzy spiral and elliptical cousins.

column1: These stars may look as if they have been randomly sprinkled on the sky
column2: but they are all held together by gravity. The colors in this image have been deliberately exaggerated to emphasize the mix of blue and red stars. The blue stars are bright
column3: hot
column4: and massive stars that have formed relatively recently
column5: whereas the red stars are much older. The presence of both tells us that stars have been forming in this galaxy throughout its history.

column1: At a distance of just over 14 million light-years away NGC 4789A is relatively close to us
column2: allowing us to see many of the individual stars within its bounds. This image also reveals numerous other galaxies
column3: far more distant
column4: that appear as fuzzy shapes spread across the image.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/5265452d53d91720d218b5c6a609145e;2016-11-14;648.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/30952176712/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4789a

column1: 28163291031.0;Launch of Space Shuttle Atlantis on STS-125 Mission;"Space Shuttle Atlantis and its seven-member STS-125 crew head toward Earth orbit and rendezvous with NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. Liftoff was on time at 2:01 p.m. EDT on May 11
column3: from Launch Pad 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center.

column1: Onboard were astronauts Scott Altman
column2: commander; Gregory C. Johnson
column3: pilot; Michael Good
column4: Megan McArthur
column5: John Grunsfeld
column6: Mike Massimino and Andrew Feustel
column7: all mission specialists.

column1: Atlantis' 12-day flight included five spacewalks that refurbished and upgraded the telescope with state-of-the-art science instruments that expanded Hubble's capabilities and extended its operational lifespan. The payload included the Wide Field Camera 3
column2: a fine guidance sensor and the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/540b8e7747bbbceb191c0205cf88666a;2009-05-11;1600.0;2400.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28163291031/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission shuttlemission spaceshuttle launch spaceshuttleatlantis kennedyspacecenter

24893155568.0;Streaks and stripes;"This picturesque view from the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope peers into the distant Universe to reveal a galaxy cluster called Abell 2537.
Galaxy clusters such as this one contain thousands of galaxies of all ages
column2: shapes and sizes
column3: together totalling a mass thousands of times greater than that of the Milky Way. These groupings of galaxies are colossal — they are the largest structures in the Universe to be held together by their own gravity.

column1: Clusters are useful in probing mysterious cosmic phenomena like dark matter and dark energy
column2: the latter of which is thought to define the geometry of the entire Universe. There is so much matter stuffed into a cluster like Abell 2537 that its gravity has visible effects on its surroundings. Abell 2537’s gravity warps the very structure of its environment (spacetime)
column3: causing light to travel along distorted paths through space. This phenomenon can produce a magnifying effect
column4: allowing us to see objects that lie behind the cluster and are thus otherwise unobservable from Earth. Abell 2537 is a particularly efficient lens
column5: as demonstrated by the stretched stripes and streaking arcs visible in the frame. These smeared shapes are in fact galaxies
column6: their light heavily distorted by the gravitational field of Abell 2537.

column1: This spectacular scene was captured by Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys and Wide-Field Camera 3 as part of an observing programme called RELICS.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/da8be7c840f558dda507d36dd4371c62;2017-06-09;966.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/24893155568/in/album-72157667717916600;abell2537
37731704661.0;Size can be deceiving;"As far as galaxies are concerned
column2: size can be deceiving. Some of the largest galaxies in the Universe are dormant
column3: while some dwarf galaxies
column4: such as ESO 553-46 imaged here by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope
column5: can produce stars at a hair-raising rate. In fact
column6: ESO 553-46 has one of the highest rates of star formation of the 1000 or so galaxies nearest to the Milky Way. No mean feat for such a diminutive galaxy!

column1: Clusters of young
column2: hot stars are speckling the galaxy
column3: burning with a fierce blue glow. The intense radiation they produce also causes surrounding gas to light up
column4: which is bright red in this image. The small mass and distinctive colouring of galaxies of this type prompted astronomers to classify them
column5: appropriately
column6: as blue compact dwarfs (BCD).

column1: Lacking the clear core and structure that many larger galaxies — such as the Milky Way — have
column2: BCDs such as ESO 553-46 are composed of many large clusters of stars bound together by gravity. Their chemical makeup is interesting to astronomers
column3: since they contain relatively little dust and few elements heavier than helium
column4: which are produced in stars and distributed via supernova explosions. Such conditions are strikingly similar to those that existed in the early Universe
column5: when the first galaxies were beginning to form.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/ca750d9f45314db7a5cffef7125a7da5;2017-06-19;519.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/37731704661/in/album-72157667717916600;eso55346

column1: 37021949231.0;Mysterious supernovae;"Like firecrackers lighting up the sky on New Year’s Eve
column2: the majestic spiral arms of NGC 5559 are alight with new stars being born. NGC 5559 is a spiral galaxy
column3: with spiral arms filled with gas and dust sweeping out around the bright galactic bulge. These arms are a rich environment for star formation
column4: dotted with a festive array of colors including the newborn stars glowing blue as a result of their immensely high temperatures.

column1: NGC 5559 was discovered by astronomer William Herschel in 1785 and lies approximately 240 million light-years away in the northern constellation of Boötes (the Herdsman).

column2: a calcium-rich supernova called 2001co was observed in NGC 5559. Calcium-rich supernovae (Ca-rich SNe) are described as “fast-and-faint
column3: ” as they're less luminous than other types of supernovae and also evolve more rapidly
column4: to reveal spectra dominated by strong calcium lines. 2001co occurred within the disk of NGC 5559 near star-forming regions
column5: but Ca-rich SNe are often observed at large distances from the nearest galaxy
column6: raising curious questions about their progenitors.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/57ae3f133a7ee1e8e5bdcca0d802ed63;2016-10-27;936.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/37021949231/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc5559

27514162254.0;Astronauts Hoffman and Musgrave install the Magnetic Sensing System on HST;Astronauts Jeffrey A. Hoffman (left) and F. Story Musgrave are partially silhouetted against the Indian Ocean as they work to install the Magnetic Sensing System (MSS) on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). Musgrave is anchored to the end of the Space Shuttle Endeavour's Remote Manipulator System (RMS) arm. The HST is positioned along the southern end of Madagascar
column2: 325 nautical miles away. Visible on the western coast are the sediment laden Onilahy and Fiherenana Rivers which empty into Saint Augustin Bay. North of Fiherenana River is the Mangoky River. The circular feature on the southern end of Madagascar and to the right of HST is the L'ivakoany Mountains. The eastern coast is relatively straight compared to the western coast.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/7b325873ea6a5730fa31674919a76aa8;2010-09-02;4716.0;4662.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27514162254/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

column1: 28240992795.0;STS-125 Crew after the Landing of Space Shuttle Atlantis;"The STS-125 crew pose for a photo near Space Shuttle Atlantis on Runway 22 at Edwards Air Force Base in California following their landing
column2: which ended the STS-125 mission to repair and upgrade NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. From the left are astronauts Mike Massimino
column3: mission specialist; Gregory C. Johnson
column4: pilot; Scott Altman
column5: commander; Megan McArthur
column6: John Grunsfeld
column7: Andrew Feustel
column8: and Michael Good
column9: all mission specialists.

column1: The main landing gear of Atlantis touched down at 8:39:05 a.m. PDT on May 24
column2: 2009. Nose gear touchdown was at 8:39:15 a.m. Wheel-stop was at 8:40:15 a.m.
column3: bringing the mission's elapsed time to 12 days
column4: 21 hours
column5: 37 minutes
column6: 9 seconds. Landing opportunities on May 22
column7: May 23
column8: and May 24 were waved off due to weather concerns at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida
column9: the shuttle's primary landing site.

column1: Through five spacewalks
column2: Hubble was refurbished and upgraded with state-of-the-art science instruments that will expand Hubble's capabilities and extended its operational lifespan.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/410b82c0a44dd9f307fc5b80bf0203cb;2009-06-02;2250.0;3000.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28240992795/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission astronauts shuttlemission spaceshuttle spaceshuttleatlantis

column1: 28025362755.0;Training Session in the Space Vehicle Mockup Facility;An unidentified member of the STS-109 crew uses a device called a Sky genie to simulate rappelling from a troubled shuttle in a training session in the Space Vehicle Mockup Facility at the Johnson Space Center (JSC). The mockup is called the Full Fuselage Trainer (FFT). This exercise trains the crewmembers for procedures to follow in egressing a troubled shuttle on the ground. STS-109 will be the 108th shuttle flight and the fourth Hubble Space Telescope (HST) servicing mission.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/2da0a151633786d5b5f7775fa839dd8c;2016-07-01;3865.0;2508.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28025362755/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109
28025363585.0;Astronaut Scott D. Altman;Astronaut Scott D. Altman
column2: STS-109 mission commander
column3: dons a training version of the full-pressure launch and entry suit prior to a training session in one of the trainer/mockups (out of frame) in the Space Vehicle Mockup Facility at the Johnson Space Center (JSC). Altman is assisted by United Space Alliance (USA) crew trainer David Pogue. STS-109 will be the 108th shuttle flight and the fourth Hubble Space Telescope (HST) servicing mission.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/1592feac0f2e56afc44a1070b355ecb9;2016-07-01;2526.0;3853.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28025363585/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109

column1: 28143690616.0;STS-125 MS1 Good and MS4 Massimino during EVA2;STS-125 Mission Specialist 1 (MS1) Michael Good (diagonal red stripes) and MS4 Mike Massimino (broken horizontal stripes) work to open the -V3 side doors on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) during Rate Sensor Unit (RSU) removal and replacement operations. Good is standing on the Manipulator Foot Restraint (MFR)
column2: which is connected to the Shuttle Remote Manipulator System (SRMS)/Canadarm Latching End Effector (LEE). This photo was taken during the second session of extravehicular activity (EVA2).;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/e530108d130a9494c477fc73c55a4f70;2009-05-15;2025.0;3072.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28143690616/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission astronauts shuttlemission spaceshuttle eva spacewalk extravehicularactivity spaceshuttleatlantis

column1: 27562325123.0;STS-125 MS1 Good during EVA2;View of STS-125 Mission Specialist 1 (MS1) Michael Good working to secure Crew Aids and Tools (CATs) to the Manipulator Foot Restraint (MFR) on the Shuttle Remote Manipulator System (SRMS)/Canadarm end effector near the beginning of the second session of extravehicular activity (EVA2).;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/a961419f899628733b92623e45f48a93;2009-05-15;2034.0;3072.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27562325123/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission shuttlemission spaceshuttle astronaut eva extravehicularactivity spacewalk spaceshuttleatlantis

28240472225.0;STS-125 MS3 Grunsfeld during EVA5;STS-125 Mission Specialist 3 (MS3) John Grunsfeld participates in the mission's fifth and final session of extravehicular activity (EVA) as work continue to refurbish and upgrade the Hubble Space Telescope. During the seven-hour and two-minute spacewalk
column2: Grunsfeld and mission specialist Andrew Feustel (out of frame) installed a battery group replacement
column3: removed and replaced a Fine Guidance Sensor
column4: and installed three thermal blankets (NOBLs) that protect Hubble's electronics.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/772c695855ef3f89921760bba834d53d;2009-05-18;1993.0;3000.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28240472225/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission shuttlemission spaceshuttle astronaut eva spacewalk extravehicularactivity

column1: 28331247955.0;Deployment of the Hubble Space Telescope;"In this April 25
column3: photograph taken by the crew of the STS-31 space shuttle mission
column4: the Hubble Space Telescope is suspended above shuttle Discovery's cargo bay some 332 nautical miles above Earth. The Canadian-built Remote Manipulator System (RMS) arm
column5: controlled from in-cabin by the astronaut crew members
column6: held the huge telescope in this position during pre-deployment procedures
column7: which included extension of solar array panels and antennae.

column1: STS-31 was the tenth launch of the shuttle Discovery. On board were Commander Loren J. Shriver
column2: Pilot Charles F. Bolden
column3: Jr. (now NASA Administrator)
column4: Mission Specialists Steven A. Hawley
column5: Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn D. Sullivan (now NOAA Administrator). To launch Hubble into an orbit that guaranteed longevity
column6: Discovery soared to a record altitude of 600 km.

column1: Image Credit: NASA";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/b51c787de52c7fa60f2bbc399de1bbe4;2009-07-01;1032.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Deployment;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28331247955/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa hubbledeployment sts31
36306072281.0;M17;"Illuminated by ultraviolet radiation from young
column2: massive stars on the right side of this photograph
column4: also known as the Omega Nebula or Swan Nebula
column5: is one of the largest star-forming regions in the Milky Way galaxy. Hubble’s stunning image of a central portion of the nebula has been colorized to highlight certain wavelengths of light. Green represents oxygen while red reveals hydrogen and infrared light.

column1: The Omega Nebula was discovered in 1745 by the Swiss astronomer Jean-Philippe Loys de Chéseaux. It is located 5
column2: 500 light-years from Earth in the constellation Sagittarius. The nebula has an apparent magnitude of 6 and can be seen with a pair of binoculars. M17
column3: which appears near M16 and M18 in the sky
column4: is best viewed on clear nights in August.

column1: M17 contains one of our galaxy’s youngest star clusters
column2: at only 1 million years old. However
column3: many of the young stars in this cluster are impossible to see because of the gas and dust that surrounds them. The powerful radiation from the young stars evaporates and erodes the dense clouds of cold gas in which new stars form. One such pocket of gas is seen at the center of the brightest region of the nebula (near the bottom of this image) and is about 10 times larger than our solar system. Other dense pockets of gas have formed the remarkable dark features jutting inward from the bottom left corner of the image.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M17
column2: see:

column2: or the Ring Nebula
column3: is a planetary nebula
column4: the glowing remains of a sun-like star. The tiny white dot in the center of the nebula is the star’s hot core
column5: called a white dwarf. M57 is about 2
column6: 000 light-years away in the constellation Lyra
column7: and is best observed during August. Discovered by the French astronomer Antoine Darquier de Pellepoix in 1779
column8: the Ring Nebula has an apparent magnitude of 8.8 and can be spotted with moderately sized telescopes.

column1: M57 is tilted toward Earth so that astronomers see the ring face-on. This gorgeous
column2: high-resolution Hubble image helped astronomers determine that the nebula’s shape is more complicated than initially thought. The blue gas in the nebula’s center is actually a football-shaped structure seen end-on that pierces the red
column3: doughnut-shaped material. The inner rim of the ring displays an intricate structure of dark
column4: irregular knots of dense gas that the stellar winds have not yet been able to blow away. The knots and their tails look like spokes in a bicycle.

column1: This image of M57 has been colorized to illustrate the nebula’s chemical composition. The deep blue color in the center represents helium
column2: the light blue color of the inner ring is the glow of hydrogen and oxygen
column3: and the reddish color of the outer ring is from nitrogen and sulfur.

column1: For more information on Hubble’s observations of M57

column1: 36046741050.0;M43;"Separated from the Orion Nebula (M42) by only a dark lane of dust
column2: M43 was recognized as a distinct nebula by the French astronomer Jean-Jacques d’Ortous de Mairan in 1731. A massive star is illuminating M43 and sculpting its landscape of dust and gas with its radiation. Astronomers call the area a miniature Orion Nebula because of its small size and the single star that is shaping it. The Orion Nebula itself is much larger and has four hefty stars that are carving the dust-and-gas terrain.

column1: Both nebulas are part of the massive stellar nursery called the Orion Molecular Cloud Complex
column2: which includes several other nebulas
column3: such as the Horsehead Nebula (Barnard 33) and the Flame Nebula (NGC 2024). At the center of this view of M43
column4: taken using infrared and visible-light cameras on Hubble
column5: sits the massive star that is warping the gas and dust around it.

column1: Located 1
column2: 600 light-years from Earth
column3: M43 has an apparent magnitude of 9. It can be spotted through a small telescope and is best observed during January.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M43
column2: see:

column2: Charles Messier discovered spiral galaxy M66 along with its neighbor M65
column3: both of which belong to the Leo Triplet of galaxies. (The third member
column4: NGC 3628
column5: was discovered by William Herschel in 1784 and is not included in the Messier catalog). M66 is located 35 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Leo and has an apparent magnitude of 8.9. Best observed during April
column6: M66 can be spotted with a small telescope.

column1: Showing a large portion of M66
column2: this Hubble photo is a composite of images obtained at visible and infrared wavelengths. The images have been combined to represent the real colors of the galaxy.

column1: This view highlights the fascinating anatomy of M66. Because the galaxies in the Leo Triplet interact with one another
column2: each has an effect on its neighbors’ structures. M66 displays asymmetric spiral arms and a core that appears to be off center — features likely caused by the gravitational pull of the other two galaxies in the Leo Triplet.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M66
column2: see:

26772095589.0;Hubble Space Telescope Major Configuration Elements;"This illustration shows the Hubble Space Telescope's (HST's) major configuration elements. The spacecraft has three interacting systems: the Support System Module (SSM)
column2: an outer structure that houses the other systems and provides services such as power
column3: communication
column4: and control; the Optical Telescope Assembly (OTA)
column5: which collects and concentrates the incoming light in the focal plane for use by the Scientific Instruments (SI); and five SIs. The SI Control and Data Handling (CDH) unit controls the five SIs
column6: four that are housed in an aft section focal plane structure and one that is placed along the circumference of the spacecraft.

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column3: is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit. By placing the telescope in space
column4: astronomers are able to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble detects objects 25 times fainter than the dimmest objects seen from Earth and provides astronomers with an observable universe 250 times larger than is visible from ground-based telescopes
column5: extending our view more than 13 billion light-years away. Hubble views galaxies
column6: stars
column7: planets
column8: comets
column9: planet formation in other solar systems
column10: and even unusual phenomena such as quasars
column11: with 10 times the clarity of ground-based telescopes.

column1: The Marshall Space Flight Center had responsibility for design
column2: development
column3: and construction of the observatory. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury
column4: Connecticut
column5: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. The Lockheed Missile and Space Company of Sunnyvale
column6: California
column7: produced the protective outer shroud and spacecraft systems
column8: and assembled and tested the finished telescope.

27414026284.0;Cat's Eye Nebula;"Though the Cat's Eye Nebula was one of the first planetary nebulae to be discovered
column2: it is one of the most complex such nebulae ever seen. Planetary nebulae form when Sun-like stars gently eject their outer gaseous layers
column3: creating amazing and confounding shapes. The Cat's Eye Nebula
column4: also known as NGC 6543
column5: is a visual "fossil record" of the dynamics and late evolution of a dying star. It is estimated to be 1
column6: 000 years old.

column2: initial Hubble observations revealed the nebula's surprisingly intricate structures
column3: including gas shells
column4: jets of high-speed gas
column5: and unusual shock-induced knots of gas. Subsequent Hubble images showed a bull's-eye pattern of eleven or more concentric rings
column6: or shells
column7: of dust around the Cat's Eye. Each "ring" is actually the edge of a spherical bubble seen projected onto the sky — that's why it appears bright along its outer edge.

column1: Observations suggest the star that created the Cat's Eye Nebula ejected its mass in a series of pulses at 1
column2: 500-year intervals. These convulsions created dust shells
column3: each of which contains as much mass as all of the planets in our solar system combined (still only one percent of the Sun's mass). These concentric shells make a layered
column4: onion-skin structure around the dying star. The view from Hubble is like seeing an onion cut in half
column5: where each skin layer is discernible.

column1: 26772238369.0;Hubble Space Telescope Solar Array
column2: Secondary Deployment Test;"This is a view of a solar cell blanket deployed on a water table during the solar array deployment test. The Hubble Space Telescope's solar arrays provide power to the spacecraft. The arrays are mounted on opposite sides of the spacecraft
column3: on the forward shell of the Support Systems Module. Each array stands on a 4-foot mast that supports a retractable wing of solar panels 40 feet (12.1 meters) long and 8.2 feet (2.5 meters) wide
column4: in full extension. The arrays rotate so that the solar cells face the Sun as much as possible to harness the Sun's energy. The Space Telescope Operations Control Center at the Goddard Space Center operates the array
column5: extending the panels and maneuvering the spacecraft to focus maximum sunlight on the arrays.

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column3: is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit. By placing the telescope in space
column4: astronomers are able to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble's solar array was designed by the European Space Agency and built by British Aerospace. The Marshall Space Flight Center had overall responsibility for design
column5: development
column6: and construction of the observatory.

column2: a primary and a secondary
column3: to collect and focus light from selected celestial objects.

column1: Hubble is the first of NASA's great observatories and the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made. The purpose of Hubble is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit by placing the telescope in space
column2: enabling astronomers to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery (STS-31 mission) into Earth orbit in April 1990.

36368449165.0;M5;"Discovered in 1702 by the German astronomer Gottfried Kirch
column2: M5 is one of the oldest globular clusters in the Milky Way galaxy. With an apparent magnitude of 6.7 and a location 25
column3: 000 light-years away in the constellation Serpens
column4: M5 appears as a patch of light with a pair of binoculars and is best viewed during July.

column1: This image from Hubble captures M5 in stunning detail
column2: resolving the patch of light into individual stars. A composite of exposures taken with visible and infrared cameras
column3: this image features over 100
column4: 000 stars. A majority of M5’s stars formed more than 12 billion years ago
column5: but there are some unexpected newcomers on the scene
column6: adding some vitality to this aging population.

column1: Stars in globular clusters are believed to form in the same stellar nursery and grow old together. The most massive stars age quickly
column2: exhausting their fuel supply in less than a million years
column3: and end their lives in spectacular supernova explosions. This process should have left the ancient cluster M5 with only old
column4: low-mass stars.

column1: Yet astronomers have spotted many young
column2: blue stars amongst the ancient stars in this cluster. Astronomers think that these laggard youngsters
column3: called blue stragglers
column4: were created either by collisions between stars or other stellar interactions. Such events are easy to imagine in densely populated globular clusters
column5: in which up to a few million stars are tightly packed together.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M5

36231885071.0;M14;"Discovered by Charles Messier in 1764
column2: the globular cluster M14 is home to over 150
column3: 000 stars and has an apparent magnitude of 8.3. It is located 29
column4: 000 light-years away from Earth in the constellation Ophiuchus
column5: and is best observed with a telescope during July.

column1: In the summer of 1938
column2: M14 played host to a nova — an extraordinarily rare event in a cluster of its kind. A nova is a sudden stellar eruption where
column3: in just a few days
column4: a star’s brightness increases by a factor of 10
column5: 000. Then over the following months the outburst fades away and the star returns to its normal brightness.

column1: This image of M14 was assembled using both infrared and visible-light observations from Hubble. Its stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera used to take the exposures. The camera consisted of four light detectors
column2: one of which provided a higher resolution but had a smaller field of view than the other three. Because the detector with the higher resolution did not cover as much area as the others
column3: black regions are left around its image segment when the exposures from all four detectors are combined into one picture.

column1: 36467910325.0;M87;"The elliptical galaxy M87 is the home of several trillion stars
column2: a supermassive black hole and a family of roughly 15
column3: 000 globular star clusters. For comparison
column4: our Milky Way galaxy contains only a few hundred billion stars and about 150 globular clusters. The monstrous M87 is the dominant member of the neighboring Virgo cluster of galaxies
column5: which contains some 2
column6: 000 galaxies. Discovered in 1781 by Charles Messier
column7: this galaxy is located 54 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Virgo. It has an apparent magnitude of 9.6 and can be observed using a small telescope most easily in May.

column1: This Hubble image of M87 is a composite of individual observations in visible and infrared light. Its most striking features are the blue jet near the center and the myriad of star-like globular clusters scattered throughout the image.
The jet is a black-hole-powered stream of material that is being ejected from M87’s core. As gaseous material from the center of the galaxy accretes onto the black hole
column2: the energy released produces a stream of subatomic particles that are accelerated to velocities near the speed of light.

column1: At the center of the Virgo cluster
column2: M87 may have accumulated some of its many globular clusters by gravitationally pulling them from nearby dwarf galaxies that seem to be devoid of such clusters today.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M87

35651134244.0;M94;"M94 is a spiral galaxy located 16 million light-years away in the constellation Canes Venatici. It was discovered in 1781 by Pierre Méchain
column2: a French astronomer for whom an asteroid was named in 2002. The galaxy has an apparent magnitude of 9 and can be spotted through a small telescope. The best time of year to observe M94 is during May.

column1: This Hubble image of M94’s core is composed of observations taken at visible and infrared wavelengths. New stars are forming at a high rate within the bright ring. This region is known as a starburst ring. The cause of this peculiarly shaped star-forming region is likely a pressure wave traveling outward from the galactic center
column2: compressing the gas and dust in the outer regions. The compression of material means the gas starts to collapse into denser clouds. Inside these dense clouds
column3: gravity pulls the gas and dust together until the temperature and pressure are high enough for stars to be born.

column1: Although M94 was initially believed to be roughly 30
column2: 000 light-years in diameter
column3: two faint spiral arms (not visible in this image) were recently discovered outside of its core region that extend far out into space. This discovery has effectively tripled the galaxy’s known diameter. M94 is also notable for its deficiency of dark matter relative to other galaxies. Astronomers do not know why it lacks the normal amount of dark matter
column4: but the galaxy has been the subject of extensive study as a result.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M94

36484805985.0;M70;"In this image
column2: Hubble has captured the brilliant
column3: compact center of the globular cluster M70 in both visible and infrared light. Quarters are always tight in globular clusters
column4: where the mutual hold of gravity binds together hundreds of thousands of stars in a small region of space. M70 is particularly fascinating because it has undergone what is known as a core collapse. This means that even more stars squeeze into the object’s core than in an average globular cluster.

column1: The legions of stars in a globular cluster orbit about a shared center of gravity. Some stars maintain relatively circular orbits
column2: while others loop out into the cluster’s fringes. As the stars interact with each other over time
column3: lighter stars tend to pick up speed and migrate out toward the cluster’s edges
column4: while the heavier stars are slower and congregate toward the center. This huddling effect produces the characteristically dense center of core-collapsed clusters. About a fifth of the roughly 150 globular clusters in the Milky Way have undergone a core collapse.

column1: M70 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. It is located 30
column2: 000 light-years away in the constellation Sagittarius. With an apparent magnitude of 9.1
column3: the cluster can be observed through a small telescope best in the month of August.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M70
column2: see:

39878610335.0;M75;"This beautiful image features the globular star cluster M75. Discovered in 1780 by Pierre Méchain
column2: M75 was also observed by Charles Messier and added to his catalog later that year.

column1: M75 is the most centrally concentrated globular cluster in Messier's catalog
column2: with the majority of its stars located in a large nucleus. In total
column3: there are about 400
column4: 000 stars in the globular cluster. M75 is believed to be around 13 billion years old and sits approximately 67
column5: 500 light-years away from Earth.

column1: Located in the western part of Sagittarius
column2: M75 has a magnitude of 8.6. The cluster is surprisingly easy to see in binoculars and telescopes thanks to it being extremely condensed in the center. However
column3: because of its compact nature
column4: M75 can barely be distinguished from a star when viewed in binoculars. Telescopes that are 10 inches across or larger are needed to resolve some of the stars in the cluster. August is the best month to observe M75.

column1: This Hubble image of M75 is a composite of observations taken in near-infrared and visible light using the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 and the Wide Field Camera 3. The image features the bright central core of M75 and its surrounding stars. The Hubble observations were made to help astronomers better understand the stellar populations in globular clusters and to investigate the clusters' potential for harboring central
column2: intermediate-mass black holes (with approximately one hundred to one million times the mass of our Sun).

column1: 36300205812.0;M100;"This Hubble image of a region of M100 shows a type of pulsating star called a Cepheid variable. These stars are reliable distance indicators to galaxies. The top three frames
column2: taken on three different dates in May 1994
column3: reveal that the star (in the center of each box) changes brightness. Cepheids go through these changes rhythmically over a few weeks. The interval it takes for the Cepheid to complete one pulsation is a direct indication of the star’s intrinsic brightness. Astronomers can use this brightness to precisely determine the galaxy’s distance.

column1: 28025338905.0;Galapagos Islands;The astronauts on board the Space Shuttle Columbia took this 70mm picture featuring the Galapagos Islands. For orientation purposes

column1: 26341511059.0;Hubble Sees Nearby Asteroids Photobombing Distant Galaxies;"Like rude relatives who jump in front your vacation snapshots of landscapes
column2: some of our solar system's asteroids have photobombed deep images of the universe taken by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. These asteroids reside
column3: on average
column4: only about 160 million miles from Earth — right around the corner in astronomical terms. Yet they've horned their way into this picture of thousands of galaxies scattered across space and time at inconceivably farther distances.

column1: This Hubble photo of a random patch of sky is part of a survey called Frontier Fields. The colorful image contains thousands of galaxies
column2: including massive yellowish ellipticals and majestic blue spirals. Much smaller
column3: fragmentary blue galaxies are sprinkled throughout the field. The reddest objects are most likely the farthest galaxies
column4: whose light has been stretched into the red part of the spectrum by the expansion of space.

column1: Intruding across the picture are asteroid trails that appear as curved or S-shaped streaks. Rather than leaving one long trail
column2: the asteroids appear in multiple Hubble exposures that have been combined into one image. Of the 20 total asteroid sightings for this field
column3: seven are unique objects. Of these seven asteroids
column4: only two were earlier identified. The others were too faint to be seen previously.

column1: The trails look curved due to an observational effect called parallax. As Hubble orbits around Earth
column2: an asteroid will appear to move along an arc with respect to the vastly more distant background stars and galaxies.

column1: This parallax effect is somewhat similar to the effect you see from a moving car
column2: in which trees by the side of the road appear to be passing by much more rapidly than background objects at much larger distances. The motion of Earth around the Sun
column3: and the motion of the asteroids along their orbits
column4: are other contributing factors to the apparent skewing of asteroid paths.

column1: All the asteroids were found manually
column2: the majority by "blinking" consecutive exposures to capture apparent asteroid motion. Astronomers found a unique asteroid for every 10 to 20 hours of exposure time.

column1: The Frontier Fields program is a collaboration among NASA's Great Observatories and other telescopes to study six massive galaxy clusters and their effects. Using a different camera
column2: pointing in a slightly different direction
column3: Hubble photographed six so-called "parallel fields" at the same time it photographed the massive galaxy clusters. This maximized Hubble's observational efficiency in doing deep space exposures. These parallel fields are similar in depth to the famous Hubble Deep Field
column4: and include galaxies about four-billion times fainter than can be seen by the human eye.

column1: This picture is of the parallel field for the galaxy cluster Abell 370. It was assembled from images taken in visible and infrared light. The field's position on the sky is near the ecliptic
column2: the plane of our solar system. This is the zone in which most asteroids reside
column3: which is why Hubble astronomers saw so many crossings. Hubble deep-sky observations taken along a line-of-sight near the plane of our solar system commonly record asteroid trails.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope is a project of international cooperation between NASA and ESA (European Space Agency). NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt
column2: Maryland
column3: manages the telescope. The Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore conducts Hubble science operations. STScI is operated for NASA by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy
column4: Inc.
column5: in Washington
column6: D.C.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/303db688fe126f0e7686035c87489b45;2017-11-02;1102.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/26341511059/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 33686043241.0;The NGC and its modern counterpart;"Some astronomical objects have endearing or quirky nicknames
column2: inspired by mythology or their own appearance. Take
column3: for example
column4: the constellation of Orion (the Hunter)
column5: the Sombrero Galaxy
column6: the Horsehead Nebula
column7: or even the Milky Way. However
column8: the vast majority of cosmic objects appear in astronomical catalogs
column9: and are given rather less poetic names based on the order of their discovery.

column1: Two galaxies are clearly visible in this Hubble image
column2: the larger of which is NGC 4424. This galaxy is cataloged in the New General Catalogue of Nebulae and Clusters of Stars (NGC)
column3: which was compiled in 1888. The NGC is one of the largest astronomical catalogs
column4: which is why so many Hubble pictures feature NGC objects. In total there are 7
column5: 840 entries in the catalog and they are also generally the larger
column6: brighter
column7: and more eye-catching objects in the night sky
column8: and hence the ones more easily spotted by early stargazers.

column1: The smaller
column2: flatter
column3: bright galaxy sitting just below NGC 4424 is named LEDA 213994. The Lyon-Meudon Extragalactic Database (LEDA) is far more modern than the NGC. Created in 1983 at the Lyon Observatory it contains millions of objects. However
column4: many NGC objects still go by their initial names simply because they were christened within the NGC first. No astronomer can resist a good acronym
column5: and “LEDA” is more appealing than “the LMED
column6: ” perhaps thanks to the old astronomical affinity with mythology when it comes to naming things: Leda was a princess in Ancient Greek mythology.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/91103f4428032c3e4cfcbb4e833c0f20;2016-10-26;1030.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33686043241/in/album-72157667717916600;leda213994 ngc4424

column1: 27747552400.0;Hubble's Sharpest View of the Orion Nebula;"This dramatic image offers a peek inside a cavern of roiling dust and gas where thousands of stars are forming. The image
column2: taken by the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) aboard NASA's Hubble Space Telescope
column3: represents the sharpest view ever taken of this region
column4: called the Orion Nebula. More than 3
column5: 000 stars of various sizes appear in this image. Some of them have never been seen in visible light. These stars reside in a dramatic dust-and-gas landscape of plateaus
column6: mountains
column7: and valleys that are reminiscent of the Grand Canyon.

column1: The Orion Nebula is a picture book of star formation
column2: from the massive
column3: young stars that are shaping the nebula to the pillars of dense gas that may be the homes of budding stars. The bright central region is the home of the four heftiest stars in the nebula. The stars are called the Trapezium because they are arranged in a trapezoid pattern. Ultraviolet light unleashed by these stars is carving a cavity in the nebula and disrupting the growth of hundreds of smaller stars. Located near the Trapezium stars are stars still young enough to have disks of material encircling them. These disks are called protoplanetary disks or "proplyds" and are too small to see clearly in this image. The disks are the building blocks of solar systems.

column1: The bright glow at upper left is from M43
column2: a small region being shaped by a massive
column3: young star's ultraviolet light. Astronomers call the region a miniature Orion Nebula because only one star is sculpting the landscape. The Orion Nebula has four such stars. Next to M43 are dense
column4: dark pillars of dust and gas that point toward the Trapezium. These pillars are resisting erosion from the Trapezium's intense ultraviolet light. The glowing region on the right reveals arcs and bubbles formed when stellar winds - streams of charged particles ejected from the Trapezium stars - collide with material.

column1: The faint red stars near the bottom are the myriad brown dwarfs that Hubble spied for the first time in the nebula in visible light. Sometimes called "failed stars
column2: " brown dwarfs are cool objects that are too small to be ordinary stars because they cannot sustain nuclear fusion in their cores the way our Sun does. The dark red column
column3: below
column4: left
column5: shows an illuminated edge of the cavity wall.

column1: The Orion Nebula is 1
column2: 500 light-years away
column3: the nearest star-forming region to Earth. Astronomers used 520 Hubble images
column4: taken in five colors
column5: to make this picture. They also added ground-based photos to fill out the nebula. The ACS mosaic covers approximately the apparent angular size of the full moon.

column1: The Orion observations were taken between 2004 and 2005.
For more information

column1: 28265165379.0;Twins with differences;This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image shows a spiral galaxy known as NGC 7331. First spotted by the prolific galaxy hunter William Herschel in 1784
column2: NGC 7331 is located about 45 million light-years away in the constellation of Pegasus (The Winged Horse). Facing us partially edge-on
column3: the galaxy showcases it’s beautiful arms which swirl like a whirlpool around its bright central region. Astronomers took this image using Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3)
column4: as they were observing an extraordinary exploding star — a supernova — which can still be faintly seen as a tiny red dot near the galaxy’s central yellow core. Named SN2014C
column5: it rapidly evolved from a supernova containing very little Hydrogen to one that is Hydrogen-rich — in just one year. This rarely observed metamorphosis was luminous at high energies and provides unique insight into the poorly understood final phases of massive stars. NGC 7331 is similar in size
column6: shape
column7: and mass to the Milky Way. It also has a comparable star formation rate
column8: hosts a similar number of stars
column9: has a central supermassive black hole and comparable spiral arms. The primary difference between our galaxies is that NGC 7331 is an unbarred spiral galaxy — it lacks a “bar” of stars
column10: gas and dust cutting through its nucleus
column11: as we see in the Milky Way. Its central bulge also displays a quirky and unusual rotation pattern
column12: spinning in the opposite direction to the galactic disc itself. By studying similar galaxies we hold a scientific mirror up to our own
column13: allowing us to build a better understanding of our galactic environment which we cannot always observe
column14: and of galactic behaviour and evolution as a whole.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/39ff44e25d2a8bc5ad81573708421ba3;2018-01-29;778.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28265165379/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc7331

column1: 27233547739.0;M79;"Discovered by Charles Messier’s colleague Pierre Méchain in 1780
column2: M79 is a globular cluster in the constellation Lepus the Hare. Best observed in the month of January
column3: the cluster has an apparent magnitude of about 8. The dense heart of the cluster can be spotted as a small
column4: fuzzy patch in binoculars
column5: but observers will need at least a medium-sized telescope to resolve M79’s individual stars and outer environs.

column1: While most globular clusters in our Milky Way galaxy appear around the galactic core in Sagittarius
column2: M79 is one of the few seen on the opposite side of the sky
column3: away from the galaxy’s center. That’s because Earth lies between M79 and the middle of the galaxy. M79 is about 41
column4: 000 light-years from us but roughly 60
column5: 000 light-years from the galactic center.

column1: M79 is also one of just two globular clusters in the Messier catalog that our galaxy might have stolen from other nearby galaxies in the not-too-distant past. An unusual density of red giant stars in the direction of the constellation Canis Major (not far from M79) could be the remains of a dwarf galaxy that’s currently being shredded and absorbed by our Milky Way galaxy. M79 might have been snatched from this small galaxy
column2: known as the Canis Major Dwarf Galaxy.

column1: This image of M79 combines visible and ultraviolet observations taken by Hubble in 1995 and 1997. Not surprisingly
column2: the cluster contains many aging red giant stars. However
column3: Hubble has helped show that M79 also includes numerous “blue stragglers
column4: ” which are brighter and bluer than astronomers would expect stellar residents of an old globular cluster to be. Astronomers suspect these strange
column5: youthful-looking objects are the products of their compact environments
column6: forming either from stellar mergers or from one star pulling in material from a close neighbor.

column1: For more information on Hubble’s observations of M79
column2: see: hubblesite.org/news_release/news/2017-37

column1: 25902696937.0;M62;"M62 is known for being one of the most irregularly shaped globular clusters in our galaxy. This might be because it is one of the closest globular clusters to the center of our galaxy and is affected by galactic tidal forces
column2: displacing many of the cluster's stars toward the southeast.

column1: M62 has an extremely dense core of 150
column2: 000 stars. In 2007
column3: astronomers discovered a stellar-mass black hole in M62
column4: one of the first to ever be found in a globular cluster. According to observations from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory
column5: M62 also contains a large number of X-ray binaries
column6: which formed in close encounters between stars in the cluster.

column1: This Hubble observation was taken in ultraviolet and visible light using the Advanced Camera for Surveys and Wide Field Camera 3. Most of the globular cluster is featured in this observation
column2: with the core focused toward the top right. Hubble made these observations to help astronomers study the characteristics of globular clusters
column3: measure the mass of M62's black hole
column4: and help determine the formation and evolution of cluster binaries.

column1: Charles Messier discovered M62 in 1771. The globular cluster is almost 12 billion years old. M62 has a magnitude of 6.6 and is located in the constellation Ophiuchus
column2: approximately 22
column3: 200 light-years away from Earth. Best observed in July
column4: the cluster is easily found southeast of the bright star Antares and can be seen as a hazy patch with binoculars. Small telescopes reveal a comet-like shape
column5: while telescopes 8 inches or larger will resolve more stars.

column1: 36071217760.0;M84;"Discovered by Charles Messier in 1781
column2: M84 is an elliptical galaxy located 60 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Virgo. It is one of over a thousand galaxies that make up the Virgo cluster. With an apparent magnitude of 10.1
column3: the galaxy can be spotted using a moderately sized telescope most easily during May.

column1: This image of M84 combines observations taken by Hubble at both visible and infrared wavelengths. Although the image does not show the entire galaxy
column2: it highlights one of M84’s most fascinating features: its central region. Previous Hubble observations of M84 taken with a spectrograph have indicated that the galaxy hosts a supermassive black hole at its core.

column1: M84 is also notable for being the site of two stellar explosions called supernovas
column2: one discovered in 1957 and the other in 1991.

36274887712.0;M20;"Discovered by Charles Messier in 1764
column2: M20 is a star-forming nebula located 9
column3: 000 light-years away from Earth in the constellation Sagittarius. Also known as the Trifid Nebula
column4: M20 has an apparent magnitude of 6.3 and can be spotted with a small telescope. It is best observed during August.

column1: This eerie Hubble image features the center of the Trifid Nebula and the three wing-like bands of thick dust for which the nebula was named. A group of recently formed
column2: massive
column3: bright stars toward the center of the nebula is easily visible. These stars are releasing a flood of ultraviolet radiation that dramatically influences the structure and evolution of the surrounding nebula. Star formation is no longer occurring in the immediate vicinity of this group of bright stars because their intense radiation has blown away the gas and dust from which new stars are made.

column1: The image’s stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera used to take the exposures. The camera consisted of four light detectors
column2: one of which provided a higher resolution but had a smaller field of view than the other three. Because the detector with the higher resolution did not cover as much area as the others
column3: black regions were left when the images from all four detectors were combined into one picture.

column1: This Hubble image of M20 has been colorized to indicate the presence of oxygen
column2: sulfur and hydrogen.

36046827920.0;M53;"Thousands and thousands of brilliant stars make up the globular cluster Messier 53
column2: captured with crystal clarity in this image from Hubble. Bound tightly by gravity
column3: the cluster is roughly spherical and becomes denser toward its heart. This image is a composite of multiple images taken in visible and infrared wavelengths of light.

column1: Discovered by the German astronomer Johann Elert Bode in 1775
column2: M53 is 59
column3: 700 light-years away
column4: one of the most distant globular clusters from Earth. Best observed in May
column5: it has an apparent magnitude of 8.3 and can be seen through a small telescope in the constellation Coma Berenices. Larger instruments will resolve the cluster’s individual stars.

column1: Globular clusters are much older and larger than open clusters
column2: so they are generally expected to contain more elderly
column3: red stars and fewer young
column4: blue stars. But Messier 53 has surprised astronomers with its unusual number of a type of star called blue stragglers. All the stars in a globular cluster are expected to form around the same time
column5: so they are expected to be roughly the same age. But blue stragglers appear to be brighter and more youthful than they should be. Although their precise nature remains mysterious
column6: these unusual objects are probably formed by close encounters
column7: possibly collisions
column8: between stars in the crowded centers of globular clusters like M53.

36306138351.0;M20;"This Hubble image reveals a star-forming cloud of gas and dust in M20 being torn apart by radiation from a massive nearby star
column2: just beyond the top of the frame. Two thin
column3: finger-like jets protrude from the head of a dense cloud in the upper left of the image
column4: which might be forming new stars at their tips. The jets
column5: each roughly three-quarters of a light-year long
column6: are being eroded by the radiation from the massive star. The red in this image represents hydrogen and sulfur
column7: while green represents oxygen.

25902697507.0;M95;"Found in the constellation Leo
column2: M95 is a beautiful barred spiral galaxy. It was discovered in 1781 by Pierre Méchain
column3: a colleague of Charles Messier.

column1: This Hubble observation reveals a section of M95 featuring its central bar of stars in the upper left and one of its spiral arms extending to the lower right. The observations were taken in near-infrared
column2: visible
column3: and ultraviolet wavelengths of light with Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys and Wide Field Camera 3. Hubble took these observations of M95 to better understand star formation in nearby galaxies.

column1: M95 is located approximately 33 million light-years away and has a magnitude of 9.7. It has around 40 billion stars. Its spiral arms host a flurry of star birth activity and sparkle with the light of countless young
column2: blue stars. The arms themselves are very tightly wound around the galaxy's core and are nearly circular.

column1: M95 can be seen as a hazy smudge on a clear
column2: dark night using a good pair of binoculars
column3: but large telescopes will reveal more detail. It appears close to M96
column5: and a number of fainter galaxies that all belong to the Leo I (or M96) group. The best time of the year to view M95 is in April.

Stars and glowing gases near the core of M84 are circling the galaxy’s central black hole at 880
column2: 000 miles per hour
