column1: 27712254083.0;Hubble Space Telescope Configuration;"This image illustrates the overall Hubble Space Telescope (HST) configuration. Hubble is the product of a partnership between NASA
column2: the European Space Agency
column3: contractors
column4: and the international community of astronomers. It is named after Edwin P. Hubble
column5: an American astronomer who discovered the expanding nature of the universe and was the first to realize the true nature of galaxies.

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column3: is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit. By placing the telescope in space
column4: astronomers are able to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble detects objects 25 times fainter than the dimmest objects seen from Earth and provides astronomers with an observable universe 250 times larger than is visible from ground-based telescopes
column5: extending our view more than 13 billion light-years away. Hubble views galaxies
column6: stars
column7: planets
column8: comets
column9: planet formation in other solar systems
column10: and even unusual phenomena such as quasars
column11: with 10 times the clarity of ground-based telescopes.

column1: The major elements of Hubble are the Optical Telescope Assembly (OTA)
column2: the Support System Module (SSM)
column3: and the Scientific Instruments (SI). Hubble is approximately the size of a railroad car
column4: with two cylinders joined together and wrapped in a silvery reflective heat shield blanket. Wing-like solar arrays extend horizontally from each side of these cylinders
column5: and dish-shaped anternas extend above and below the body of the telescope.  Hubble was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery (STS-31 mission) into Earth orbit in April 1990.

column1: The Marshall Space Flight Center had responsibility for design
column2: development
column3: and construction of the observatory. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury
column4: Connecticut
column5: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. The Lockheed Missile and Space Company of Sunnyvale
column6: California
column7: produced the protective outer shroud and spacecraft systems
column8: and assembled and tested the finished telescope.

column1: Date Created: 1985-04-01";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/80dd5ef26d96ae56d7cfe576d4779d25;2016-07-15;2326.0;3000.0;CC BY;7.21576710092e+16;Hubble in Development;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27712254083/in/album-72157671009197500;hubble hubblespacetelescope spacetelescope space telescope nasa
27925696572.0;Celestial Fireworks - The Official Hubble 25th Anniversary Image;"In this image
column2: the Hubble Space Telescope unveils some of nature's own fireworks - a giant cluster of about 3
column3: 000 stars called Westerlund 2. The cluster resides inside a vibrant stellar breeding ground known as Gum 29
column4: located 20
column5: 000 light-years away in the constellation Carina. The comparatively young
column6: 2-million-year-old star cluster contains some of our galaxy's hottest
column7: brightest
column8: and most massive stars. The largest stars are unleashing a torrent of ultraviolet light and hurricane-force winds that etch away the enveloping hydrogen gas cloud. This creates a fantasy celestial landscape of pillars
column9: ridges
column10: and valleys.

This view was taken after the shroud was placed over the Optical Telescope Assembly (OTA). The OTA contains two mirrors
column2: a primary and a secondary

column1: Hubble was the first of NASA's great observatories and the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made. The purpose of Hubble is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit by placing the telescope in space
column2: enabling astronomers to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery (STS-31 mission) into Earth orbit in April 1990.

column1: 27747572370.0;Gravitational Lensing in Galaxy Cluster Abell 370;"NASA's Hubble Space has peered nearly 5 billion light-years away to resolve intricate details in the galaxy cluster Abell 370. This object is one of the very first galaxy clusters where astronomers observed the phenomenon of gravitational lensing
column2: where the warping of space by the cluster's gravitational field distorts the light from galaxies lying far behind it. This is manifested as arcs and streaks in the picture
column3: which are the stretched images of background galaxies.

column1: Gravitational lensing proves a vital tool for astronomers when measuring the dark matter distribution in massive clusters
column2: since the mass distribution can be reconstructed from its gravitational effects. Galaxy clusters are the most massive structures of the universe
column3: located at the crossing of the filaments of the cosmic web of dark matter. The most massive clusters can contain up to 1
column4: 000 galaxies and intergalactic hot gas
column5: all held together primarily by the gravity of dark matter.

27415340994.0;NASA’s Hubble Finds Universe Is Expanding Faster Than Expected;"Astronomers using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope have discovered that the universe is expanding 5 percent to 9 percent faster than expected.
“This surprising finding may be an important clue to understanding those mysterious parts of the universe that make up 95 percent of everything and don’t emit light
column2: such as dark energy
column3: dark matter and dark radiation
column4: ” said study leader and Nobel Laureate Adam Riess of the Space Telescope Science Institute and Johns Hopkins University
column5: both in Baltimore
column6: Maryland.

column1: The results will appear in an issue of The Astrophysical Journal.
Riess’ team made the discovery by refining the universe’s current expansion rate to unprecedented accuracy
column2: reducing the uncertainty to only 2.4 percent. The team made the refinements by developing innovative techniques that improved the precision of distance measurements to faraway galaxies.

column1: The team looked for galaxies containing both Cepheid stars and Type Ia supernovae. Cepheid stars pulsate at rates that correspond to their true brightness
column2: which can be compared with their apparent brightness as seen from Earth to accurately determine their distance. Type Ia supernovae
column3: another commonly used cosmic yardstick
column4: are exploding stars that flare with the same brightness and are brilliant enough to be seen from relatively longer distances.

column1: By measuring about 2
column2: 400 Cepheid stars in 19 galaxies and comparing the observed brightness of both types of stars
column3: they accurately measured their true brightness and calculated distances to roughly 300 Type Ia supernovae in far-flung galaxies.

column1: The team compared those distances with the expansion of space as measured by the stretching of light from receding galaxies. They used these two values to calculate how fast the universe expands with time
column2: or the Hubble constant.

column1: The improved Hubble constant value 45.5 miles per second per megaparsec. (A megaparsec equals 3.26 million light-years.) The new value means the distance between cosmic objects will double in another 9.8 billion years.
This refined calibration presents a puzzle
column2: however
column3: because it does not quite match the expansion rate predicted for the universe from its trajectory seen shortly after the Big Bang. Measurements of the afterglow from the Big Bang by NASA’s Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP) and the European Space Agency’s Planck satellite mission yield predictions that are 5 percent and 9 percent smaller for the Hubble constant
column4: respectively.

column1: “If we know the initial amounts of stuff in the universe
column2: such as dark energy and dark matter
column3: and we have the physics correct
column4: then you can go from a measurement at the time shortly after the Big Bang and use that understanding to predict how fast the universe should be expanding today
column5: ” said Riess. “However
column6: if this discrepancy holds up
column7: it appears we may not have the right understanding
column8: and it changes how big the Hubble constant should be today.”

column1: Comparing the universe’s expansion rate with WMAP
column2: Planck
column3: and Hubble is like building a bridge
column4: Riess explained. On the distant shore are the cosmic microwave background observations of the early universe. On the nearby shore are the measurements made by Riess’ team using Hubble.

column1: “You start at two ends
column2: and you expect to meet in the middle if all of your drawings are right and your measurements are right
column3: ” Riess said. “But now the ends are not quite meeting in the middle and we want to know why.”

column1: There are a few possible explanations for the universe’s excessive speed. One possibility is that dark energy
column2: already known to be accelerating the universe
column3: may be shoving galaxies away from each other with even greater — or growing — strength.

column1: Another idea is that the cosmos contained a new subatomic particle in its early history that traveled close to the speed of light. Such speedy particles are collectively referred to as “dark radiation” and include previously known particles like neutrinos. More energy from additional dark radiation could be throwing off the best efforts to predict today's expansion rate from its post-Big Bang trajectory.
The boost in acceleration could also mean that dark matter possesses some weird
column2: unexpected characteristics. Dark matter is the backbone of the universe upon which galaxies built themselves up into the large-scale structures seen today.

column1: And finally
column2: the speedier universe may be telling astronomers that Einstein’s theory of gravity is incomplete.

column1: “We know so little about the dark parts of the universe
column2: it’s important to measure how they push and pull on space over cosmic history
column3: ” said Lucas Macri of Texas A&M University in College Station
column4: a key collaborator on the study.

column1: The Hubble observations were made with Hubble’s sharp-eyed Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3)
column2: and were conducted by the Supernova H0 for the Equation of State (SH0ES) team
column3: which works to refine the accuracy of the Hubble constant to a precision that allows for a better understanding of the universe’s behavior.

column1: The SH0ES team is still using Hubble to reduce the uncertainty in the Hubble constant even more
column2: with a goal to reach an accuracy of 1 percent. Current telescopes such as the European Space Agency’s Gaia satellite
column3: and future telescopes such as the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST)
column4: an infrared observatory
column5: and the Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope (WFIRST)
column6: also could help astronomers make better measurements of the expansion rate.

column1: Before Hubble was launched in 1990
column2: the estimates of the Hubble constant varied by a factor of two. In the late 1990s the Hubble Space Telescope Key Project on the Extragalactic Distance Scale refined the value of the Hubble constant to within an error of only 10 percent
column3: accomplishing one of the telescope’s key goals. The SH0ES team has reduced the uncertainty in the Hubble constant value by 76 percent since beginning its quest in 2005.

column1: 36331013491.0;M100;"Soon after Hubble first began sending images from space
column2: scientists discovered that the telescope's primary mirror had a flaw called spherical aberration. This flaw caused some of the collected light from celestial objects to be scattered
column3: resulting in fuzzy images. In 1994
column4: NASA released these two images of M100 taken with Hubble before (left) and after (right) the spherical aberration problem was corrected.

column2: one of Hubble's extravehicular system engineers
column3: talks to NASA Social participants about the Hubble Space Telescope and the ground-breaking missions NASA sent to service it while demonstrating some of the custom astronaut tools developed for those missions.

column1: More than 40 of NASA's followers on social media traveled from across the country to attend a NASA Social event on April 23
column3: in celebration of the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope. The day-long event began by attending the unveiling of a 25th anniversary image at a NASA press conference at the Newseum in Washington
column4: DC. The participants then traveled to NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center where they took part in behind-the-scenes tours of different laboratories
column5: ending with a viewing of the Hubble control center and a hands-on demonstration of the tools used during the Hubble servicing missions.

28026561655.0;Space Shuttle Atlantis on Launch Pad;"Space shuttle Atlantis sits on Launch Pad 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida after its rollout from the Vehicle Assembly Building. The shuttle sits atop the mobile launcher platform
column2: which is carried by the crawler-transporter beneath. Beyond the shuttle on the horizon is the Atlantic Ocean. At left
column3: behind the shuttle
column4: is the 300
column5: 000-gallon water tower that releases water over the pad for sound suppression during liftoff.

column1: Atlantis lifted off on May 11
column3: to service NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. During Atlantis' 12-day mission
column4: its crew of seven astronauts made the final shuttle flight to Hubble. During five spacewalks
column5: they installed two new instruments
column6: repaired two inactive ones and replaced other components. This resulted in six working
column7: complementary science instruments with capabilities beyond what was previously available
column8: and extended the operational lifespan for the telescope.

column1: 35450736805.0;Dying Young: Massive Dead Disk Galaxy Challenges the Picture of How Galaxies Evolve;"By combining the power of a "natural lens" in space with the capability of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope
column2: astronomers made a surprising discovery — the first example of very compact yet massive disk-shaped and rotating galaxy that stopped making stars only a few billion years after the big bang. Finding a galaxy that is pancake-shaped much like our own Milky Way so early in the history of the universe challenges the current understanding of how massive galaxies form and evolve
column3: say researchers.

column1: The galaxy
column2: called MACS 2129-1
column3: is considered "dead" because it is no longer making stars. The existence of dead galaxies so early — when the universe was just one-quarter its current age — has long been a puzzle
column4: as the universe at that time was full of gas and at the peak of the cosmic star formation history. The leading theory has been that they formed in galaxy collisions that efficiently drove all the gas into the center of the collision and turned it into stars.

column1: "Perhaps we have been blind to the fact that early 'dead' galaxies could in fact be disks
column2: simply because we haven't been able to resolve them
column3: " said study leader Sune Toft of the Dark Cosmology Centre at the Niels Bohr Institute
column4: University of Copenhagen. "This new insight may force us to rethink the whole cosmological context of how galaxies burn out early on and evolve into local elliptical-shaped galaxies." When the universe was just 3 billion years old
column5: half of the most massive galaxies were extremely compact and had already completed their star formation. Astronomers believe that they ultimately grew into the most massive elliptical galaxies seen in the nearby universe today. Scientists theorize they did this through mergers with small companion galaxies
column6: which added to the stars on the galaxy's outskirts.

column1: Confirming this scenario requires more powerful telescopes than are currently available
column2: whether on Earth or in space. However
column3: through the phenomenon known as "gravitational lensing
column4: " a massive
column5: foreground cluster of galaxies functions as a natural telescope
column6: magnifying and stretching images of far more distant background galaxies. By joining this natural lens with the resolving power of Hubble
column7: scientists were able to see into the center of the dead galaxy.

column1: The astronomers expected to see a chaotic ball of stars formed through mergers. Instead
column2: they found a pancake-shaped stellar distribution
column3: meaning that the stars must have been born in a disk. The remote galaxy is three times as massive as the Milky Way but only half the size. Rotational velocity measurements made with the European Southern Observatory's Very Large Telescope (VLT) showed that the disk galaxy is spinning more than twice as fast as the Milky Way.

column1: This is observational evidence that at least some of the earliest "dead" galaxies must have gone through major makeovers
column2: changing not just their structure
column3: but also the motions of their stars
column4: to evolve into the giant elliptical galaxies we see today.

column1: Using archival data from the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (CLASH)
column2: Toft and his team were able to determine the stellar mass
column3: star formation rate
column4: and the ages of the stars.  "We can see that the star formation stopped first in the center of the galaxy and then moved outwards through the galaxy
column5: " Toft said. "In other words
column6: it died inside out. Until now it had been impossible to resolve them
column7: so we didn't know if star formation stopped all at once in the whole galaxy
column8: or if it stopped first in the center
column9: or if it stopped first in the outskirts." Why this galaxy stopped forming stars is still unknown. It may be the result of an active galactic nucleus
column10: where energy is gushing from a supermassive black hole. This energy inhibits star formation. Or it may be the result of "halo quenching
column11: " where
column12: when cold gas tries to stream into the galaxy's center
column13: it's rapidly heated. This prevents it from reaching the center and cooling down into star-forming clouds.

column1: But how do these young
column2: massive
column3: compact disks evolve into the elliptical galaxies we see in the present-day universe? "Probably through mergers
column4: " Toft said. "If these galaxies grow through merging with minor companions
column5: and these minor companions come in large numbers and from all sorts of different angles onto the galaxy
column6: this would eventually randomize the orbits of stars in the galaxies. You could also imagine major mergers. This would definitely also destroy the ordered motion of the stars." The findings are published in the June 22
column8: issue of the journal Nature. Toft and his team hope to use NASA's upcoming James Webb Space Telescope to look for a larger sample of such galaxies.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/52a9882c7f5cb9dc3be11212ca0455e8;2017-06-21;1798.0;2000.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35450736805/in/album-72157667717916600;macsj21290741 macs21291

column1: 35971859780.0;M15;"A spectacular swarm of stars
column2: M15 was discovered in 1746 by Jean-Dominique Maraldi
column3: an Italian astronomer on the hunt for comets. This globular cluster is one of the densest ever discovered
column4: with very hot blue stars and cooler orange stars becoming more concentrated toward its bright core. M15 is located in the constellation Pegasus 33
column5: 600 light-years from Earth. Shining with an apparent magnitude of 6.2
column6: the cluster can be spotted with a pair of binoculars. The best time to observe it is in October.

column1: M15 was the first globular cluster known to host a planetary nebula (the gaseous shell of a dying star). This nebula
column2: Pease 1
column3: was detected in 1928 by Francis G. Pease and is one of only four planetary nebulas known to exist within a globular cluster. In this image
column4: Pease 1 appears as the large
column5: bright blue object to the left of the cluster’s center.

column1: This cluster has also been found to host a rare type of black hole at its center: an intermediate-mass black hole. Supermassive black holes are found at the center of galaxies and can be billions of times more massive than the sun. More diminutive “stellar” black holes
column2: on the other hand
column3: are on the order of 10 solar masses. The black hole thought to exist at the center of M15
column4: however
column5: is 4
column6: 000 times the mass of the sun.

column1: Hubble captured this image of M15’s core using observations in visible
column2: infrared and ultraviolet light.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M15
column2: see:

column1: www.spacetelescope.org/news/heic1321/
www.spacetelescope.org/images/potw1107a/
Credit: NASA
column2: ESA";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/946a6bac403adca7d3137af1d51baf18;2013-11-14;4028.0;3749.0;CC BY-NC-SA;7.2157687169e+16;Hubble's Messier Catalog;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35971859780/in/album-72157687169041200;messier15 messier hubble hubblespacetelescope nightsky space nasa pegasus octobersky astronomy m15 stars starcluster globularcluster pease1 jeandominiquemaraldi ngc7078 planetarynebula intermediatemassblackhole xraysource greatpegasuscluster

column1: 36365209231.0;M2;"The first globular cluster to be added to the Messier catalog
column2: M2 is located roughly 37
column3: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Aquarius. A globular cluster is a spherical group of stars that are bound together by their mutual gravitational attraction. M2 has a diameter of over 150 light-years and is one of the largest clusters of its kind. It was discovered in 1746 by the French astronomer Jean-Dominique Maraldi while he was observing a comet.

column1: This Hubble image of M2’s core was created using observations taken at visible and infrared wavelengths. M2 contains over 150
column2: 000 stars. Most of the cluster’s mass is concentrated at its center
column3: with shimmering streams of stars extending outward into space. It has an apparent magnitude of 6.3 and can be seen with the naked eye in ideal viewing conditions. The best time to observe M2 is during the month of October. Large telescopes will resolve the cluster’s individual stars.

column1: Credit: NASA
column2: ESA
column3: STScI
column4: and A. Sarajedini (University of Florida)";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/3c21eedd7d01887ad38b92354f376c1d;2017-06-17;4078.0;4078.0;CC BY-NC-SA;7.2157687169e+16;Hubble's Messier Catalog;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36365209231/in/album-72157687169041200;messier hubble hubblespacetelescope nightsky space nasa m2 messier2 aquarius octobersky globularcluster starcluster astronomy jeandominiquemaraldi stars

column1: 33528174686.0;Seeing things sideways;"This image from Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) shows NGC 1448
column2: a spiral galaxy located about 50 million light-years from Earth in the little-known constellation of Horologium (the Pendulum Clock). We tend to think of spiral galaxies as massive and roughly circular celestial bodies
column3: so this glittering oval does not immediately appear to fit the visual bill. What’s going on?

column1: Imagine a spiral galaxy as a circular frisbee spinning gently in space. When we see it face on
column2: our observations reveal a spectacular amount of detail and structure — a great example from Hubble is the telescope’s view of Messier 51
column3: otherwise known as the Whirlpool Galaxy. However
column4: the NGC 1448 frisbee is very nearly edge-on with respect to Earth
column5: giving it an appearance that is more oval than circular. The spiral arms
column6: which curve out from NGC 1448’s dense core
column7: can just about be seen.

column1: Although spiral galaxies might appear static with their picturesque shapes frozen in space
column2: this is very far from the truth. The stars in these dramatic spiral configurations are constantly moving and spinning around the galaxy’s core
column3: with those on the inside whirling around faster than those sitting further out. This makes the formation and continued existence of a spiral galaxy’s arms something of a cosmic puzzle
column4: because the arms wrapped around the spinning core should become wound tighter and tighter as time goes on — but this is not what we see. This is known as the winding problem.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/32a7c34963633cdc4156c8fd24b47f32;2017-03-13;922.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33528174686/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc1448

column1: 32248460071.0;A black hole of puzzling lightness;"This image taken with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) onboard the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope captures a galaxy in the Virgo constellation. This camera was installed in 2002
column2: and its wide field of view is double that of its predecessor
column3: capturing superb images with sharp image quality and enhanced sensitivity that can be seen here.

column1: The beautiful spiral galaxy visible in the center of the image is catchily known as RX J1140.1+0307
column2: and it presents an interesting puzzle. At first glance
column3: this galaxy appears to be a normal spiral galaxy
column4: much like the Milky Way
column5: but first appearances can be deceptive!

column1: The Milky Way galaxy
column2: like most large galaxies
column3: has a supermassive black hole at its center
column4: but some galaxies are centered on lighter
column5: intermediate-mass black holes. RX J1140.1+0307 is such a galaxy — in fact
column6: it is centered on one of the lowest black hole masses known in any luminous galactic core. What puzzles scientists about this particular galaxy is that the calculations don’t add up. With such a relatively low mass for the central black hole
column7: models for the emission from the object cannot explain the observed spectrum; unless there are other mechanisms at play in the interactions between the inner and outer parts of the accretion disk surrounding the black hole.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/ba3cce7cda34e366e2ef00a47706a523;2016-07-08;516.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/32248460071/in/album-72157667717916600;rxj114010307

column1: 29671368563.0;Hubble Reveals Observable Universe Contains 10 Times More Galaxies Than Previously Thought;"The universe suddenly looks a lot more crowded
column2: thanks to a deep-sky census assembled from surveys taken by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope and other observatories.

column1: The results have clear implications for galaxy formation
column2: and also helps shed light on an ancient astronomical paradox - why is the sky dark at night?

column1: In analyzing the data
column2: a team led by Christopher Conselice of the University of Nottingham
column3: U.K.
column4: found that 10 times as many galaxies were packed into a given volume of space in the early universe than found today. Most of these galaxies were relatively small and faint
column5: with masses similar to those of the satellite galaxies surrounding the Milky Way. As they merged to form larger galaxies the population density of galaxies in space dwindled. This means that galaxies are not evenly distributed throughout the universe's history
column6: the research team reports in a paper to be published in The Astrophysical Journal.

column1: "These results are powerful evidence that a significant galaxy evolution has taken place throughout the universe's history
column2: which dramatically reduced the number of galaxies through mergers between them - thus reducing their total number. This gives us a verification of the so-called top-down formation of structure in the universe
column3: " explained Conselice.

column1: One of the most fundamental questions in astronomy is that of just how many galaxies the universe contains. The landmark Hubble Deep Field
column2: taken in the mid-1990s
column3: gave the first real insight into the universe's galaxy population. Subsequent sensitive observations such as Hubble's Ultra Deep Field revealed a myriad of faint galaxies. This led to an estimate that the observable universe contained about 100 billion galaxies.

column1: The new research shows that this estimate is at least 10 times too low.
Conselice and his team reached this conclusion using deep-space images from Hubble and the already published data from other teams. They painstakingly converted the images into 3-D
column2: in order to make accurate measurements of the number of galaxies at different epochs in the universe's history. In addition
column3: they used new mathematical models
column4: which allowed them to infer the existence of galaxies that the current generation of telescopes cannot observe. This led to the surprising conclusion that in order for the numbers of galaxies we now see and their masses to add up
column5: there must be a further 90 percent of galaxies in the observable universe that are too faint and too far away to be seen with present-day telescopes. These myriad small faint galaxies from the early universe merged over time into the larger galaxies we can now observe.

column1: "It boggles the mind that over 90 percent of the galaxies in the universe have yet to be studied. Who knows what interesting properties we will find when we discover these galaxies with future generations of telescopes? In the near future
column2: the James Webb Space Telescope will be able to study these ultra-faint galaxies
column3: said Conselice.

column1: The decreasing number of galaxies as time progresses also contributes to the solution for Olbers' paradox (first formulated in the early 1800s by German astronomer Heinrich Wilhelm Olbers): Why is the sky dark at night if the universe contains an infinity of stars? The team came to the conclusion that indeed there actually is such an abundance of galaxies that
column2: in principle
column3: every patch in the sky contains part of a galaxy.

column1: However
column2: starlight from the galaxies is invisible to the human eye and most modern telescopes due to other known factors that reduce visible and ultraviolet light in the universe. Those factors are the reddening of light due to the expansion of space
column3: the universe's dynamic nature
column4: and the absorption of light by intergalactic dust and gas. All combined
column5: this keeps the night sky dark to our vision.

column1: Astronomers came to the surprising conclusion that there are at least 10 times more galaxies in the observable universe than previously thought. This places the universe's estimated population at
column2: minimally
column3: 2 trillion galaxies.

28420125986.0;NASA’s Hubble Looks to the Final Frontier;"Celebrating its 50th anniversary in 2016
column2: the TV series "Star Trek" has captured the public’s imagination with the signature phrase
column3: "To boldly go where no one has gone before." NASA's Hubble Space Telescope doesn't "boldly go" deep into space
column4: but it is "boldly peering" deeper into the universe than ever before to explore the warping of space and time and uncover some of the farthest objects ever seen.

column1: When "Star Trek" was first broadcast in 1966
column2: the largest telescopes on Earth could only see about halfway across the universe - the rest was uncharted territory. But Hubble's powerful vision has carried us into the true "final frontier."

column1: This is epitomized in the latest Hubble image released today in time for the new motion picture "Star Trek Beyond." The Hubble image unveils a very cluttered-looking universe filled with galaxies near and far. Some are distorted like a funhouse mirror through a warping-of-space phenomenon first predicted by Einstein a century ago.
In the center of the image is the immense galaxy cluster Abell S1063
column2: located 4 billion light-years away
column3: and surrounded by magnified images of galaxies much farther.

column1: Thanks to Hubble's exquisite sharpness
column2: the photo unveils the effect of space warping due to gravity. The huge mass of the cluster distorts and magnifies the light from galaxies that lie far behind it due to an effect called gravitational lensing. This phenomenon allows Hubble to see galaxies that would otherwise be too small and faint to observe. This "warp field" makes it possible to get a peek at the very first generation of galaxies. Already
column3: an infant galaxy has been found in the field
column4: as it looked 1 billion years after the big bang.

column1: This frontier image provides a sneak peak of the early universe
column2: and gives us a taste of what the James Webb Space Telescope will be capable of seeing in greater detail when it launches in 2018.

column1: The cluster contains approximately 100 million-million solar masses
column2: and contains 51 confirmed galaxies and perhaps over 400 more.

column1: The Frontier Fields program is an ambitious three-year effort
column2: begun in 2013
column3: that teams Hubble with NASA's other Great Observatories - the Spitzer Space Telescope and the Chandra X-ray Observatory - to probe the early universe by studying large galaxy lusters. Identifying the magnified images of background galaxies within these clusters will help astronomers to improve their models of the distribution of both ordinary and dark matter in the galaxy cluster. This is key to understanding the mysterious nature of dark matter that comprises most of the mass of the universe.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope is a project of international cooperation between NASA and the European Space Agency. NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt
column2: Maryland
column3: manages the telescope. The Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore
column4: Maryland
column5: conducts Hubble science operations. STScI is operated for NASA by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy in Washington
column6: D.C.

column2: and how you can get involved with #spothubble
column3: visit:

29211321440.0;Best image of Alpha Centauri A and B;"The closest star system to Earth is the famous Alpha Centauri group. Located in the constellation of Centaurus (the Centaur)
column2: at a distance of 4.3 light-years
column3: this system is made up of the binary formed by the stars Alpha Centauri A and Alpha Centauri B
column4: plus the faint red dwarf Alpha Centauri C
column5: also known as Proxima Centauri.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope has given us this stunning view of the bright Alpha Centauri A (on the left) and Alpha Centauri B (on the right)
column2: flashing like huge cosmic headlamps in the dark. The image was captured by the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 (WFPC2). WFPC2 was Hubble’s most used instrument for the first 13 years of the space telescope’s life
column3: being replaced in 2009 by WFC3 during Servicing Mission 4. This portrait of Alpha Centauri was produced by observations carried out at optical and near-infrared wavelengths.

column1: Compared to the Sun
column2: Alpha Centauri A is of the same stellar type G2
column3: and slightly bigger
column4: while Alpha Centauri B
column5: a K1-type star
column6: is slightly smaller. They orbit a common center of gravity once every 80 years
column7: with a minimum distance of about 11 times the distance between Earth and the Sun. Because these two stars are
column8: together with their sibling Proxima Centauri
column9: the closest to Earth
column10: they are among the best studied by astronomers. And they are also among the prime targets in the hunt for habitable exoplanets. Using the HARPS instrument astronomers already discovered a planet orbiting Alpha Centauri B. In August 2016 astronomers announced the discovery of an Earth-like planet in the habitable zone orbiting the star Proxima Centauri.

29992121514.0;Youthful NGC 362;"Globular clusters offer some of the most spectacular sights in the night sky. These ornate spheres contain hundreds of thousands of stars
column2: and reside in the outskirts of galaxies. The Milky Way contains over 150 such clusters — and the one shown in this Hubble Space Telescope image
column3: named NGC 362
column4: is one of the more unusual ones.

column1: As stars make their way through life they fuse elements together in their cores
column2: creating heavier and heavier elements — known in astronomy as metals — in the process. When these stars die
column3: they flood their surroundings with the material they have formed during their lifetimes
column4: enriching the interstellar medium with metals. Stars that form later therefore contain higher proportions of metals than their older relatives.

column1: By studying the different elements present within individual stars in NGC 362
column2: astronomers discovered that the cluster boasts a surprisingly high metal content
column3: indicating that it is younger than expected. Although most globular clusters are much older than the majority of stars in their host galaxy
column4: NGC 362 bucks the trend
column5: with an age lying between 10 and 11 billion years old. For reference
column6: the age of the Milky Way is estimated to be above 13 billion years.

column1: This image
column2: in which you can view NGC 362's individual stars
column3: was taken by Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS).";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/15a3a428d57a990a411df5ead5feab0b;2016-07-08;1051.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/29992121514/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc362

column1: 30805354686.0;The Toucan and the cluster;"It may be famous for hosting spectacular sights such as the Tucana Dwarf Galaxy and 47 Tucanae
column2: the second brightest globular cluster in the night sky
column3: but the southern constellation of Tucana (the Toucan) also possesses a variety of unsung cosmic beauties.

column1: One such beauty is NGC 299
column2: an open star cluster located within the Small Magellanic Cloud just under 200
column3: 000 light-years away. Open clusters such as this are collections of stars weakly bound by the shackles of gravity
column4: all of which formed from the same massive molecular cloud of gas and dust. Because of this
column5: all the stars have the same age and composition
column6: but vary in their mass because they formed at different positions within the cloud.

column1: This unique property not only ensures a spectacular sight when viewed through a sophisticated instrument attached to a telescope such as Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys
column2: but gives astronomers a cosmic laboratory in which to study the formation and evolution of stars — a process that is thought to depend strongly on a star's mass.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/eb5ceea4b834c549fe46ba250fb7041d;2016-05-03;767.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/30805354686/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc299

column1: 29610567032.0;Standing out from the crowd;"A lone source shines out brightly from the dark expanse of deep space
column2: glowing softly against a picturesque backdrop of distant stars and colorful galaxies.

column1: Captured by the Hubble Space Telescope’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)
column2: this scene shows PGC 83677
column3: a lenticular galaxy — a galaxy type that sits between the more familiar elliptical and spiral varieties in the Hubble sequence.

column1: This image was obtained as part of the Coma Cluster Survey. It reveals both the relatively calm outskirts and intriguing core of PGC 83677. Here
column2: studies have uncovered signs of a monstrous black hole that is spewing out high-energy X-rays and ultraviolet light.

column1: 27990757746.0;Hubble Space Telescope;The Hubble Space Telescope is now securely latched down on a special support structure in the cargo bay of the Space Shuttle Columbia. The bay's Flight Support System
column2: as the structure (partially visible at bottom frame) is called
column3: will hold the telescope for the next week
column4: turning and tilting it as needed for the spacewalking work. The crew used a digital still camera to record a series of images documenting the fourth docking of a shuttle to the giant telescope during its tenure in space.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/9e4c1d9e7dc3e6d67753e94542678666;2016-07-01;2008.0;3032.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27990757746/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109

column2: payload commander
column3: and Richard M. (Rick) Linnehan
column4: mission specialist
column5: participate in the first of their assigned STS-109 space walks to perform work on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). The two went on to replace the giant telescope’s starboard solar array. Their seven-hour space walk ended at 7:38 a.m. (CST) or 13:38 GMT March 4

column2: Michael J. Massimino
column3: Nancy J. Currie
column4: Scott D. Altman
column5: Duane G. Carey
column6: John M. Grunsfeld
column7: and Richard M. Linnehan. The crew returned to Earth after a successful 11-day mission servicing and upgrading the Hubble Space Telescope. Wheel stop occurred on orbit 165 at 4:33:09 a.m. EST. Main gear touchdown occurred at 4:31:52 a.m. and nose wheel touchdown at 4:32:02. Rollout time was 1 minute
column8: 17 seconds. column1: 27994496686.0;Hubble Reveals Stellar Fireworks in ‘Skyrocket’ Galaxy;"Fireworks shows are not just confined to Earth’s skies. NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has captured a spectacular fireworks display in a small
column2: nearby galaxy
column3: which resembles a July 4th skyrocket.

column1: A firestorm of star birth is lighting up one end of the diminutive galaxy Kiso 5639. The dwarf galaxy is shaped like a flattened pancake
column2: but because it is tilted edge-on
column3: it resembles a skyrocket
column4: with a brilliant blazing head and a long
column5: star-studded tail.

column1: Kiso 5639 is a rare
column2: nearby example of elongated galaxies that occur in abundance at larger distances
column3: where we observe the universe during earlier epochs. Astronomers suggest that the frenzied star birth is sparked by intergalactic gas raining on one end of the galaxy as it drifts through space.

column1: “I think Kiso 5639 is a beautiful
column2: up-close example of what must have been common long ago
column3: ” said lead researcher Debra Elmegreen of Vassar College
column4: in Poughkeepsie
column5: New York. “The current thinking is that galaxies in the early universe grow from accreting gas from the surrounding neighborhood. It’s a stage that galaxies
column6: including our Milky Way
column7: must go through as they are growing up.”

column1: Observations of the early universe
column2: such as Hubble’s Ultra-Deep Field
column3: reveal that about 10 percent of all galaxies have these elongated shapes
column4: and are collectively called “tadpoles.” But studies of the nearby universe have turned up only a few of these unusual galaxies
column5: including Kiso 5639. The development of the nearby star-making tadpole galaxies
column6: however
column7: has lagged behind that of their peers
column8: which have spent billions of years building themselves up into many of the spiral galaxies seen today.

column1: Elmegreen used Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3 to conduct a detailed imaging study of Kiso 5639. The images in different filters reveal information about an object by dissecting its light into its component colors. Hubble’s crisp resolution helped Elmegreen and her team analyze the giant star-forming clumps in Kiso 5639 and determine the masses and ages of the star clusters.
The international team of researchers selected Kiso 5639 from a spectroscopic survey of 10 nearby tadpole galaxies
column2: observed with the Grand Canary Telescope in La Palma
column3: Spain
column4: by Jorge Sanchez Almeida and collaborators at the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias. The observations revealed that in most of those galaxies
column5: including Kiso 5639
column6: the gas composition is not uniform.

column1: The bright gas in the galaxy’s head contains fewer heavier elements (collectively called “metals”)
column2: such as carbon and oxygen
column3: than the rest of the galaxy. Stars consist mainly of hydrogen and helium
column4: but cook up other “heavier” elements. When the stars die
column5: they release their heavy elements and enrich the surrounding gas.

column1: “The metallicity suggests that there has to be rather pure gas
column2: composed mostly of hydrogen
column3: coming into the star-forming part of the galaxy
column4: because intergalactic space contains more pristine hydrogen-rich gas
column5: ” Elmegreen explained. “Otherwise
column6: the starburst region should be as rich in heavy elements as the rest of the galaxy.”

column1: Hubble offers a detailed view of the galaxy’s star-making frenzy. The telescope uncovered several dozen clusters of stars in the galaxy’s star-forming head
column2: which spans 2
column3: 700 light-years across. These clusters have an average age of less than 1 million years and masses that are three to six times larger than those in the rest of the galaxy. Other star formation is taking place throughout the galaxy but on a much smaller scale. Star clusters in the rest of the galaxy are between several million to a few billion years old.

column1: “There is much more star formation going on in the head than what you would expect in such a tiny galaxy
column2: ” said team member Bruce Elmegreen of IBM’s Thomas J. Watson’s Research Center
column3: in Yorktown Heights
column4: New York. “And we think the star formation is triggered by the ongoing accretion of metal-poor gas onto a part of an otherwise quiescent dwarf galaxy.”

column1: Hubble also revealed giant holes peppered throughout the galaxy’s starburst head. These cavities give the galaxy’s head a Swiss-cheese appearance because numerous supernova detonations – like firework aerial bursts – have carved out holes of rarified superheated gas.
The galaxy
column2: located 82 million light-years away
column3: has taken billions of years to develop because it has been drifting through an isolated “desert” in the universe
column4: devoid of much gas.

column1: What triggered the starburst in such a backwater galaxy? Based on simulations by Daniel Ceverino of the Center for Astronomy at Heidelberg University in Germany
column2: and other team members
column3: the observations suggest that less than 1 million years ago
column4: Kiso 5639’s leading edge encountered a filament of gas. The filament dropped a large clump of matter onto the galaxy
column5: stoking the vigorous star birth.

column1: Debra Elmegreen expects that in the future other parts of the galaxy will join in the star-making fireworks show. “Galaxies rotate
column2: and as Kiso 5639 continues to spin
column3: another part of the galaxy may receive an infusion of new gas from this filament
column4: instigating another round of star birth
column5: ” she said.

column1: The team’s results have been accepted for publication in The Astrophysical Journal.
Other team members include Casiana Munoz-Tunon and Mercedes Filho (Instituto de Astrofísica de Canarias
column2: Canary Islands)
column3: Jairo Mendez-Abreu (University of St. Andrews
column4: United Kingdom)
column5: John Gallagher (University of Wisconsin-Madison)
column6: and Marc Rafelski (NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center
column7: Greenbelt
column8: Maryland).

column1: For images and more information about Kiso 5639 and Hubble
column2: visit:

27951378961.0;Hubble Captures Vivid Auroras in Jupiter’s Atmosphere;"Astronomers have used the Hubble Space Telescope to study auroras — stunning light shows in a planet’s atmosphere — on the poles of the largest planet in the solar system
column2: Jupiter. This observation program was supported by measurements made by NASA’s Juno spacecraft
column3: which was on its way to Jupiter at the time of Hubble's observations.

column1: Jupiter
column2: the largest planet in the solar system
column3: is best known for its colorful storms
column4: the most famous being the Great Red Spot. Now astronomers have focused on another beautiful feature of the planet
column5: using Hubble's ultraviolet capabilities.

column1: The extraordinary vivid glows shown in the new observations are known as auroras. They are created when high-energy particles enter a planet’s atmosphere near its magnetic poles and collide with atoms of gas. As well as producing beautiful images
column2: this program aims to determine how various components of Jupiter’s auroras respond to different conditions in the solar wind
column3: a stream of charged particles ejected from the Sun.

column1: This observation program was perfectly timed as NASA’s Juno spacecraft was in the solar wind near Jupiter and was about to enter the orbit of the planet in early July 2016. While Hubble was observing and measuring the auroras on Jupiter
column2: Juno was measuring the properties of the solar wind itself; a perfect collaboration between a telescope and a space probe.

column1: “These auroras are very dramatic and among the most active I have ever seen”
column2: said Jonathan Nichols from the University of Leicester
column3: U.K.
column4: and principal investigator of the study.

column1: To highlight changes in the auroras Hubble is observing Jupiter almost daily for several months. Using this series of far-ultraviolet images from Hubble's Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph
column2: it is possible for scientists to create videos that demonstrate the movement of the vivid auroras
column3: which cover areas bigger than Earth.

column1: Not only are the auroras huge in size
column2: they are also hundreds of times more energetic than auroras on Earth. And
column3: unlike those on Earth
column4: they never cease. While on Earth the most intense auroras are caused by solar storms — when charged particles rain down on the upper atmosphere
column5: excite gases and cause them to glow red
column6: green and purple — Jupiter has an additional source for its auroras.

column1: The strong magnetic field of the gas giant grabs charged particles from its surroundings. This includes not only the charged particles within the solar wind but also the particles thrown into space by its orbiting moon Io
column2: known for its numerous and large volcanoes.

column1: The new observations and measurements made with Hubble and Juno will help to better understand how the Sun and other sources influence auroras. While the observations with Hubble are still ongoing and the analysis of the data will take several more months
column2: the first images and videos are already available and show the auroras on Jupiter’s north pole in their full beauty.

column1: For images
column2: video and more information about auroras on Jupiter and about Hubble
column3: visit:

27926789252.0;Hubble Hotbed of Vigorous Star Formation;"This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image reveals the iridescent interior of one of the most active galaxies in our local neighborhood — NGC 1569
column2: a small galaxy located about eleven million light-years away in the constellation of Camelopardalis (The Giraffe).

column1: This galaxy is currently a hotbed of vigorous star formation. NGC 1569 is a starburst galaxy
column2: meaning that — as the name suggests — it is bursting at the seams with stars
column3: and is currently producing them at a rate far higher than that observed in most other galaxies. For almost 100 million years
column4: NGC 1569 has pumped out stars more than 100 times faster than the Milky Way!

column1: As a result
column2: this glittering galaxy is home to super star clusters
column3: three of which are visible in this image — one of the two bright clusters is actually the superposition of two massive clusters. Each containing more than a million stars
column4: these brilliant blue clusters reside within a large cavity of gas carved out by multiple supernovae
column5: the energetic remnants of massive stars.

column2: Hubble observed the galaxy's cluttered core and sparsely populated outer fringes. By pinpointing individual red giant stars
column3: Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys enabled astronomers to calculate a new — and much more precise — estimate for NGC 1569’s distance. This revealed that the galaxy is actually one and a half times farther away than previously thought
column4: and a member of the IC 342 galaxy group.

column1: Astronomers suspect that the IC 342 cosmic congregation is responsible for the star-forming frenzy observed in NGC 1569. Gravitational interactions between this galactic group are believed to be compressing the gas within NGC 1569. As it is compressed
column2: the gas collapses
column3: heats up and forms new stars.

column1: Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA
column2: Aloisi
column3: Ford; Acknowledgement: Judy Schmidt

column1: Text credit: European Space Agency

27956966633.0;Hubble Views a Galaxy Fit to Burst;"This Hubble Space Telescope image reveals the vibrant core of the galaxy NGC 3125. Discovered by John Herschel in 1835
column2: NGC 3125 is a great example of a starburst galaxy — a galaxy in which unusually high numbers of new stars are forming
column3: springing to life within intensely hot clouds of gas.

column1: Located approximately 50 million light-years away in the constellation of Antlia (The Air Pump)
column2: NGC 3125 is similar to
column3: but unfathomably brighter and more energetic than
column4: one of the Magellanic Clouds. Spanning 15
column5: 000 light-years
column6: the galaxy displays massive and violent bursts of star formation
column7: as shown by the hot
column8: young
column9: and blue stars scattered throughout the galaxy’s rose-tinted core. Some of these clumps of stars are notable — one of the most extreme Wolf–Rayet star clusters in the local universe
column10: NGC 3125-A1
column11: resides within NGC 3125.

column1: Despite their appearance
column2: the fuzzy white blobs dotted around the edge of this galaxy are not stars
column3: but globular clusters. Found within a galaxy’s halo
column4: globular clusters are ancient collections of hundreds of thousands of stars. They orbit around galactic centers like satellites — the Milky Way
column5: for example
column6: hosts over 150 of them.

column1: Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA
column2: Acknowledgement: Judy Schmidt

column1: Text credit: European Space Agency

28292060866.0;Hubble Spots a Secluded Starburst Galaxy;"This image was taken by the Hubble Space Telescope’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) and shows a starburst galaxy named MCG+07-33-027. This galaxy lies some 300 million light-years away from us
column2: and is currently experiencing an extraordinarily high rate of star formation — a starburst.

column1: Normal galaxies produce only a couple of new stars per year
column2: but starburst galaxies can produce a hundred times more than that. As MCG+07-33-027 is seen face-on
column3: the galaxy’s spiral arms and the bright star-forming regions within them are clearly visible and easy for astronomers to study.

column1: In order to form newborn stars
column2: the parent galaxy has to hold a large reservoir of gas
column3: which is slowly depleted to spawn stars over time. For galaxies in a state of starburst
column4: this intense period of star formation has to be triggered somehow — often this happens due to a collision with another galaxy. MCG+07-33-027
column5: however
column6: is special; while many galaxies are located within a large cluster of galaxies
column7: MCG+07-33-027 is a field galaxy
column8: which means it is rather isolated. Thus
column9: the triggering of the starburst was most likely not due to a collision with a neighboring or passing galaxy and astronomers are still speculating about the cause. The bright object to the right of the galaxy is a foreground star in our own galaxy.

column1: Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA and N. Grogin (STScI)
Text credit: European Space Agency

View the NASA release here.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/3da6dc9a5f3e43d19ccaa00086b58c75;2016-07-11;674.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28292060866/in/album-72157667717916600;mcg0733027
27415290074.0;Hubble Uncovers a Mysterious Hermit;"The drizzle of stars scattered across this image forms a galaxy known as UGC 4879. UGC 4879 is an irregular dwarf galaxy — as the name suggests
column2: galaxies of this type are a little smaller and messier than their cosmic cousins
column3: lacking the majestic swirl of a spiral or the coherence of an elliptical.

column1: This galaxy is also very isolated. There are about 2.3 million light years between UGC 4879 and its closest neighbor
column2: Leo A
column3: which is about the same distance as that between the Andromeda Galaxy and the Milky Way.

column1: This galaxy’s isolation means that it has not interacted with any surrounding galaxies
column2: making it an ideal laboratory for studying star formation uncomplicated by interactions with other galaxies. Studies of UGC 4879 have revealed a significant amount of star formation in the first 4-billion-years after the Big Bang
column3: followed by a strange nine-billion-year lull in star formation
column4: ended 1-billion-years ago by a more recent recognition. The reason for this behavior
column5: however
column6: remains mysterious
column7: and the solitary galaxy continues to provide ample study material for astronomers looking to understand the complex mysteries of star birth throughout the Universe.

column1: Image credit: NASA/ESA
Text credit: European Space Agency

27748755200.0;Hubble Gazes at Stars of the Large Magellanic Cloud;"This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image shows the star cluster NGC 1854
column2: a gathering of red
column3: white and blue stars in the southern constellation of Dorado (The Dolphinfish). NGC 1854 is located about 135
column4: 000 light-years away in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC)
column5: one of our closest cosmic neighbors and a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way.

column1: The LMC is a hotbed of vigorous star formation. Rich in interstellar gas and dust
column2: the galaxy is home to approximately 60 globular clusters and 700 open clusters. These clusters are frequently the subject of astronomical research
column3: as the Large Magellanic Cloud and its little sister
column4: the Small Magellanic Cloud
column5: are the only systems known to contain clusters at all stages of evolution. Hubble is often used to study these clusters as its extremely high-resolution cameras can resolve individual stars
column6: even at the clusters’ crowded cores
column7: revealing their mass
column8: size and degree of evolution.

column1: Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA
Text credit: European Space Agency

28163290911.0;Launch of Space Shuttle Atlantis on STS-125 Mission;"Space Shuttle Atlantis and its seven-member STS-125 crew head toward Earth orbit and rendezvous with NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. Liftoff was on time at 2:01 p.m. EDT on May 11
column3: from Launch Pad 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center.

column1: Onboard were astronauts Scott Altman
column2: commander; Gregory C. Johnson
column3: pilot; Michael Good
column4: Megan McArthur
column5: John Grunsfeld
column6: Mike Massimino and Andrew Feustel
column7: all mission specialists.

column1: Atlantis' 12-day flight included five spacewalks that refurbished and upgraded the telescope with state-of-the-art science instruments that expanded Hubble's capabilities and extended its operational lifespan. The payload included the Wide Field Camera 3
column2: a fine guidance sensor and the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/c8c391047618b1d40a7cbe8628848334;2009-05-14;2008.0;3000.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28163290911/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission shuttlemission spaceshuttle kennedyspacecenter spaceshuttleatlantis launch

column1: 39866059134.0;A frenzy of stars;"Discovered in 1900 by astronomer DeLisle Stewart and here imaged by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope
column2: IC 4710 is an undeniably spectacular sight. The galaxy is a busy cloud of bright stars
column3: with bright pockets - marking bursts of new star formation - scattered around its edges.

column1: IC 4710 is a dwarf irregular galaxy. As the name suggests
column2: such galaxies are irregular and chaotic in appearance
column3: lacking central bulges and spiral arms - they are distinctly different from spirals or ellipticals. It is thought that irregular galaxies may once have been spirals or ellipticals
column4: but became distorted over time through external gravitational forces during interactions or mergers with other galaxies. Dwarf irregulars in particular are important to our overall understanding of galactic evolution
column5: as they are thought to be similar to the first galaxies that formed in the universe.

column1: IC 4710 lies roughly 25 million light-years away in the southern constellation of Pavo (the Peacock). This constellation also contains the third-brightest globular cluster in the sky
column2: NGC 6752
column3: the spiral galaxy NGC 6744
column4: and six known planetary systems (including HD 181433
column5: which is host to a super-Earth).

column1: The data used to create this image were gathered by Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS).
Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA
column2: Acknowledgements: Judy Schmidt";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/a70d59fc5347456794739a6f33cbdf62;2017-06-27;946.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/39866059134/in/album-72157667717916600;ic4710

column1: 27946391401.0;Astronaut Mark C. Lee;Backdropped against the aft firewall of Discovery's cargo bay and the starboard orbital maneuvering system (OMS) pod
column2: astronaut Mark C. Lee
column3: payload commander
column4: watches as astronaut Steven L. Smith (out of frame but reflected in Lee's helmet visor plate) stands on the end of the remote manipulator system (RMS). 39855026671.0;Hubble's Celestial Snow Globe;"It's beginning to look a lot like the holiday season in this NASA Hubble Space Telescope image of a blizzard of stars
column2: which resembles a swirling snowstorm in a snow globe.

column1: The stars are residents of the globular star cluster Messier 79
column2: or M79
column3: located 41
column4: 000 light-years from Earth
column5: in the constellation Lepus. The cluster is also known as NGC 1904.

column1: Globular clusters are gravitationally bound groupings of as many as 1 million stars. M79 contains about 150
column2: 000 stars packed into an area measuring only 118 light-years across. These giant "star-globes" contain some of the oldest stars in our galaxy
column3: estimated to be 11.7 billion years old.

column1: Most globular clusters are grouped around the central hub of our pinwheel-shaped galaxy. However
column2: M79's home is nearly on the opposite side of the sky from the direction of the galactic center. One idea for the cluster's unusual location is that its neighborhood may contain a higher-than-average density of stars
column3: which fueled its formation. Another possibility is that M79 may have formed in an unusual dwarf galaxy that is merging with the Milky Way.

column1: In the Hubble image
column2: Sun-like stars appear yellow. The reddish stars are bright giants that represent the final stages of a star's life. Most of the blue stars sprinkled throughout the cluster are aging "helium-burning" stars. These bright blue stars have exhausted their hydrogen fuel and are now fusing helium in their cores.

column1: A scattering of fainter blue stars are "blue stragglers." These unusual stars glow in blue light
column2: mimicking the appearance of hot
column3: young stars. Blue stragglers form either by the merger of stars in a binary system or by the collision of two unrelated stars in M79's crowded core.

column1: The star cluster was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1780. Méchain reported the finding to Charles Messier
column2: who included it in his catalog of non-cometary objects. About four years later
column3: using a larger telescope than Messier's
column4: William Herschel resolved the stars in M79
column5: and described it as a "globular star cluster."

column1: The image is a combination of observations taken in 1995 and 1997 by Hubble's Wide Field Planetary Camera 2. The red
column2: green
column3: and blue colors used to compose the image represent a natural view of the cluster.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope is a project of international cooperation between NASA and ESA (European Space Agency). NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt
column2: Maryland
column3: manages the telescope. The Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore
column4: Maryland
column5: conducts Hubble science operations. STScI is operated for NASA by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy
column6: Inc.
column7: in Washington

column1: 37497400621.0;Galaxies in a swarm of star clusters;"In the center of a rich cluster of galaxies located in the direction of the constellation of Coma Berenices
column2: lies a galaxy surrounded by a swarm of star clusters. NGC 4874 is a giant elliptical galaxy
column3: about ten times larger than the Milky Way
column4: at the center of the Coma Galaxy Cluster. With its strong gravitational pull
column5: it is able to hold onto more than 30
column6: 000 globular clusters of stars
column7: more than any other galaxy that we know of
column8: and even has a few dwarf galaxies in its grasp.

column1: In this Hubble Space Telescope image
column2: NGC 4874 is the brightest object
column3: located to the right of the frame and seen as a bright star-like core surrounded by a hazy halo. A few of the other galaxies of the cluster are also visible
column4: looking like flying saucers dancing around NGC 4874. But the really remarkable feature of this image is the point-like objects around NGC 4874
column5: revealed on a closer look: almost all of them  are clusters of stars that belong to the galaxy. Each of these globular star clusters contains many hundreds of thousands of stars.

column1: Recently
column2: astronomers discovered that a few of these point-like objects are not  star clusters but ultra-compact dwarf galaxies
column3: also under the  gravitational influence of NGC 4874. Being only about 200 light-years across and mostly made up of old stars
column4: these galaxies resemble brighter  and larger versions of globular clusters. They are thought to be the  cores of small elliptical galaxies that
column5: due to the violent interactions  with other galaxies in the cluster
column6: lost their gas and surrounding stars.

column1: This Hubble image also shows many more distant galaxies that do not belong to the cluster
column2: seen as small smudges in the background. While the  galaxies in the Coma Cluster are located about 350 million light-years  away
column3: these other objects are much further out. Their light took several hundred million to billions of years to reach us.

column1: Most unusually
column2: the image also shows a very faint blue satellite trail
column3: extending across the whole image
column4: from the upper left corner of the frame to the lower right. Because Hubble’s cameras can only see a tiny part of the sky at one time
column5: such trails are very rare.

column1: This picture was created from optical and near-infrared exposures taken with  the Wide Field Channel of Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys. The  field of view is 3.3 arcminutes across.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/0dbe5f05344345f54c7aa7dcdfb43e55;2011-09-19;1080.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/37497400621/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4874

37466224842.0;Hubble Is Paving Scientific Paths for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope;"NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope is helping identify potential celestial targets for the James Webb Space Telescope through a series of preparatory science observations to be completed before Webb is ready to make observations of its own.

This preparatory science program began in 2016 in response to the desire of astronomers to use Hubble observations to set the stage for Webb. The program marked the first time astronomers were encouraged to submit science proposals for Hubble observations that could pave the way for Webb’s own observations. So far
column2: 40 proposals have been approved.

column1: Using multiple observatories to analyze the same objects can identify aspects of those objects that using one observatory alone cannot. Hubble was designed to primarily observe the universe through visible light (though it is also able to see into the ultraviolet and near-infrared)
column2: while Webb is specifically designed to observe the universe in infrared light
column3: through both direct imaging and spectroscopy. Spectroscopy measures the spectrum of light
column4: which scientists analyze to determine physical properties of what is being observed
column5: including temperature
column6: mass
column7: and chemical composition.

column1: Several preparatory science proposals in the program promise to use Hubble to deliver observational data Webb is not designed to collect. Hubble is able to see parts of the visible-light spectrum that Webb is not able to observe
column2: and so it can fill potential observational gaps. For example
column3: Hubble can examine exoplanets in light across the full electromagnetic spectrum available to it
column4: with emphasis on the ultraviolet and blue wavelengths. Coupled with Webb’s infrared capabilities
column5: both telescopes will deliver a more complete picture of the exoplanet systems.

column1: Other proposals have a goal of using Hubble to carry some of the workload for Webb
column2: allowing astronomers to use their observation time with Webb more efficiently. Astronomers could use Hubble to survey multiple targets and determine the best strategy for Webb to perform further analysis. Depending on the data Hubble returned
column3: astronomers would know to observe targets with Webb in a broad range of infrared wavelengths or to focus on smaller wavelength ranges
column4: thus giving them a better starting point for their own observations.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/d14a71ebbdc2c4ae79877e85488d895e;2017-09-21;735.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/37466224842/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 39855066531.0;Lasers and supermassive black holes;"This image
column2: captured by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope’s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3)
column3: shows a galaxy named UGC 6093. As can be easily seen
column4: UGC 6093 is something known as a barred spiral galaxy — it has beautiful arms that swirl outwards from a bar slicing through the galaxy’s center. It is classified as an active galaxy
column5: which means that it hosts an active galactic nucleus
column6: or AGN: a compact region at a galaxy’s center within which material is dragged towards a supermassive black hole. As this black hole devours the surrounding matter it emits intense radiation
column7: causing it to shine brightly. But UGC 6093 is more exotic still. The galaxy essentially acts as a giant astronomical laser that spews out light at microwave
column8: not visible
column9: wavelengths — this type of object is dubbed a megamaser (maser being the term for a microwave laser). Megamasers such as UGC 6093 can be some 100 million times brighter than masers found in galaxies like the Milky Way. Hubble’s WFC3 observes light spanning a range wavelengths — from the near-infrared
column10: through the visible range
column11: to the near-ultraviolet. It has two channels that detect and process different light
column12: allowing astronomers to study a remarkable range of astrophysical phenomena; for example
column13: the UV-visible channel can study galaxies undergoing massive star formation
column14: while the near-infrared channel can study redshifted light from galaxies in the distant Universe. Such multi-band imaging makes Hubble invaluable in studying megamaser galaxies
column15: as it is able to untangle their intriguing complexity.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/9224184871a3b805063802c06f7424ba;2017-06-09;545.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/39855066531/in/album-72157667717916600;ugc6093

column1: 36428619833.0;Starbursts in NGC 5398;"This Hubble Space Telescope picture shows NGC 5398
column2: a barred spiral galaxy located about 55 million light-years away.

column1: The galaxy is famous for containing an especially extensive HII region
column2: a large cloud composed of ionized hydrogen (or HII
column3: pronounced “H-two”
column4: with H being the chemical symbol for hydrogen and the “II” indicating that the atoms have lost an electron to become ionized). NGC 5398’s cloud is named Tol 89 and sits at the lower left end of the galaxy’s central “bar” of stars
column5: a structure that cuts through the galactic core and funnels material inwards to maintain the star formation occurring there.

column1: Tol 89 is conspicuous in being the only large massive star forming complex in the entire galaxy
column2: with an extension of roughly 5
column4: 000 light-years; it contains at least seven young and massive star clusters. The two brightest clumps within Tol 89
column5: which astronomers have named simply “A” and “B
column6: ” appear to have undergone two bursts of star-forming activity — “starbursts” — roughly 4 million and less than 3 million years ago
column7: respectively. Tol 89-A is thought to contain a number of particularly bright and massive stars known as Wolf-Rayet stars
column8: which are known for their high temperatures and extreme stellar winds.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/bff0ca9698ba08ad91347e64d1be2f6d;2016-12-03;520.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36428619833/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc5398

column1: 35632968244.0;M45;"In this image
column2: which combines visible and infrared observations
column3: Hubble has captured the eerie
column4: wispy tendrils of an interstellar cloud being destroyed by one of the brightest stars in M45. Like fireworks illuminating dark clouds at night
column5: the star’s light is reflecting off the surface of pitch-black clouds of cold gas laced with dust. This produces a reflection nebula.

column1: Commonly called the Pleiades or Seven Sisters
column2: M45 is known as an open star cluster. It contains over a thousand stars that are loosely bound by gravity
column3: but it is visually dominated by a handful of its brightest members.

column1: One of these stars
column2: Merope
column3: is located just outside the frame of this image to the upper right. The colorful rays of light at the upper right
column4: emanating from the star
column5: are an optical phenomenon produced within the telescope. The nearly straight
column6: blue-white wisps pointing toward the upper right are streams of large dust particles. As the cloud moves toward Merope
column7: its smaller dust particles are slowed down by the star’s radiation pressure more than the larger particles are. The large dust particles continue on toward the star while the smaller particles are left behind at the lower left of the picture.

column1: The Pleiades cluster has been observed since ancient times
column2: so it has no known discoverer. However
column3: Galileo Galilei
column4: the Italian scientist best known for discovering the largest moons of Jupiter and championing a heliocentric model of the solar system
column5: was the first to observe the Pleiades through a telescope. M45 is located an average distance of 445 light-years from Earth in the constellation Taurus. It has an apparent magnitude of 1.6 and can be seen with the naked eye. The cluster is best observed during January.

column1: 36046499800.0;M22;"While scanning the night sky in search of Saturn in August of 1665
column2: the German amateur astronomer Abraham Ihle made an amazing discovery: the globular cluster M22. It was one of the first objects of its kind ever detected. Located 10
column3: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Sagittarius
column4: the cluster’s relatively bright apparent magnitude of 5.1 makes it a popular target for today’s amateur astronomers. In ideal conditions
column5: M22 can be seen with the naked eye. The best time to observe the cluster is during August.

column1: Containing some of the oldest known stars
column2: globular clusters are popular objects of study for astronomers. M22 has some additional features that are particularly fascinating: two stellar-mass black holes
column3: and six planet-sized objects (discovered by Hubble) that are not orbiting stars. The cluster is also one of only four of its kind ever found to host a planetary nebula — a short-lived gaseous shell ejected by a star at the end of its life.

column1: Hubble’s stunning image
column2: created using visible and infrared observations
column3: captured the densely packed heart of M22.

35674229833.0;M10;"Discovered by Charles Messier in 1764
column2: M10 is a globular cluster located in the constellation Ophiuchus. It is roughly 15
column3: 000 light-years from Earth and has an apparent magnitude of 6.4. This cluster can be spotted using a pair of binoculars and is most easily observed during July.

column1: M10 is notable for its high population of blue stragglers — stars that appear to be far younger than their neighbors. The stars in globular clusters are thought to have formed and aged together
column2: so they should all be roughly the same age. These anomalous
column3: bluer stars were created either by collisions between stars or other stellar interactions. Such events are easy to imagine in densely populated globular clusters
column4: in which up to a few million stars are tightly packed together.

column1: Hubble’s image of M10’s dense core is made up of observations taken in visible and infrared light.
For more information about Hubble’s observations of M10
