36345580381.0;M30;"This Hubble image of M30 is composed of exposures taken in visible and infrared light. It captures the cluster’s several hundred thousand stars in stunning detail.
Although globular clusters such as M30 are mainly populated by old stars
column2: the density of the stellar swarm leads to some old stars apparently reclaiming their youth as "blue stragglers." Using observations from Hubble
column3: astronomers have identified two types of blue stragglers in M30: those that form in near head-on collisions between two stars and those that are in binary systems where one star siphons hydrogen from its companion.

column1: M30 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. It is located roughly 28
column2: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Capricornus. It has an apparent magnitude of 7.7 and can be seen through a pair of binoculars. M30 is best observed during September.

35633114204.0;M101;"This stunning view of M101
column2: also known as the Pinwheel galaxy
column3: is one of the largest images Hubble has ever captured of a spiral galaxy. Assembled from 51 exposures taken during various studies over nearly ten years
column4: this infrared and visible-light image measures 16
column6: 000 pixels. Ground-based images were used to fill in the portions of the galaxy that Hubble did not observe.

column1: The giant spiral disk of stars
column2: dust and gas is 170
column3: 000 light-years across — nearly twice the diameter of our galaxy
column4: the Milky Way. M101 is estimated to contain at least one trillion stars. The galaxy’s spiral arms are sprinkled with large regions of star-forming nebulas. These nebulas are areas of intense star formation within giant molecular hydrogen clouds. Brilliant
column5: young clusters of hot
column6: blue
column7: newborn stars trace out the spiral arms.

column1: Pierre Méchain
column2: one of Charles Messier’s colleagues
column3: discovered the Pinwheel galaxy in 1781. Located 25 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Ursa Major
column4: M101 has an apparent magnitude of 7.9. It can be spotted through a small telescope and is most easily observed during April.

column1: 36300319052.0;M106;"This magnificent view of the spiral galaxy M106 was assembled from Hubble exposures and ground-based images taken by the amateur astronomer Robert Gendler. Gendler’s ground-based images were used to fill in pieces of the galaxy that Hubble did not observe. The center of the galaxy is composed almost entirely of Hubble observations. The outer spiral arms are also predominantly Hubble data
column2: but were colorized with ground-based images taken by Gendler and fellow amateur astronomer Jay GaBany.

column1: The image reveals one of the most striking features of M106: its extra pair of arms. Most spiral galaxies only have one pair of arms
column2: but M106 has an extra set
column3: seen here as red wisps of gas. Unlike the other arms
column4: these two extra arms are made up of hot gas rather than stars. Astronomers attribute these ghostly arms to the supermassive black hole at the galaxy’s center. The extra arms appear to be an indirect result of the violent churning of matter around the black hole.

column1: M106 was discovered by Charles Messier’s observing assistant
column2: Pierre Méchain
column3: in 1781. It is located 24 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Canes Venatici. Although a larger telescope is needed to resolve detail
column4: M106 has a relatively bright apparent magnitude of 9.1 and can be spotted with a small telescope. It is best observed during May.

column1: For more information on Hubble’s observations of M106

39878609355.0;M89;"M89 is one of eight galaxies in the Virgo cluster that Charles Messier discovered in 1781. An elliptical galaxy
column2: M89 is almost exactly circular. It is located about 50 million light-years away in the constellation Virgo.

column1: M89 contains approximately 100 billion stars and well over 2
column2: 000 globular clusters. It was the first galaxy discovered to have an extended envelope
column3: which means that it has a larger region of light surrounding it than other elliptical galaxies
column4: most likely because of its high number of stars and globular clusters. At the center of M89 is a supermassive black hole estimated to have one billion times the mass of our Sun.

column1: This image combines Hubble observations of M89 taken in near-infrared and visible light using the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2. It features most of the galaxy
column2: with M89's bright central nucleus at the top right of the image and many of its globular clusters appearing as star-like points of light throughout the field. The image also captures a separate edge-on spiral galaxy below M89's core. These Hubble observations were taken to help determine the structure and formation of elliptical galaxies
column3: as well as searching for evidence of black holes in the hearts of these galaxies.

column1: Telescopes that are 8 inches or larger can see the 9.8-magnitude galaxy as a faint ball of light. The best time to view M89 is in May.
Credits: NASA
column2: ESA
column3: STScI
column4: and M. Franx (Universiteit Leiden) and S. Faber (University of California

column1: 37482401952.0;M105;"Hubble peered into the core of M105 (also known as NGC 3379) and measured the motions of stars swirling around its center. These observations proved that a supermassive black hole resides at the galaxy’s heart. According to recent estimates
column2: this black hole could be up to 200 million times as massive as our Sun.

column1: 36484697745.0;M63;"Star formation is one of the most important processes in shaping the universe. In addition to birthing new stars
column2: it gives rise to planetary systems and plays a pivotal role in the evolution of galaxies. Yet there is still much that astronomers do not understand about this fundamental process. The driving force behind star formation is particularly unclear for a type of galaxy called a flocculent spiral. Unlike grand-design spiral galaxies
column3: flocculent spiral galaxies do not have well defined spiral arms. Instead
column4: they appear to have many discontinuous arms.

column2: also known as the Sunflower galaxy
column3: is one such flocculent spiral galaxy. Although it only has two arms
column4: many appear to be winding around its yellow core in this image captured by Hubble. The arms shine with the radiation from recently formed blue stars and can be more clearly seen in infrared observations. By imaging flocculent spiral galaxies like M63
column5: astronomers hope to gain a better understanding of how stars form in such systems.

column1: The Sunflower galaxy was discovered in 1779 by the French astronomer Pierre Méchain and was the first of 24 objects that Méchain would contribute to Charles Messier’s catalog. The galaxy is located roughly 27 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Canes Venatici. It has an apparent magnitude of 9.3 and appears as a faint patch of light in small telescopes. The best time to observe M63 is during May.
For more information about Hubble’s observations of M63
column2: see:

39878610545.0;M58;"Discovered in 1779 by Charles Messier
column2: M58 was one of the first galaxies recognized to have a spiral shape and is one of four barred spiral galaxies in Messier's catalog. M58 is one of the brightest galaxies in the constellation Virgo. Located roughly 62 million light-years from Earth
column3: M58 is the most distant Messier object.

column1: Although it appears bright
column2: M58's core is relatively dim compared to other spiral galaxies. The core contains high rates of star formation
column3: known as starburst activity. It also houses a supermassive black hole around 70 million times the mass of our Sun. A very small ring around the galaxy's nucleus
column4: known as an ultra-compact nuclear ring
column5: is a main region of widespread starburst activity in M58 and is a rare phenomenon among galaxies.

column1: Long arms extend out from the galaxy's bright nucleus. However
column2: a lack of hydrogen means that there is very little star formation activity in the arms. This could be the result of gravitational interactions with the nearby galaxies of the Virgo cluster. Two supernovas have been detected in M58
column3: one in 1988 and the other in 1989.

column1: The best time to view M58 is in May. With a magnitude of 9.8
column2: the galaxy is best observed with an 8-inch or larger telescope
column3: but it can be seen with large binoculars on clear nights as well. Small telescopes will only reveal the galaxy's core.

column1: This Hubble observation was taken in ultraviolet and visible light using the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2. The image's stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera. It shows about half of M58
column2: with the galaxy's core and arms filling the image. Hubble took these observations of M58 to study the properties of its nucleus (classified as a LINER
column3: or low-ionization nuclear emission-line region) and compare it with active galactic nuclei in the centers of other galaxies.

column1: 36348775181.0;M71;"Ever since it was discovered in 1746 by the Swiss astronomer Jean-Philippe Loys de Chéseaux
column2: the nature of M71 has been the subject of some questioning. Over the centuries
column3: it has been classified as both an abnormally dense open star cluster and as an unusually loose globular cluster.

column1: Because M71 does not seem to have a high concentration of stars at its center
column2: and because the elemental composition of the stars it contains suggests that they are younger than most globular clusters
column3: M71 was initially believed to be an open cluster. In the 1970s
column4: astronomers examined the relationship between the brightnesses and temperatures of the stars in the cluster. They found a characteristic trend among the stellar population that is unique to globular clusters
column5: so M71 was reclassified as a young
column6: loosely concentrated globular cluster — one of the smallest of its kind.

column1: This Hubble image of M71 is a composite of observations at visible and infrared wavelengths of light. M71 is located roughly 13
column2: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Sagitta. It has an apparent magnitude of 6.1 and appears as a faint patch of light with a pair of binoculars. The cluster is best observed during September.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M71

36440353816.0;M72;"Pierre Méchain
column2: a French astronomer and colleague of Charles Messier
column3: discovered the globular cluster M72 in 1780. It was the first of five star clusters that Méchain would discover while assisting Messier and
column4: at a distance of 50
column5: 000 light-years from Earth
column6: it is one of the most remote clusters in Messier’s catalog. M72 is located in the constellation Aquarius and has an apparent magnitude of 9.4. The cluster appears as a faint patch of light in small telescopes
column7: and the best time to observe it is during September.

column1: A globular cluster is an ancient
column2: spherical collection of old stars that are packed very closely together toward the cluster’s center. The stars in the cluster orbit around a mutual center of gravity at this dense core. Roughly 150 globular clusters have been discovered in the Milky Way galaxy.

column1: This image of M72 from Hubble combines observations at visible and infrared wavelengths. Capturing huge numbers of stars in the cluster itself
column2: the picture also reveals many galaxies that are much more distant than M72
column3: seen between and around the cluster stars.

36443798005.0;M77;"Initially identified as a nebula by the French astronomer Pierre Méchain in 1780
column2: M77 is one of the largest galaxies in the Messier catalog. It is located in the constellation Cetus at a distance of 45 million light-years from Earth. M77 has an apparent magnitude of 9.6 and can be seen using a small telescope. It is most easily observed during December.

column1: Hubble has captured this vivid image of M77’s center using visible and infrared observations. The streaks of red and blue in the image highlight pockets of star formation along the pinwheeling arms
column2: with dark dust lanes wrapping around the galaxy’s starry center.

column1: M77 is a prime example of a Seyfert galaxy
column2: or a galaxy with an intensely active center that is obscured by gas and dust in visible light.

column9: and Andrew J. Feustel. Altman commanded the final space shuttle mission to Hubble

column1: 27712253693.0;Hubble Space Telescope Support Systems Module;"This illustration depicts the design features of the Hubble Space Telescope's Support Systems Module (SSM). The SSM is one of the three major elements of Hubble and encloses the other two elements
column2: the Optical Telescope Assembly (OTA) and the Scientific Instruments (SI).

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column3: is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit. By placing the telescope in space
column4: astronomers are able to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble detects objects 25 times fainter than the dimmest objects seen from Earth and provides astronomers with an observable universe 250 times larger than is visible from ground-based telescopes
column5: extending our view more than 13 billion light-years away. Hubble views galaxies
column6: stars
column7: planets
column8: comets
column9: planet formation in other solar systems
column10: and even unusual phenomena such as quasars
column11: with 10 times the clarity of ground-based telescopes.

column1: The spacecraft is 42.5 feet (13 meters) long and weighs 25
column2: 000 pounds (11
column3: 600 kilograms). Two communication antennas
column4: two solar array panels that collect energy for Hubble
column5: and storage bays for electronic gear are on the outside. Hubble was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery (STS-31 mission) into Earth orbit in April 1990.

column1: The Marshall Space Flight Center had responsibility for design
column2: development
column3: and construction of the observatory. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury
column4: Connecticut
column5: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. The Lockheed Missile and Space Company of Sunnyvale
column6: California
column7: produced the protective outer shroud and spacecraft systems
column8: and assembled and tested the finished telescope.

30257723195.0;The center of NGC 247;"This Hubble image shows the central region of a spiral galaxy known as NGC 247. NGC 247 is a relatively small spiral galaxy in the southern constellation of Cetus (the Whale). Lying at a distance of around 11 million light-years from us
column2: it forms part of the Sculptor Group
column3: a loose collection of galaxies that also contains the more famous NGC 253 (otherwise known as the Sculptor Galaxy).

column1: NGC 247's nucleus is visible here as a bright
column2: whitish patch
column3: surrounded by a mixture of stars
column4: gas and dust. The dust forms dark patches and filaments that are silhouetted against the background of stars
column5: while the gas has formed into bright knots known as H II regions
column6: mostly scattered throughout the galaxy's arms and outer areas.

column1: This galaxy displays one particularly unusual and mysterious feature — it is not visible in this image
column2: but can be seen clearly in wider views of the galaxy
column3: such as this picture from ESO's MPG/ESO 2.2-meter telescope. The northern part of NGC 247's disk hosts an apparent void
column4: a gap in the usual swarm of stars and H II regions that spans almost a third of the galaxy's total length.

column1: There are stars within this void
column2: but they are quite different from those around it. They are significantly older
column3: and as a result much fainter and redder. This indicates that the star formation taking place across most of the galaxy's disk has somehow been arrested in the void region
column4: and has not taken place for around one billion years. Although astronomers are still unsure how the void formed
column5: recent studies suggest it might have been caused by gravitational interactions with part of another galaxy.

column1: NASA image use policy
NASA Hubble Space Telescope

28085733274.0;Hubble Gazes at Long-dead Star;"This Hubble Space Telescope image captures the remnants of a long-dead star. These rippling wisps of ionized gas
column2: named DEM L316A
column3: are located some 160
column4: 000 light-years away within one of the Milky Way’s closest galactic neighbors — the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC).

column1: The explosion that formed DEM L316A was an example of an especially energetic and bright variety of supernova
column2: known as a Type Ia. Such supernova events are thought to occur when a white dwarf star steals more material than it can handle from a nearby companion
column3: and becomes unbalanced. The result is a spectacular release of energy in the form of a bright
column4: violent explosion
column5: which ejects the star’s outer layers into the surrounding space at immense speeds. As this expelled gas travels through the interstellar material
column6: it heats up and ionizes it
column7: producing the faint glow that Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3 has captured here.

column1: The LMC orbits the Milky Way as a satellite galaxy and is the fourth largest in our group of galaxies
column2: the Local Group. DEM L316A is not the only supernova remnant in the LMC; Hubble came across another one in 2010 with SNR 0509
column3: and in 2013 it snapped SNR 0519.

column1: Image credit: ESA (European Space Agency)/Hubble & NASA
column2: Y. Chu

30319502845.0;Cassiopeia's unusual resident;"This image
column2: taken by the Hubble Space Telescope's Wide Field Planetary Camera 2
column3: shows a spiral galaxy named NGC 278. This cosmic beauty lies some 38 million light-years away in the northern constellation of Cassiopeia (the Seated Queen).

column1: While NGC 278 may look serene
column2: it is anything but. The galaxy is currently undergoing an immense burst of star formation. This flurry of activity is shown by the unmistakable blue-hued knots speckling the galaxy's spiral arms
column3: each of which marks a clump of hot newborn stars.

column1: However
column2: NGC 278's star formation is somewhat unusual; it does not extend to the galaxy's outer edges
column3: but is only taking place within an inner ring some 6
column4: 500 light-years across. This two-tiered structure is visible in this image — while the galaxy's center is bright
column5: its extremities are much darker. This odd configuration is thought to have been caused by a merger with a smaller
column6: gas-rich galaxy — while the turbulent event ignited the center of NGC 278
column7: the dusty remains of the small snack then dispersed into the galaxy's outer regions. Whatever the cause
column8: such a ring of star formation
column9: called a nuclear ring
column10: is extremely unusual in galaxies without a bar at their center
column11: making NGC 278 a very intriguing sight.

column1: NASA image use policy
NASA Hubble Space Telescope

31784535286.0;Astro-pointillism;"On a clear evening in April of 1789
column2: the renowned astronomer William Herschel continued his unrelenting survey of the night sky
column3: hunting for new cosmic objects — and found cause to celebrate! Lengthening his impressive list of cosmic discoveries yet again
column4: the astronomer spotted this bright spiral galaxy
column5: named NGC 4707
column6: lurking in the constellation of Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs). NGC 4707 lies roughly 22 million light-years from Earth.

column1: Over two centuries later
column2: the Hubble Space Telescope is able to view the same galaxy in far greater detail than Herschel could
column3: allowing us to appreciate the intricacies and characteristics of NGC 4707 as never before. This striking image comprises observations from Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)
column4: one of a handful of high-resolution instruments currently aboard the space telescope.

column1: Herschel himself reportedly described NGC 4707 as a “small
column2: stellar” galaxy; while it is classified as a spiral (type Sm)
column3: its overall shape
column4: center
column5: and spiral arms are very loose and undefined
column6: and its central bulge is either very small or non-existent. It instead appears as a rough sprinkling of stars and bright flashes of blue on a dark canvas
column7: as if a pointillist painter had dotted the cosmos with small pinpricks of bright paint.

column2: payload commander

column1: 27414029694.0;Hubble Observes Infant Stars in Nearby Galaxy;"This image taken with NASA's Hubble Space Telescope depicts bright
column2: blue
column3: newly formed stars that are blowing a cavity in the center of a star-forming region in the Small Magellanic Cloud.

column1: At the heart of the star-forming region
column2: lies star cluster NGC 602. The high-energy radiation blazing out from the hot young stars is sculpting the inner edge of the outer portions of the nebula
column3: slowly eroding it away and eating into the material beyond. The diffuse outer reaches of the nebula prevent the energetic outflows from streaming away from the cluster.

column1: Ridges of dust and gaseous filaments are seen towards the northwest (in the upper-left part of the image) and towards the southeast (in the lower right-hand corner). Elephant trunk-like dust pillars point towards the hot blue stars and are tell-tale signs of their eroding effect. In this region it is possible with Hubble to trace how the star formation started at the center of the cluster and propagated outward
column2: with the youngest stars still forming today along the dust ridges.

column1: The Small Magellanic Cloud
column2: in the constellation Tucana
column3: is roughly 200
column4: 000 light-years from Earth. Its proximity to us makes it an exceptional laboratory to perform in-depth studies of star formation processes and their evolution in an environment slightly different from our own Milky Way.

column1: Dwarf galaxies such as the Small Magellanic Cloud
column2: with significantly fewer stars compared to our own galaxy
column3: are considered to be the primitive building blocks of larger galaxies. The study of star formation within this dwarf galaxy is particularly interesting to astronomers because its primitive nature means that it lacks a large percentage of the heavier elements that are forged in successive generations of stars through nuclear fusion.

column1: These observations were taken with Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys in July 2004. Filters that isolate visible and infrared light were combined with a filter that samples the hydrogen and nitrogen emission from the glowing clouds.
For more information
column2: visit:

column3: and the Hubble Heritage Team (STScI/AURA) - ESA/Hubble Collaboration";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/be9c33d1c793bee3cad783bd325ad73a;2016-07-01;3659.0;3749.0;CC BY;7.21576698597e+16;Hubble Highlights;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27414029694/in/album-72157669859734000;hubblespacetelescope hubble nasa space astronomy starformation smallmegallaniccloud smc starcluster ngc602 tucana

column1: 27925737332.0;Barred Spiral Galaxy NGC 1300;"The Hubble Space Telescope captured a display of starlight
column2: glowing gas
column3: and silhouetted dark clouds of interstellar dust in this image of the barred spiral galaxy NGC 1300. NGC 1300 is considered to be prototypical of barred spiral galaxies. Barred spirals differ from normal spiral galaxies in that the arms of the galaxy do not spiral all the way into the center
column4: but are connected to the two ends of a straight bar of stars containing the nucleus at its center.

column1: At Hubble's resolution
column2: a myriad of fine details
column3: some of which have never before been seen
column4: is seen throughout the galaxy's arms
column5: disk
column6: bulge
column7: and nucleus. Blue and red supergiant stars
column8: star clusters
column9: and star-forming regions are well resolved across the spiral arms
column10: and dust lanes trace out fine structures in the disk and bar. Numerous more distant galaxies are visible in the background
column11: and are seen even through the densest regions of NGC 1300.

column1: In the core of the larger spiral structure of NGC 1300
column2: the nucleus shows its own extraordinary and distinct "grand-design" spiral structure that is about 3
column3: 300 light-years (1 kiloparsec) long. Only galaxies with large-scale bars appear to have these grand-design inner disks - a spiral within a spiral. Models suggest that the gas in a bar can be funneled inwards
column4: and then spiral into the center through the grand-design disk
column5: where it can potentially fuel a central black hole. NGC 1300 is not known to have an active nucleus
column6: however
column7: indicating either that there is no black hole
column8: or that it is not accreting matter.

column1: The image was constructed from exposures taken in September 2004 by the Advanced Camera for Surveys onboard Hubble in four filters. Starlight and dust are seen in blue
column2: visible
column3: and infrared light. Bright star clusters are highlighted in red by their associated emission from glowing hydrogen gas. Due to the galaxy's large size
column4: two adjacent pointings of the telescope were necessary to cover the extent of the spiral arms. The galaxy lies roughly 69 million light-years away (21 megaparsecs) in the direction of the constellation Eridanus.

27414028014.0;Omega Centauri - WFC3;"NASA's Hubble Space Telescope snapped this panoramic view of a colorful assortment of 100
column2: 000 stars residing in the crowded core of a giant star cluster. The image reveals a small region inside the massive globular cluster Omega Centauri
column3: which boasts nearly 10 million stars.

column1: Globular clusters
column2: ancient swarms of stars united by gravity
column3: are the homesteaders of our Milky Way galaxy. The stars in Omega Centauri are between 10 billion and 12 billion years old. The cluster lies about 16
column4: 000 light-years from Earth.

column1: Omega Centauri is among the biggest and most massive of some 200 globular clusters orbiting the Milky Way. It is one of the few globular clusters that can be seen with the unaided eye. Located in the constellation Centaurus
column2: it resembles a small cloud in the southern sky and might easily be mistaken for a comet.

27946233661.0;Linear Sand Dunes
column2: Mauritania;"The western end of the great Sahara Desert is captured in this southeast-looking
column3: low-oblique photograph of desert and coastal areas of Mauritania. This region of west Africa is a major source of eolian sand that is transported across the Atlantic Ocean to North America. Other photographs taken during Space Shuttle flights have charted the distance and areal extent that these west African dust palls travel. The yellow and orange areas are sand dunes and sand sheets
column4: and the darker areas are bedrock outcrops. The major area of northeast-southwest-trending bedrock produces a downwind "wind shadow" effect on the landscape that extends to the coast. The northern grayish areas with little or no sand are rock and gravel desert plains. The peninsula of Cape Blanc protrudes into Lévrier Bay.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/512edaa80f408899393261d77da306db;2016-07-01;4513.0;5641.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Deployment;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27946233661/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa hubbledeployment sts31

column1: 33032459185.0;Sidekick or star of the show?;"This image was captured by the Hubble Space Telescope’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)
column2: a highly efficient wide-field camera covering the optical and near-infrared parts of the spectrum. While this lovely image contains hundreds of distant stars and galaxies
column3: one vital thing is missing — the object Hubble was actually studying at the time!

column1: This is not because the target has disappeared. The ACS actually uses two detectors: the first captures the object being studied — in this case an open star cluster known as NGC 299 — while the other detector images the patch of space just "beneath" it. This is what can be seen here.
Technically
column2: this picture is merely a sidekick of the actual object of interest — but space is bursting with activity
column3: and this field of bright celestial bodies offers plenty of interest on its own. It may initially seem to show just stars
column4: but a closer look reveals many of these tiny objects to be galaxies. The spiral galaxies have arms curving out from a bright center. The fuzzier
column5: less clearly shaped galaxies might be ellipticals. Some of these galaxies contain millions and millions of stars
column6: but are so distant that all of their starry residents are contained within just a small pinprick of light that appears to be the  same size as a single star!

column1: The bright blue dots are very hot stars
column2: sometimes distorted into crosses by the struts supporting Hubble’s secondary mirror. The redder dots are cooler stars
column3: possibly in the red giant phase when a dying star cools and expands.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/99ec42f50437882def003e40593f3f6a;2016-08-22;525.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33032459185/in/album-72157667717916600;fieldstars

column1: 28026561445.0;Space Shuttle Atlantis on Launch Pad;"Space shuttle Atlantis sits on Launch Pad 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida after its rollout from the Vehicle Assembly Building. The shuttle sits atop the mobile launcher platform
column2: which is carried by the crawler-transporter beneath. At left is the rotating service structure with the payload changeout room that allows transfer of payloads from a canister into the shuttle's payload bay. Next to the shuttle is the fixed service structure with its 80-foot lightning mast on top.

column1: Atlantis lifted off on May 11
column3: to service NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. During Atlantis' 12-day mission
column4: its crew of seven astronauts made the final shuttle flight to Hubble. During five spacewalks
column5: they installed two new instruments
column6: repaired two inactive ones and replaced other components. This resulted in six working
column7: complementary science instruments with capabilities beyond what was previously available
column8: and extended the operational lifespan for the telescope.

column1: Photo Credit: NASA/Jack Pfaller";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/2c7ba8022248288b0e3b9d4511fedc90;2016-07-01;3000.0;1958.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28026561445/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission shuttlemission spaceshuttle kennedyspacecenter launchpad spaceshuttleatlantis
28163290971.0;STS-125 Crew Members Head for Launch Pad 39A;"After suiting up
column2: the STS-125 crewmembers exited the Operations and Checkout Building to board the Astrovan
column3: which took them to Launch Pad 39A for the launch of Space Shuttle Atlantis on the STS-125 mission to service the Hubble Space Telescope. From right to left are astronauts Scott Altman
column4: commander; Gregory C. Johnson
column5: pilot; Andrew Feustel
column6: Mike Massimino
column7: Megan McArthur
column8: John Grunsfeld and Michael Good
column9: all mission specialists.

column1: Atlantis' 12-day flight included five spacewalks that refurbished and upgraded the telescope with state-of-the-art science instruments that expanded Hubble's capabilities and extended its operational lifespan. The payload included the Wide Field Camera 3
column2: a fine guidance sensor and the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph. Launch of Atlantis took place at 2:01 p.m. EDT on May 11
column3: 2009.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/0ddd22524e9918b1c0c22d69cd581e90;2009-05-11;2008.0;3000.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28163290971/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission astronauts shuttlemission spaceshuttle astrovan kennedyspacecenter

column1: 28136831492.0;Launch of Space Shuttle Atlantis on STS-125 Mission;"Space Shuttle Atlantis and its seven-member STS-125 crew head toward Earth orbit and rendezvous with NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. Liftoff was on time at 2:01 p.m. EDT on May 11

column1: Onboard were astronauts Scott Altman

column6: Mike Massimino and Andrew Feustel

column1: 27414028794.0;Starburst Cluster Shows Celestial Fireworks;"NASA's Hubble Space Telescope imaged a glittering collection of stars.  The cluster is surrounded by clouds of interstellar gas and dust – the raw material for new star formation. The nebula
column2: located 20
column3: 000 light-years away in the constellation Carina
column4: contains a central cluster of huge
column5: hot stars
column6: called NGC 3603.

column1: This environment is not as peaceful as it looks. Ultraviolet radiation and violent stellar winds have blown out an enormous cavity in the gas and dust enveloping the cluster
column2: providing an unobstructed view of the cluster.

column1: Most of the stars in the cluster were born around the same time but differ in size
column2: mass
column3: temperature
column4: and color. The course of a star's life is determined by its mass
column5: so a cluster of a given age will contain stars in various stages of their lives
column6: giving an opportunity for detailed analyses of stellar life cycles. NGC 3603 also contains some of the most massive stars known. These huge stars live fast and die young
column7: burning through their hydrogen fuel quickly and ultimately ending their lives in supernova explosions.

column1: Star clusters like NGC 3603 provide important clues to understanding the origin of massive star formation in the early
column2: distant universe. Astronomers also use massive clusters to study distant starbursts that occur when galaxies collide
column3: igniting a flurry of star formation. The proximity of NGC 3603 makes it an excellent lab for studying such distant and momentous events.

column1: This Hubble image was captured in August 2009 and December 2009 with the Wide Field Camera 3 in both visible and infrared light
column2: which trace the glow of sulfur
column3: hydrogen
column4: and iron.

column1: 29874183300.0;Hubble Detects Giant 'Cannonballs' Shooting from Star;"Great balls of fire! NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has detected superhot blobs of gas
column2: each twice as massive as the planet Mars
column3: being ejected near a dying star. The plasma balls are zooming so fast through space it would take only 30 minutes for them to travel from Earth to the moon. This stellar "cannon fire" has continued once every 8.5 years for at least the past 400 years
column4: astronomers estimate.

column1: The fireballs present a puzzle to astronomers
column2: because the ejected material could not have been shot out by the host star
column3: called V Hydrae. The star is a bloated red giant
column4: residing 1
column5: 200 light-years away
column6: which has probably shed at least half of its mass into space during its death throes. Red giants are dying stars in the late stages of life that are exhausting their nuclear fuel that makes them shine. They have expanded in size and are shedding their outer layers into space.

column1: This four-panel graphic illustrates how the binary-star system V Hydrae is launching balls of plasma into space.
Panel 1 shows the two stars orbiting each other. One of the stars is nearing the end of its life and has swelled in size
column2: becoming a red giant.

column1: In panel 2
column2: the smaller star's orbit carries the star into the red giant's expanded atmosphere. As the star moves through the atmosphere
column3: it gobbles up material from the red giant
column4: which settles into a disk around the star.

column1: The buildup of material reaches a tipping point and is eventually ejected as blobs of hot plasma along the star's spin axis
column2: shown in panel 3.

column1: This ejection process is repeated every eight years
column2: the time it takes for the orbiting star to make another pass through the bloated red giant's envelope
column3: shown in panel 4.

column2: click here.

29081669631.0;Stellar shrapnel;"Several thousand years ago
column2: a star some 160
column3: 000 light-years away from us exploded
column4: scattering stellar shrapnel across the sky. The aftermath of this energetic detonation is shown here in this striking image from the Hubble Space Telescope’s Wide Field Camera 3.

column1: The exploding star was a white dwarf located in the Large Magellanic Cloud
column2: one of our nearest neighboring galaxies. Around 97% of stars within the Milky Way that are between a tenth and eight times the mass of the Sun are expected to end up as white dwarfs. These stars can face a number of different fates
column3: one of which is to explode as supernovae
column4: some of the brightest events ever observed in the universe. If a white dwarf is part of a binary star system
column5: it can siphon material from a close companion. After gobbling up more than it can handle — and swelling to approximately one and a half times the size of the Sun — the star becomes unstable and ignites as a Type Ia supernova.

column1: This was the case for the supernova remnant pictured here
column2: which is known as DEM L71. It formed when a white dwarf reached the end of its life and ripped itself apart
column3: ejecting a superheated cloud of debris in the process. Slamming into the surrounding interstellar gas
column4: this stellar shrapnel gradually diffused into the separate fiery filaments of material seen scattered across this skycap.

29589773702.0;Hubble Takes Close-up Look at Disintegrating Comet;"NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has captured one of the sharpest
column2: most detailed observations of a comet breaking apart
column3: which occurred 67 million miles from Earth. In a series of images taken over a three-day span in January 2016
column4: Hubble revealed 25 building-size blocks made of a mixture of ice and dust that are drifting away from the comet at a leisurely pace.

27747557010.0;Light Echo Illuminates Dust Around Supergiant Star V838 Monocerotis (V838 Mon);""Starry Night
column2: " Vincent van Gogh's famous painting
column3: is renowned for its bold whorls of light sweeping across a raging night sky. Although this image of the heavens came only from the artist's restless imagination
column4: this picture from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope bears remarkable similarities to the van Gogh work
column5: complete with never-before-seen spirals of dust swirling across  trillions of miles of interstellar space.

column1: This image
column2: obtained with the Advanced Camera for Surveys on February 8
column4: shows an expanding halo of light around a distant star
column5: named V838 Monocerotis (V838 Mon). The illumination of interstellar dust comes from the red supergiant star at the middle of the image
column6: which gave off a flashbulb-like pulse of light. V838 Mon is located about 20
column7: 000 light-years away from Earth in the direction of the constellation Monoceros
column8: placing the star at the outer edge of our Milky Way galaxy.

column1: Called a light echo
column2: the expanding illumination of a dusty cloud around the star has been revealing remarkable structures ever since the star suddenly brightened for several weeks in early 2002. Though Hubble has followed the light echo in several snapshots
column3: this new image shows swirls or eddies in the dusty cloud for the first time. These eddies are probably caused by turbulence in the dust and gas around the star as they slowly expand away. The dust and gas were   likely ejected from the star in a previous explosion
column4: similar to   the 2002 event
column5: which occurred some tens of thousands of years ago. The surrounding dust remained invisible and unsuspected until suddenly illuminated by the brilliant explosion of the central star two years ago.

column1: Hubble has imaged V838 Mon and its light echo several  times since the star's outburst in January 2002
column2: in order to follow the constantly changing appearance of the dust as the pulse of illumination continues to expand away from the star at the speed of light. During the outburst event
column3: the normally faint star suddenly brightened
column4: becoming 600
column5: 000 times more luminous than our Sun. It was thus one of the brightest stars in the entire Milky Way
column6: until it faded away again in April 2002. The star has some similarities to a class of objects called "novae
column7: " which suddenly increase in brightness due to thermonuclear explosions at their surfaces; however
column8: the detailed behavior of V838 Mon
column9: in particular its extremely red color
column10: has been completely different from any  previously known nova.

column1: Nature's own piece of performance art
column2: this structure will continue to change its appearance in coming years as the light from the stellar outburst continues to propagate outward and bounce off more distant black clouds of dust.

27993269556.0;Veil Nebula Supernova Remnant;"NASA's Hubble Space Telescope unveiled in stunning detail a small section of the expanding remains of a massive star that exploded about 8
column2: 000 years ago.

column1: Called the Veil Nebula
column2: the debris is one of the best-known supernova remnants
column3: deriving its name from its delicate
column4: draped filamentary structures. The entire nebula is 110 light-years across
column5: covering six full moons on the sky as seen from Earth
column6: and resides about 2
column7: 100 light-years away in the constellation Cygnus
column8: the Swan.

column1: This view is a mosaic of six Hubble pictures of a small area roughly two light-years across
column2: covering only a tiny fraction of the nebula's vast structure.

column1: This close-up look unveils wisps of gas
column2: which are all that remain of what was once a star 20 times more massive than our Sun. The fast-moving blast wave from the ancient explosion is plowing into a wall of cool
column3: denser interstellar gas
column4: emitting light. The nebula lies along the edge of a large bubble of low-density gas that was blown into space by the dying star prior to its self-detonation.

column1: The image shows an incredible array of structures and detail from the collision between the blast wave and the gas and dust that make up the cavity wall. The nebula resembles a crumpled bed sheet viewed from the side. The bright regions are where the shock wave is encountering relatively dense material or where the "bed sheet" ripples are viewed edge on.
In this image
column2: red corresponds to the glow of hydrogen
column3: green from sulfur
column4: and blue from oxygen. The bluish features
column5: outlining the cavity wall
column6: appear smooth and arched in comparison to the fluffy green and red structures. The red glow is from cooler gas that was excited by the shock collision at an earlier time and has subsequently diffused into a more chaotic structure. A few thin
column7: crisp-looking
column8: red filaments arise after gas is swept into the shock wave at speeds of nearly 1 million miles an hour
column9: so fast that it could travel from Earth to the moon in 15 minutes.

column1: Astronomers are comparing these images to images taken by Hubble in 1997. This comparison allows scientists to study how the nebula has expanded since it was originally photographed. The supernova that created the Veil Nebula would have been briefly visible to our very distant ancestors about 8
column2: 000 years ago as a bright "new star" in the northern sky.

27414184023.0;The Antennae Galaxies/NGC 4038-4039;"This NASA Hubble Space Telescope image of the Antennae galaxies is the sharpest yet of this merging pair of galaxies. During the course of the collision
column2: billions of stars will be formed. The brightest and most compact of these star birth regions are called super star clusters.

column1: The two spiral galaxies started to interact a few hundred million years ago
column2: making the Antennae galaxies one of the nearest and youngest examples of a pair of colliding galaxies. Nearly half of the faint objects in the Antennae image are young clusters containing tens of thousands of stars. The orange blobs to the left and right of image center are the two cores of the original galaxies and consist mainly of old stars criss-crossed by filaments of dust
column3: which appears brown in the image. The two galaxies are dotted with brilliant blue star-forming regions surrounded by glowing hydrogen gas
column4: appearing in the image in pink.

column1: The new image allows astronomers to better distinguish between the stars and super star clusters created in the collision of two spiral galaxies. By age dating the clusters in the image
column2: astronomers find that only about 10 percent of the newly formed super star clusters in the Antennae will survive beyond the first 10 million years. The vast majority of the super star clusters formed during this interaction will disperse
column3: with the individual stars becoming part of the smooth background of the galaxy. It is however believed that about a hundred of the most massive clusters will survive to form regular globular clusters
column4: similar to the globular clusters found in our own Milky Way galaxy.

column1: The Antennae galaxies take their name from the long antenna-like "arms" extending far out from the nuclei of the two galaxies
column2: best seen by ground-based telescopes. These "tidal tails" were formed during the initial encounter of the galaxies some 200 to 300 million years ago. They give us a preview of what may happen when our Milky Way galaxy will collide with the neighboring Andromeda galaxy in several billion years.

40842984281.0;M110;"Located in the constellation Andromeda
column2: M110 was discovered in 1773 by Charles Messier. It is a satellite galaxy of the Andromeda galaxy (M31) and a member of the Local Group
column3: which is made up of the galaxies located closest to the Milky Way (our Milky Way is considered a member of the Local Group as well). M110 is approximately 2
column5: 000 light-years away from Earth and has a magnitude of 8.

column1: M110 is an elliptical galaxy
column2: which means that it has a smooth and nearly featureless structure. Elliptical galaxies do not have arms or regions of star formation. They are oftentimes considered "dead" compared to spiral galaxies
column3: and the stars in elliptical galaxies are often older than those in other galaxies. However
column4: there is evidence that a population of young blue stars exists at the center of M110. This small elliptical galaxy has approximately 10 billion stars
column5: as well as at least eight globular clusters (the brightest of which can be seen with large telescopes).

column1: This Hubble observation was taken in visible and near-infrared light with the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2. The core of M110 is seen toward the lower right of the image
column2: with the galaxy's globular clusters and numerous stars shown as points of light throughout the frame. Also featured in this Hubble image are large clouds of gas and dust
column3: seen as dark splotches (one large region is located near the middle of the image and another
column4: smaller one appears above the galaxy's core). Hubble took these observations of M110 to study the development of globular clusters located in the galaxy.

column1: With a telescope
column2: M110 is fairly easy to spot near the core of the much larger and brighter Andromeda galaxy. Smaller telescopes will only reveal a faint
column3: diffuse patch of light
column4: while larger telescopes will unveil an oval shape with a brighter core. The best time to view M110 is during November.

column1: 36236078681.0;The Hockey Stick Galaxy;"The star of this Hubble image is a galaxy known as NGC 4656
column2: located in the constellation of Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs). However
column3: it also has a somewhat more interesting and intriguing name: the Hockey Stick Galaxy! The reason for this is a little unclear from this partial view
column4: which shows the bright central region
column5: but the galaxy is actually shaped like an elongated
column6: warped stick
column7: stretching out through space until it curls around at one end to form a striking imitation of a celestial hockey stick.

column1: This unusual shape is thought to be due to an interaction between NGC 4656 and a couple of near neighbors
column2: NGC 4631 (otherwise known as the Whale Galaxy) and NGC 4627 (a small elliptical). Galactic interactions can completely reshape a celestial object
column3: shifting and warping its constituent gas
column4: stars
column5: and dust into bizarre and beautiful configurations. The Hubble Space Telescope has spied a large number of interacting galaxies over the years
column6: from the cosmic rose of Arp 273 to the egg-penguin duo of Arp 142 and the pinwheel swirls of Arp 240. More Hubble images of interacting galaxies can be seen here.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/a5d537fd03d36c2550a02b45d32145b1;2017-01-24;976.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36236078681/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4656

column1: 27991868946.0;Space Shuttle Atlantis on Launch Pad;"Space shuttle Atlantis sits on Launch Pad 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida after its rollout from the Vehicle Assembly Building. The shuttle sits atop the mobile launcher platform
column2: which is carried by the crawler-transporter beneath. At left is the rotating service structure with the payload changeout room that allows transfer of payloads from a canister into the shuttle's payload bay. Next to the shuttle is the fixed service structure with its 80-foot lightning mast on top.

column1: Atlantis lifted off on May 11
column3: to service NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. During Atlantis' 12-day mission
column4: its crew of seven astronauts made the final shuttle flight to Hubble. During five spacewalks
column5: they installed two new instruments
column6: repaired two inactive ones and replaced other components. This resulted in six working
column7: complementary science instruments with capabilities beyond what was previously available
column8: and extended the operational lifespan for the telescope.

column1: 27414177593.0;The Sombrero Galaxy;"Resembling a wide-brimmed hat with a tall bulge at the center
column2: galaxy M104 is nicknamed the Sombrero Galaxy. Far larger than any hat on Earth
column3: this Sombrero is 50
column4: 000 light-years wide. We see the galaxy nearly edge-on
column5: so the dark dust in its pancake-like disk appears to bisect a large
column6: white
column7: rounded core of stars. Roughly 29 million light-years away
column8: the Sombrero can be spotted with a modest telescope in the constellation Virgo.

column1: Using Hubble
column2: a team of astronomers led by John Kormendy of the University of Hawaii found evidence of a supermassive black hole at the center of the Sombrero Galaxy. Estimated to be as massive as a billion Suns
column3: it's one of the heftiest black holes in the neighboring universe.

column1: Hubble observations also reveal that the Sombrero Galaxy includes nearly 2
column2: 000 globular clusters — 10 times more than in our galaxy. Globular clusters are giant
column3: spherical-shaped groups of stars that are sometimes older than the galaxy in which they reside. The Sombrero's globular clusters range from 10 billion to 13 billion years old
column4: similar to those in the Milky Way.

column1: Several teams of astronomers have used Hubble and telescopes on the ground to study the Sombrero's globular clusters. They've found that some clusters are rich in elements heavier than helium (which astronomers call "metals") and some are poor. Among other findings
column2: the observations reveal that the "metal-rich" clusters are concentrated in the galaxy's bulge and that they are typically smaller than the "metal-poor" ones. Such studies are helping astronomers figure out how ancient globular clusters developed early in the universe's history.

27993301006.0;Hubble Frontier Field Abell 2744;"This long-exposure Hubble Space Telescope image of massive galaxy cluster  Abell 2744 is the deepest ever made of any cluster of galaxies. It shows some of  the faintest and youngest galaxies ever detected in space. Abell 2744
column2: located in  the constellation Sculptor
column3: appears in the foreground of this image. It contains  several hundred galaxies as they looked 3.5 billion years ago. The immense  gravity in Abell 2744 acts as a gravitational lens to warp space and brighten and  magnify images of nearly 3
column4: 000 distant background galaxies. The more distant  galaxies appear as they did longer than 12 billion years ago
column5: not long after the big bang.

column1: This image is part of an unprecedented long-distance view of the universe from an ambitious collaborative project among the NASA Great Observatories called the Frontier Fields. As part of the project
column2: select patches of the sky were photographed for the purpose of better understanding galaxy evolution. This visible-light and near-infrared composite image was taken with the Wide Field Camera 3.

column1: 27414046424.0;Stephan's Quintet;"This portrait of Stephan's Quintet
column2: also known as Hickson Compact Group 92
column3: was taken by NASA's Hubble Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3). Stephan's Quintet
column4: as the name implies
column5: is a group of five galaxies. However
column6: studies have shown that group member NGC 7320
column7: at upper left
column8: is actually a foreground galaxy about 40 million light-years from Earth. The other members of the quintet reside 290 million light-years away.

column1: Three of the galaxies have distorted shapes
column2: elongated spiral arms
column3: and long
column4: gaseous tidal tails containing myriad star clusters
column5: proof of their close encounters. These interactions have sparked a frenzy of star birth in the central pair of galaxies. This drama is being played out against a rich backdrop of faraway galaxies.

column1: The galaxy group Stephan's Quintet is located in the constellation Pegasus.

27139939569.0;Explosive tendencies;"Don’t be fooled! ESO 580-49
column2: may seem tranquil and unassuming
column3: but this spiral galaxy actually displays some explosive tendencies.

column1: In October of 2011
column2: a cataclysmic burst of high-energy gamma-ray radiation — known as a gamma-ray burst
column3: or GRB — was detected coming from the region of sky containing ESO 580-49. Astronomers believe that the galaxy was the host of the GRB
column4: given that the chance of a coincidental alignment between the two is roughly 1 in 10 million. At a distance of around 185 million light-years from Earth
column5: it was the second-closest gamma-ray burst (GRB) ever detected.

column1: Gamma-ray bursts are among the brightest events in the cosmos
column2: occasionally outshining the combined gamma-ray output of the entire observable Universe for a few seconds. The exact cause of the GRB that probably occurred within this galaxy
column3: cataloged as GRB 111005A
column4: remains a mystery. Several events are known to lead to GRBs
column5: but none of these explanations appear to fit the bill in this case. Astronomers have therefore suggested that ESO 580-49 hosted a new type of GRB explosion — one that has not yet been characterised.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/b719ff6940e00bd8d70022084d4270ec;2017-12-04;728.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27139939569/in/album-72157667717916600;eso58049

column1: 27946393571.0;Gregory J. Harbaugh;Close-up of Gregory J. Harbaugh during EVA.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/fc3d40fc894a956b7c3196c429d6a701;2016-07-01;1024.0;1536.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 2;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27946393571/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission servicingmission2 sts82
28170254574.0;Decades of Discovery: NASA’s Exploration of Jupiter;"Launched on Aug. 5
column3: NASA’s Juno mission maneuvered into orbit around Jupiter on July 4
column5: joining a long tradition of discovery at the gas giant.

column1: One of the brightest objects in the night sky
column2: Jupiter has enthralled humans since ancient times. Today
column3: scientists believe that learning more about the planet may be the key to discovering our solar system’s origins and formation. They theorize that Jupiter didn’t always rest where it is now
column4: but that it moved throughout the solar system in its youth
column5: disrupting the formation of Mars
column6: influencing the formation and location of the asteroid belt
column7: and more.

column1: Scientists began to use space missions to unlock the planet’s secrets in the early 1970s when Juno’s earliest ancestors
column2: Pioneer 10 and 11
column3: launched. The pair of spacecraft reached the planet in late 1973 and early 1974. For the first time ever
column4: scientists could obtain direct observations and close-up images of Jupiter
column5: its moons
column6: and the mysterious Great Red Spot.

column1: From Pioneer’s findings
column2: scientists were able to make numerous conclusions about Jupiter. They found that the planet is composed mostly of liquid
column3: and that it has a magnetotail
column4: an extension of its magnetic field
column5: like Earth. This hinted at Jupiter’s composition and the possibility of a solid core. They also got a close look at Jupiter’s clouds – from 26
column6: 000 miles (about 42
column7: 000 km) – to determine weather patterns.

column1: The Pioneer missions paved the way for a second set of Jupiter-focused missions in the late 1970s
column2: Voyager 1 and 2. Launched in 1977
column3: the spacecraft are most famous for traversing to the outermost portion of the solar system – Voyager 1 has even passed its outer limits and has now passed into the space between solar systems. In time
column4: Voyager 2 and the Pioneer missions will also leave the solar system. The Voyager pair flew past Jupiter in 1979
column5: taking more than 52
column6: 000 photos of the planet and its moons over the course of several months.

column1: These images and accompanying observations sparked seemingly countless new discoveries. The data revealed many features of the weather on Jupiter
column2: including the existence of lightning in the cloud tops and of hurricane-like storm systems. Plus
column3: for the first time
column4: scientists discovered the existence of active volcanoes elsewhere than Earth
column5: on the planet’s moon Io.

column1: The Galileo missions to Jupiter followed in the late 1980s. Unlike previous missions
column2: this set of spacecraft – an atmospheric probe and an orbiter – were designed to orbit the planet rather than collect data on flyby. The probe was the first spacecraft to directly measure characteristics of Jupiter’s atmosphere – descending 95 miles (153 kilometers) into it before melting and vaporizing from the extreme heat. The probe passed 58 minutes of atmospheric data to the orbiter
column3: which then transmitted it back to Earth. The data included measurements of Jupiter’s atmospheric elements and showed that their abundance differed from that of the Sun
column4: providing insight into the planet’s formation.

column1: The orbiter itself made numerous long-term observations about the Jupiter system
column2: including finding evidence to support the theory that an ocean of water lies under the surface of the moon Europa and finding Jupiter’s ring system
column3: a nearly invisible set of rings composed of dust created by meteoroid impacts with the planet’s four moons. In July 1994
column4: Galileo also witnessed the collision of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 with Jupiter
column5: the first observation of such an impact as it occurred on any planet besides Earth.

column1: The Ulysses mission to study the Sun collected data on Jupiter’s magnetosphere while the planet provided a gravitational assist to change the spacecraft’s trajectory in 1992. The Cassini spacecraft also observed Jupiter in 2000 on its way to its target destination
column2: Saturn. Cassini’s camera took 26
column3: 000 images of the planet and its moons and created the most detailed global color portrait of Jupiter ever produced at the time.

column1: More recently
column2: New Horizons
column3: a mission to Pluto
column4: added to these observations during its flyby of Jupiter in 2007
column5: finding the planet changed since previous looks by NASA – the Galileo spacecraft burned up in Jupiter’s atmosphere in fall 2003. New Horizons spent about six months observing the Jupiter planet system during its flyby on the way to Pluto
column6: further exploring its weather systems
column7: moons and rings. Perhaps most notably
column8: New Horizons saw about 36 volcanoes on Io and measured the temperature of lava
column9: finding it similar to that of Earth-based volcanoes.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope has made multiple observations and taken numerous photos of Jupiter since its launch in April 1990. Hubble’s observations of the planet stretch over 26 years
column2: and many of its observations are concurrent with other Jupiter missions
column3: particularly Galileo. In fact
column4: Hubble also witnessed the collision of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 with Jupiter
column5: providing another perspective of the impact sites. Hubble’s observations of the gas giant have continued to the present day. In October 2015
column6: Hubble photos showed changes in Jupiter’s Great Red Spot
column7: and in June 2016
column8: Hubble took awe-inspiring photos of auroras on the planet’s poles. Hubble’s observations of the solar system and the wider universe are expected to continue through 2020 and beyond.

column1: Since Juno’s successful orbit insertion at Jupiter in July 2016
column2: NASA has already released several images taken of the planet by the JunoCam camera. Juno will make observations about Jupiter’s atmosphere and magnetic and gravitational fields
column3: providing more information about the planet’s structure so scientists can deepen their understanding of Jupiter’s origin and evolution. Any of these clues could begin to unravel the mystery of the solar system’s origins and formation.

column1: 28101382881.0;STS-125 MS5 Feustel during EVA3;Astronaut Andrew Feustel
column2: STS-125 mission specialist
column3: positioned on the Manipulator Foot Restraint (MFR) on the end of Atlantis' remote manipulator system (RMS)
column4: participates in the mission's third session of extravehicular activity (EVA3) as work continued to refurbish and upgrade the Hubble Space Telescope. During the six-hour
column5: 36-minute spacewalk
column6: Feustel and astronaut John Grunsfeld (out of frame) removed the Corrective Optics Space Telescope Axial Replacement and installed in its place the new Cosmic Origins Spectrograph. They also completed the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) electronic card replacement work
column7: and completed part 2 of the ACS repair
column8: installing a new electronics box and cable.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/d686005c18aee251cd9089e31c480933;2009-05-16;1993.0;3000.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28101382881/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission shuttlemission spaceshuttle astronaut eva extravehicularactivity spacewalk spaceshuttleatlantis

27411458454.0;Astronaut Kent V. Rominger and LeRoy Cain;Astronaut Kent V. Rominger (seated)
column2: and LeRoy Cain are photographed at the Mission Operation Directorate (MOD) console in the shuttle flight control room (WFCR) in Houston's Mission Control Center (MCC). Several hundred miles away in Florida
column3: the STS-109 crewmembers were awaiting countdown in the crew cabin of the Space Shuttle Columbia on the launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center (KSC). As soon as the vehicle cleared the tower in Florida
column4: the Houston-based team of flight controllers took over the ground control of the mission. Rominger is the Deputy Director of the Flight Crew Operations Directorate (FCOD) and was the STS-109 FCOD management representative in the MCC. Cain was the Weather Flight Director for the mission’s ascent phase
column5: coordinating weather issues for lead Ascent Flight Director John Shannon (out of frame).;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/841380172bd4a8d8cdd0bb63bc6fb519;2016-07-01;1152.0;1728.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27411458454/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109

column1: 27990736686.0;Space Shuttle Columbia Liftoff;The Space Shuttle Columbia begins its 27th flight in the pre-dawn hours from Launch Pad 39A. Liftoff for STS-109 occurred at 6:22:02:08 a.m.
column2: EST (11:22:02:08 GMT) on March 1
column3: 2002. The goal of the mission is the maintenance and upgrade of the Hubble Space Telescope
column4: to be carried out in five space walks. On board the spacecraft were astronauts Scott D. Altman
column5: Duane G. Carey
column6: Nancy J. Currie
column7: John M. Grunsfeld
column8: James H. Newman
column9: Richard M. Linnehan

column1: 35256336063.0;Hubble Anchor Guide Studs on Display at NASA Social;"The Hubble Space Telescope and the International Space Station are the only two artificial satellites designed to be repaired in space. The Anchor Guide Studs provided a mechanical interface to install repair tools and were displayed for NASA's social media followers.
More than 40 of NASA's followers on social media traveled from across the country to attend a NASA Social event on April 23
column3: in celebration of the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope. The day-long event began by attending the unveiling of a 25th anniversary image at a NASA press conference at the Newseum in Washington
column4: DC. The participants then traveled to NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center where they took part in behind-the-scenes tours of different laboratories
column5: ending with a viewing of the Hubble control center and a hands-on demonstration of the tools used during the Hubble servicing missions.

column1: Credit: NASA/Goddard/Debbie Mccallum

column1: 36347322021.0;M65;"M65 is a spiral galaxy with an apparent magnitude of 10.3. Charles Messier discovered it and its neighbor M66 on the same night in 1780. Located roughly 35 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Leo
column2: M65 is a member of the Leo Triplet of galaxies. It can be spotted with a small telescope in the same field of view as the other members of the triplet (M66 and NGC 3628). The best time to observe M65 is in April.

column1: This image of M65’s center is a composite created using exposures taken with Hubble at both visible and infrared wavelengths. Its stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera used to take the exposures. The camera consisted of four light detectors
column2: one of which provided a higher resolution but had a smaller field of view than the other three. Because the detector with the higher resolution did not cover as much area as the others
column3: black regions remain when the images from all four detectors are combined into one picture.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M65
column2: see:

27712252513.0;Hubble Space Telescope Concept;"This is an artist's concept of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). Hubble is the product of a partnership between NASA
column2: the European Space Agency
column3: contractors
column4: and the international community of astronomers. It is named after Edwin P. Hubble
column5: an American astronomer who discovered the expanding nature of the universe and was the first to realize the true nature of galaxies.

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column3: is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit. By placing the telescope in space
column4: astronomers are able to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble detects objects 25 times fainter than the dimmest objects seen from Earth and provides astronomers with an observable universe 250 times larger than is visible from ground-based telescopes
column5: extending our view more than 13 billion light-years away. Hubble views galaxies
column6: stars
column7: planets
column8: comets
column9: planet formation in other solar systems
column10: and even unusual phenomena such as quasars
column11: with 10 times the clarity of ground-based telescopes.

column1: The major elements of Hubble are the Optical Telescope Assembly (OTA)
column2: the Support System Module (SSM)
column3: and the Scientific Instruments (SI). Hubble is approximately the size of a railroad car
column4: with two cylinders joined together and wrapped in a silvery reflective heat shield blanket. Wing-like solar arrays extend horizontally from each side of these cylinders
column5: and dish-shaped anternas extend above and below the body of the telescope.  Hubble was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery (STS-31 mission) into Earth orbit in April 1990.

column1: The Marshall Space Flight Center had responsibility for design
column2: development
column3: and construction of the observatory. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury
column4: Connecticut
column5: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. The Lockheed Missile and Space Company of Sunnyvale
column6: California
column7: produced the protective outer shroud and spacecraft systems
column8: and assembled and tested the finished telescope.

27712252203.0;Hubble Space Telescope;"This image illustrates the Hubble Space Telescope's Optical Telescope Assembly (OTA). One of the spacecraft's three major elements
column2: the OTA consists of two mirrors (a primary mirror and a secondary mirror)
column3: support trusses
column4: and the focal plane structure.

column1: The mirrors collect and focus light from selected celestial objects and are housed near the center of the telescope. The primary mirror captures light from objects in space and focuses it toward the secondary mirror. The secondary mirror redirects the light to a focal plane where the scientific instruments are located. The primary mirror is 94.5 inches (2.4 meters) in diameter
column2: and the secondary mirror is 12.2 inches (0.3 meters) in diameter.

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made

column5: extending our view more than 13 billion light-years away. Hubble views galaxies
column6: stars
column7: planets
column8: comets
column9: planet formation in other solar systems
column10: and even unusual phenomena such as quasars
column11: with 10 times the clarity of ground-based telescopes.

column2: Wide Field and Planetary Camera;"In this photograph
column3: engineers and technicians prepare the Hubble Space Telescope's Wide Field and Planetary Camera (WF/PC) for installation at the Lockheed Missile and Space Company. The WF/PC was designed to investigate the age of the universe and to search for new planetary systems around young stars. It was designed to take pictures of large numbers of galaxies and close-ups of planets in our solar system.

column1: Hubble was the first of NASA's great observatories and the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made. The purpose of Hubble is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit by placing the telescope in space

27950259781.0;Jupiter (April 21
column2: 2014);"Jupiter's monster storm
column3: the Great Red Spot
column4: was once so large that three Earths would fit inside it. But measurements by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope reveal that the largest storm in our solar system has downsized significantly. The red spot
column5: which has been raging for at least a hundred years
column6: is only the width of one Earth. What is happening? One possibility is that some unknown activity in the planet's atmosphere may be draining energy and weakening the storm
column7: causing it to shrink.

column1: 36436761996.0;M12;"M12 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. The globular cluster is located 23
column2: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Ophiuchus. It has an apparent magnitude of 7.7 and can be observed with a pair of binoculars most easily in July.

column1: Because globular clusters like M12 have such high concentrations of stars
column2: they often contain binary star systems — systems of two stars that are locked in orbit around each other. As the stars interact
column3: material from one star can be transferred to its companion
column4: producing X-rays in the process. These X-rays serve as a signature of interacting binary systems
column5: and many have been detected in M12. This is unexpected because M12 is a relatively diffuse globular cluster
column6: so stars should be less likely to interact than if they were in clusters with a higher concentration of stars.

column1: M12 also has fewer low-mass stars than expected. Astronomers suspect that gravity has ripped many low-mass stars from M12 as the cluster passed through denser regions of the Milky Way during its orbit around the galaxy’s center. M12 is thought to have lost up to one million stars this way.
Hubble’s image of M12’s center was taken using both visible and infrared observations.
For more information about Hubble’s observations of M12

column1: 36368249745.0;M1;"Peering deep into M1
column2: this spectacular Hubble image captures the nebula’s beating heart: the rapidly spinning pulsar at its core. Bright wisps are moving outward from the pulsar (the rightmost of the two bright stars near the center of the image) at half the speed of light to form an expanding ring. These wisps form along magnetic field lines in a gas of extremely energetic particles driven into space by the highly magnetized
column3: rapidly rotating neutron star.

Presumably one of these stars is the source of the nova; though it is also possible that the nova-producing star is too faint to be seen.

column1: 27744106100.0;Hubble Space Telescope;The Hubble Space Telescope (HST) floats gracefully above the blue Earth after release from Discovery’s robot arm after a successful servicing mission. The event marks the fourth time in history that a Space Shuttle has released the great observatory. Those occasions were the initial release in 1990 and three subsequent servicing missions including STS-103.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/9ae6276d8cbe32d3268a1679989fe604;2016-07-01;2032.0;2043.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3A;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27744106100/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission3a sts103
35632767684.0;M81;"Discovered by the German astronomer Johann Elert Bode in 1774
column2: M81 is one of the brightest galaxies in the night sky. It is located 11.6 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Ursa Major and has an apparent magnitude of 6.9. Through a pair of binoculars
column3: the galaxy appears as a faint patch of light in the same field of view as M82. A small telescope will resolve M81’s core. The galaxy is best observed during April.

column1: This stunning Hubble image was assembled using observations in visible and infrared light. The galaxy’s spiral arms
column2: which wind all the way down into its nucleus
column3: are made up of young
column4: bluish
column5: hot stars formed in the past few million years. They also host a population of stars formed in an episode of star formation that started about 600 million years ago. Ultraviolet light from hot
column6: young stars is fluorescing the surrounding clouds of hydrogen gas. A number of sinuous dust lanes also wind all the way into the nucleus of M81.

column1: The galaxy’s central bulge contains much older
column2: redder stars. It is significantly larger than the Milky Way’s bulge. A black hole of 70 million solar masses resides at the center of M81 and is about 15 times the mass of the Milky Way’s central black hole. Previous Hubble research showed that the size of the black hole in a galaxy’s nucleus is proportional to the mass of the galaxy’s bulge.
