column1: 27747573280.0;The Carina Nebula: Star Birth in the Extreme;"In celebration of the 17th anniversary of the launch and deployment of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope
column2: a team of astronomers released one of the largest panoramic images ever taken with Hubble's cameras. It is a 50-light-year-wide view of the central region of the Carina Nebula where a maelstrom of star birth - and death - is taking place.

column1: Hubble's view of the nebula shows star birth in a new level of detail. The fantasy-like landscape of the nebula is sculpted by the action of outflowing winds and scorching ultraviolet radiation from the monster stars that inhabit this inferno. In the process
column2: these stars are shredding the surrounding material that is the last vestige of the giant cloud from which the stars were born.

column1: The immense nebula contains at least a dozen brilliant stars that are roughly estimated to be at least 50 to 100 times the mass of our Sun. The most unique and opulent inhabitant is the star Eta Carinae
column2: at far left. Eta Carinae is in the final stages of its brief and eruptive lifespan
column3: as evidenced by two billowing lobes of gas and dust that presage its upcoming explosion as a titanic supernova.

column1: The fireworks in the Carina region started three million years ago when the nebula's first generation of newborn stars condensed and ignited in the middle of a huge cloud of cold molecular hydrogen. Radiation from these stars carved out an expanding bubble of hot gas. The island-like clumps of dark clouds scattered across the nebula are nodules of dust and gas that are resisting being eaten away by photoionization.

The hurricane blast of stellar winds and blistering ultraviolet radiation within the cavity is now compressing the surrounding walls of cold hydrogen. This is triggering a second stage of new star formation.

Our Sun and our solar system may have been born inside such a cosmic crucible 4.6 billion years ago. In looking at the Carina Nebula we are seeing the genesis of star making as it commonly occurs along the dense spiral arms of a galaxy.
The immense nebula is an estimated 7
column2: 500 light-years away in the southern constellation Carina the Keel (of the old southern constellation Argo Navis
column3: the ship of Jason and the Argonauts
column4: from Greek mythology).

column1: This image is a mosaic of the Carina Nebula assembled from 48 frames taken with Hubble Space Telescope's Advanced Camera for Surveys. The Hubble images were taken in the light of neutral hydrogen. Color information was added with data taken at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile. Red corresponds to sulfur
column2: green to hydrogen
column3: and blue to oxygen emission.

column1: 33129240364.0;Alien aurorae on Uranus;"Ever since Voyager 2 beamed home spectacular images of the planets in the 1980s
column2: planet-lovers have been hooked on extra-terrestrial aurorae. Aurorae are caused by streams of charged particles like electrons that come from various origins such as solar winds
column3: the planetary ionosphere
column4: and moon volcanism. They become caught in powerful magnetic fields and are channeled into the upper atmosphere
column5: where their interactions with gas particles
column6: such as oxygen or nitrogen
column7: set off spectacular bursts of light.

column1: The alien aurorae on Jupiter and Saturn are well studied
column2: but not much is known about the aurorae of the giant ice planet Uranus. In 2011
column3: the Hubble Space Telescope became the first Earth-based telescope to snap an image of the aurorae on Uranus.

column1: In 2012 and 2014 astronomers took a second look at the aurorae using the ultraviolet capabilities of the Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS) installed on Hubble. They tracked the interplanetary shocks caused by two powerful bursts of solar wind travelling from the Sun to Uranus
column2: then used Hubble to capture their effect on Uranus’ aurorae — and found themselves observing the most intense aurorae ever seen on the planet. By watching the aurorae over time
column3: they collected the first direct evidence that these powerful shimmering regions rotate with the planet. They also re-discovered Uranus’ long-lost magnetic poles
column4: which were lost shortly after their discovery by Voyager 2 in 1986 due to uncertainties in measurements and the featureless planet surface.

column1: This is a composite image of Uranus by Voyager 2 and two different observations made by Hubble — one for the ring and one for the aurorae.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/b34d58ad9041befaad6b94b8252245d6;2017-03-30;881.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33129240364/in/album-72157667717916600;uranus
36734402865.0;A distorted duo;"Gravity governs the movements of the cosmos. It draws flocks of galaxies together to form small groups and more massive galaxy clusters
column2: and brings duos so close that they begin to tug at one another. This latter scenario can have extreme consequences
column3: with members of interacting pairs of galaxies often being dramatically distorted
column4: torn apart
column5: or driven to smash into one another
column6: abandoning their former identities and merging to form a single accumulation of gas
column7: dust
column8: and stars.

column1: The subject of this Hubble Space Telescope image
column3: is currently interacting with its near neighbor
column4: NGC 672 (which is just out of frame). The pair’s interactions have triggered peculiar and intriguing phenomena within both objects — most noticeably in IC 1727. The galaxy’s structure is visibly twisted and asymmetric
column5: and its bright nucleus has been dragged off-center.

column1: In interacting galaxies such as these
column2: astronomers often see signs of intense star formation (in episodic flurries known as starbursts) and spot newly formed star clusters. They are thought to be caused by gravity churning
column3: redistributing
column4: and compacting the gas and dust. In fact
column5: astronomers have analyzed the star formation within IC 1727 and NGC 672 and discovered something interesting — observations show that simultaneous bursts of star formation occurred in both galaxies some 20 to 30 million and 450 to 750 million years ago. The most likely explanation for this is that the galaxies are indeed an interacting pair
column6: approaching each other every so often and swirling up gas and dust as they pass close by.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/1c8560db918796826743c46ff0aca60a;2017-03-13;781.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36734402865/in/album-72157667717916600;ic1727 ugc1249

column1: 24116308448.0;Cosmic archaeology;"This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image is chock-full of galaxies — each glowing speck is a different galaxy
column2: bar the bright flash in the middle of the image which is actually a star lying within our own galaxy that just happened to be in the way. At the center of the image lies something especially interesting
column3: the center of the massive galaxy cluster called WHL J24.3324-8.477
column4: including the brightest galaxy of the cluster.

column1: The Universe contains structures on various scales — planets collect around stars
column2: stars collect into galaxies
column3: galaxies collect into groups
column4: and galaxy groups collect into clusters. Galaxy clusters contain hundreds to thousands of galaxies bound together by gravity. Dark matter and dark energy play key roles in the formation and evolution of these clusters
column5: so studying massive galaxy clusters can help scientists to unravel the mysteries of these elusive phenomena.

column1: This infrared image was taken by Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys and Wide-Field Camera 3 as part of an observing programme called RELICS (Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey). RELICS imaged 41 massive galaxy clusters with the aim of finding the brightest distant galaxies for the forthcoming NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to study. Such research will tell us more about our cosmic origins.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/0f6c294a955a10a792bcf72bc297ed51;2017-06-09;980.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/24116308448/in/album-72157667717916600;whlj2433248477

40011721022.0;Standout stars;This image from the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope reveals a glistening and ancient globular cluster named NGC 3201 — a gathering of hundreds of thousands of stars bound together by gravity. NGC 3201 was discovered in 1826 by the Scottish astronomer James Dunlop
column2: who described it as a “pretty large
column3: pretty bright” object that becomes “rather irregular” towards its centre. Globular clusters are found around all large galaxies
column4: but their origin and role in galaxy formation remain tantalisingly unclear. Astronomers recently discovered a black hole lurking at the heart of NGC 3201 — its position was revealed by the strange movements of a star being quickly flung around a massive
column5: invisible counterpart. This sparkling group of stars also has some strange properties which make it unique amongst the over 150 globular clusters belonging to the Milky Way. NGC 3201 has an extremely fast velocity with respect to the Sun and its orbit is retrograde
column6: meaning that it moves speedily in the opposite direction to the galactic center
column7: which it orbits. The unusual behavior of this cluster suggests that it may have extragalactic origins
column8: but at some point was captured by the Milky Way’s gravity. However
column9: the chemical makeup of this intriguing cluster tells a different story — the stars within NGC 3201 are chemically very similar to those of other galactic globular clusters
column10: implying that they formed at a similar location and time to their neighbours. Whether this mysterious cluster was adopted by our galaxy or has for some reason evolved very differently to the family of clusters it grew up with
column11: it is certainly an unusual astronomical beauty. Acknowledgement: Sarajedini et al.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/9c38841037ba3d5ef75e2c6fed777bd0;2018-01-22;1075.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/40011721022/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc3201

column1: 25430827647.0;A window into the cosmic past;This image from Hubble shows the galaxy cluster PLCK G004.5-19.5. It was discovered by the ESA Planck satellite through the Sunyaev-Zel’dovich effect —  the distortion of the cosmic microwave background radiation in the direction of the galaxy cluster
column2: by high energy electrons in the intracluster gas. The large galaxy at the center is the brightest galaxy in the cluster and the dominant object in this image
column3: and above it a thin
column4: curved gravitational lens arc is visible. This is caused by the gravitational forces of the cluster bending the light from stars and galaxies behind it
column5: in a similar way to how a glass lens bends light. Several stars are visible in front of the cluster — recognizable by their diffraction spikes — but aside from these
column6: all other visible objects are distant galaxies. Their light has become redshifted by the expansion of space
column7: making them appear redder than they actually are. By measuring the amount of redshift
column8: we know that it took more than 5 billion years for the light from this galaxy cluster to reach us. The light of the galaxies in the background had to travel for even longer than that
column9: making this image an extremely old window into the far reaches of the Universe. This image was taken by Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) and Wide-Field Camera 3 (WFC3) as part of an observing program called RELICS (Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey). RELICS imaged 41 massive galaxy clusters with the aim of finding the brightest distant galaxies for the forthcoming NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to study.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/5a371258bd28bbc9cb38ad027103f469;2018-01-25;892.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/25430827647/in/album-72157667717916600;plckg0045195

column1: 24610139618.0;Cosmic search for a missing limb;This new Picture of the Week
column2: taken by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope
column3: shows the dwarf galaxy NGC 4625
column4: located about 30 million light-years away in the constellation of Canes Venatici (The Hunting Dogs). The image
column5: acquired with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)
column6: reveals the single spiral arm of the galaxy
column7: which gives it an asymmetric appearance. But why is there only one spiral arm
column8: when spiral galaxies normally have at least two? Astronomers looked at NGC 4625 in different wavelengths in the hope of solving this cosmic mystery. Observations in the ultraviolet provided the first hint: in ultraviolet light the disc of the galaxy appears four times larger than on the image depicted here. An indication that there are a large number of very young and hot — hence mainly visible in the ultraviolet — stars forming in the outer regions of the galaxy. These young stars are only around one billion years old
column9: about 10 times younger than the stars seen in the optical center. At first astronomers assumed that this high star formation rate was being triggered by the interaction with another
column10: nearby dwarf galaxy called NGC 4618. They speculated that NGC 4618 may be the culprit “harassing” NGC 4625
column11: causing it to lose all but one spiral arm. In 2004 astronomers found proof for this claim: The gas in the outermost regions of the dwarf galaxy NGC 4618 has been strongly affected by NGC 4625.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/ff29e75e6225be66a3ab064687c8cb38;2017-06-09;555.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/24610139618/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4625

column1: 35649372244.0;M61;"Discovered in 1779 by the Italian astronomer Barnaba Oriani
column2: M61 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Virgo. Charles Messier noticed it on the same night as Oriani
column3: but he mistook the galaxy for a passing comet. A member of the Virgo Cluster of galaxies
column4: M61 is roughly 55 million light-years away from Earth and has an apparent magnitude of 10.2. It is most easily spotted during the month of May and can be observed using a moderately sized telescope.

column1: M61 is a type of galaxy known as a starburst galaxy. Starburst galaxies experience an incredibly high rate of star formation
column2: hungrily using up their reservoir of gas in a very short period of time (in astronomical terms). But this is not the only activity going on within the galaxy; an X-ray source has been detected deep at its heart
column3: leading astronomers to believe that a supermassive black hole sits at its core. This galaxy has also been host to seven observed supernovas — the most of any galaxy in the Messier catalog.

column1: This Hubble image of M61
column2: created from observations at visible and infrared wavelengths
column3: grants a close look at the face-on galaxy’s structure. The spiral arms can be seen in stunning detail
column4: swirling inward to the very center of the galaxy
column5: where they form a smaller
column6: intensely bright spiral. In the outer regions
column7: these vast arms are sprinkled with bright
column8: blue regions where new stars are being formed from hot
column9: dense clouds of gas.

column1: The image’s stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera used to take the exposures. The camera consisted of four light detectors
column2: one of which provided a higher resolution but had a smaller field of view than the other three. Because the detector with the higher resolution did not cover as much area as the others
column3: black regions were left when the images from all four detectors were combined into one picture.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M61

column1: 36299753382.0;M80;"This stellar swarm is M80
column2: one of the densest of the approximately 150 known globular clusters in the Milky Way galaxy. Located about 28
column3: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Scorpius
column4: the cluster contains hundreds of thousands of stars that are held together by their mutual gravitational attraction. M80 has an apparent magnitude of 7.9 and was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. It can be spotted with a small telescope most easily during July.

column1: M80 is notable for being the site of a nova in the year 1860. Nova outbursts can occur when a close companion star transfers fresh hydrogen fuel to a burned-out white dwarf. Eventually the hydrogen ignites a thermonuclear explosion on the surface of the white dwarf
column2: giving rise to the nova outburst. Hubble’s ultraviolet observations of M80 helped astronomers identify the hot
column3: faint remnant of the nova-producing white dwarf.

column1: Hubble’s examination of M80’s core has also revealed a large population of blue stragglers — stars that appear to be unusually young and more massive than the other stars in a globular cluster. M80 contains more than twice as many of these unusual stars than any other globular cluster surveyed by Hubble.
For more information about Hubble’s observations of M80

36275371792.0;M74;"A stunning face-on spiral galaxy
column2: M74 was discovered in 1780 by Charles Messier’s observing assistant
column3: the French astronomer Pierre Méchain. M74 is located roughly 32 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Pisces. With an apparent magnitude of only 10
column4: the galaxy appears as a faint patch of light through small telescopes. It is best observed during November.

column1: M74 is a perfect example of a grand-design spiral galaxy. Symmetrical spiral arms reach out from the galaxy’s central nucleus and are traced by winding dust lanes. The arms are dotted with clusters of young
column2: blue stars and pink regions where the ultraviolet light from these young stars has ionized clouds of hydrogen and caused them to glow.

column1: This Hubble image of M74 is a composite of exposures taken in 2003 and 2005 at visible and infrared wavelengths. A small segment of this image used data from the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope and the Gemini Observatory to fill in a region that Hubble did not observe.
For more information about Hubble’s observations of M74

36484788505.0;M69;"M69 is one of the most metal-rich globular clusters ever observed. In astronomy
column2: the term “metal” refers to any element heavier than the two most common elements in our universe
column3: hydrogen and helium. The nuclear fusion that powers stars created many of the metallic elements in nature
column4: from the calcium in our bones to the carbon in diamonds. New stars are made from the remains of their predecessors
column5: so ancient globular clusters have much lower metallic abundances than more recently formed stars
column6: such as the sun.

column1: The stars in M69 have over ten times more iron than stars in other globular clusters of the same age. Studying the makeup of stars in globular clusters like M69 has helped astronomers trace back the evolution of star formation in the cosmos.
This cluster was discovered by Charles Messier in 1780. It is located 29
column2: 700 light-years away from Earth in the constellation Sagittarius. M69 has an apparent magnitude of 8.3 and can be spotted with a pair of binoculars most easily in August. This Hubble image of M69’s center is a composite of exposures taken in visible and infrared light.

36365272851.0;M19;"M19 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. The cluster is located 28
column2: 500 light-years from Earth in the constellation Ophiuchus and is most easily observed during July. It has an apparent magnitude of 7.7 and can be spotted through a pair of binoculars
column3: though it will only appear as a faint patch of light. Large telescopes will resolve M19’s individual stars.

column1: The stars in globular clusters orbit about a common center of gravity
column2: so these clusters are usually spherical. Some globular clusters
column3: like M19
column4: have a slightly elongated shape. This cluster is only 6
column5: 500 light-years away from the center of our Milky Way galaxy
column6: so the gravity and tidal forces from the massive galactic center could be causing M19 to stretch out.

column1: This Hubble image of M19 was created using observations of both visible and ultraviolet light. The image’s stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera used to take the exposures. The camera consisted of four light detectors
column2: one of which provided a higher resolution but had a smaller field of view than the other three. Because the detector with the higher resolution did not cover as much area as the others
column3: black regions were left when the images from all four detectors were combined into one picture.

column1: 36300159042.0;M100;"M100 is a stunning example of a grand-design spiral galaxy. This detailed Hubble image reveals individual stars within the galaxy’s prominent spiral arms. column2: including the youngest one ever observed in our cosmic neighborhood.

column1: The galaxy was discovered in 1781 by the French astronomer Pierre Méchain
column2: Charles Messier’s fellow comet hunter who discovered eight comets in his lifetime. M100 is located 56 million light-years away from Earth and appears dim in the night sky. Its apparent magnitude of 10.1 means that
column3: while it can be seen through small telescopes
column4: it will appear only as a faint patch of light. Larger telescopes can resolve more details of this galaxy. M100 is located in the constellation Coma Berenices and is best observed during May.

column1: The image’s stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera used to take the exposures. The camera consisted of four light detectors
column2: one of which provided a higher resolution but had a smaller field of view than the other three. Because the detector with the higher resolution does not cover as much area as the others
column3: black regions remain when the images from all four detectors are combined into one picture.

27747556420.0;A Giant Hubble Mosaic of the Crab Nebula;"This is a mosaic image
column2: one of the largest ever taken by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope of the Crab Nebula
column3: a six-light-year-wide expanding remnant of a star's supernova explosion. Japanese and Chinese astronomers recorded this violent event nearly 1
column4: 000 years ago in 1054
column5: as did
column6: almost certainly
column7: Native Americans.

column1: The orange filaments are the tattered remains of the star and consist mostly of hydrogen. The rapidly spinning neutron star embedded in the center of the nebula is the dynamo powering the nebula's eerie interior bluish glow. The blue light comes from electrons whirling at nearly the speed of light around magnetic field lines from the neutron star. The  neutron star
column2: like a lighthouse
column3: ejects twin beams of radiation that appear to pulse 30 times a second due to the neutron star's rotation. A neutron star is the crushed ultra-dense core of the exploded star.

column1: The Crab Nebula derived its name from its appearance in a drawing made by Irish astronomer Lord Rosse in 1844
column2: using a 36-inch telescope. When viewed by Hubble
column3: as well as by large ground-based telescopes such as the European Southern Observatory's Very Large Telescope
column4: the Crab Nebula takes on a more detailed appearance that yields clues into the spectacular demise of a star
column6: 500 light-years away.

column1: This image was assembled from 24 individual Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 exposures taken in October 1999
column2: January 2000
column3: and December 2000. The colors in the image indicate the different elements that were expelled during the explosion. Blue in the filaments in the outer part of the nebula represents neutral oxygen
column4: green is  singly ionized sulfur
column5: and red indicates doubly ionized oxygen.

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column3: is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit. By placing the telescope in space
column4: astronomers are able to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere.

column5: Cornecticut

column1: 36486468025.0;M107;"M107 is one of approximately 150 globular star clusters found around the disk of the Milky Way galaxy. These spherical collections each contain hundreds of thousands of extremely old stars and are among the oldest objects in the Milky Way. The origin of globular clusters and their impact on galactic evolution remain somewhat unclear
column2: so astronomers continue to study them through pictures such as this one
column3: obtained by Hubble using visible and infrared observations.

column1: Discovered in 1782 by Pierre Méchain
column2: a French astronomer and colleague of Charles Messier
column3: M107 was the last Messier object to be found. M104 through M109 were all discovered by Méchain and were considered “Méchain objects” until 1947
column4: when they were added to the Messier catalog.

column1: M107 is located 20
column2: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Ophiuchus. It has an apparent magnitude of 8.9 and can be spotted through a small telescope most easily during July.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M107

column1: More than 40 of NASA's followers on social media traveled from across the country to attend a NASA Social event on April 23
column3: in celebration of the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope. The day-long event began by attending the unveiling of a 25th anniversary image at a NASA press conference at the Newseum in Washington

column5: ending with a viewing of the Hubble control center and a hands-on demonstration of the tools used during the Hubble servicing missions.

column1: Atlantis' 12-day flight included five spacewalks that refurbished and upgraded the telescope with state-of-the-art science instruments that expanded Hubble's capabilities and extended its operational lifespan. The payload included the Wide Field Camera 3
column2: a fine guidance sensor and the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph. The launch of Atlantis took place at 2:01 p.m. EDT on May 11

column1: 35560415723.0;M16;"These towering tendrils of cosmic dust and gas sit at the heart of M16
column2: or the Eagle Nebula. The aptly named Pillars of Creation
column3: featured in this stunning Hubble image
column4: are part of an active star-forming region within the nebula and hide newborn stars in their wispy columns.

column1: Although this is not Hubble’s first image of this iconic feature of the Eagle Nebula
column2: it is the most detailed. The blue colors in the image represent oxygen
column3: red is sulfur
column4: and green represents both nitrogen and hydrogen. The pillars are bathed in the scorching ultraviolet light from a cluster of young stars located just outside the frame. The winds from these stars are slowly eroding the towers of gas and dust.

column1: Stretching roughly 4 to 5 light-years
column2: the Pillars of Creation are a fascinating but relatively small feature of the entire Eagle Nebula
column3: which spans 70 by 55 light-years. The nebula
column4: discovered in 1745 by the Swiss astronomer Jean-Philippe Loys de Chéseaux
column5: is located 7
column6: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Serpens. With an apparent magnitude of 6
column7: the Eagle Nebula can be spotted through a small telescope and is best viewed during July. A large telescope and optimal viewing conditions are necessary to resolve the Pillars of Creation.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M16
column2: see:

hubblesite.org/news_release/news/2005-12
hubblesite.org/news_release/news/1995-44/

column1: 36105726980.0;M11;"M11 is one of the few open star clusters in the Messier catalog that has been observed by Hubble. Unlike the many globular clusters Hubble has imaged
column2: open clusters are groups of stars that are only loosely bound by gravity. The lifespans of open clusters are relatively short when compared to those of globular clusters. This is because the gravitational interactions between members of open clusters are comparatively weak
column3: so stars do not remain bound for long before they are drawn away by stronger gravitational forces.

column1: Also known as the Wild Duck Cluster for the roughly V-shaped arrangement of its brightest stars
column2: M11 was discovered by the German astronomer Gottfried Kirch in 1681. It is located 6
column3: 200 light-years from Earth in the constellation Scutum and has an apparent magnitude of 6.3. Of the 26 open clusters included in the Messier catalog
column4: M11 is the most distant that can be seen with the naked eye. The best time to spot the cluster is in August. M11 is one of the most densely populated open clusters known. Containing over 2
column5: 900 stars
column6: it appears as a triangular patch of light through a pair of binoculars.

column1: This Hubble image of a portion of the cluster was created using observations at visible and ultraviolet wavelengths. The black stripe through the middle of the image results from a gap between the two detectors of the camera that made the observations.
Credit: NASA
column2: ESA
column3: STScI
column4: and P. Dobbie (University of Tasmania)";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/54c9c634b84ffa93eb36b2484f6c46ce;2017-06-23;2048.0;2048.0;CC BY-NC-SA;7.2157687169e+16;Hubble's Messier Catalog;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36105726980/in/album-72157687169041200;messier hubble hubblespacetelescope nightsky space nasa wildduckcluster messier11 m11 augustsky scutum astronomy galacticcluster opencluster ngc6705 stars starcluster

column1: 31975852484.0;Hubble Witnesses Massive Comet-Like Object Pollute Atmosphere of a White Dwarf;"(Artist's Depiction)
For the first time
column2: scientists using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope have witnessed a massive object with the makeup of a comet being ripped apart and scattered in the atmosphere of a white dwarf
column3: the burned-out remains of a compact star. The object has a chemical composition similar to Halley’s Comet
column4: but it is 100
column5: 000 times more massive and has a much higher amount of water. It is also rich in the elements essential for life
column6: including nitrogen
column7: carbon
column8: oxygen
column9: and sulfur.

column1: These findings are evidence for a belt of comet-like bodies orbiting the white dwarf
column2: similar to our solar system’s Kuiper Belt. These icy bodies apparently survived the star’s evolution as it became a bloated red giant and then collapsed to a small
column3: dense white dwarf.

column1: As many as 25 to 50 percent of white dwarfs are known to be polluted with infalling debris from rocky
column2: asteroid-like objects
column3: but this is the first time a body made of icy
column4: comet-like material has been seen polluting a white dwarf’s atmosphere.

column1: The results also suggest the presence of unseen
column2: surviving planets which may have perturbed the belt and worked as a “bucket brigade” to draw the icy objects into the white dwarf. The burned-out star also has a companion star
column3: which may disturb the belt
column4: causing objects from the belt to travel toward the burned-out star.

column1: Siyi Xu of the European Southern Observatory in Garching
column2: Germany
column3: led the team that made the discovery. According to Xu
column4: this was the first time that nitrogen was detected in the planetary debris that falls onto a white dwarf. “Nitrogen is a very important element for life as we know it
column5: ” Xu explained. “This particular object is quite rich in nitrogen
column6: more so than any object observed in our solar system.”

column1: Our own Kuiper Belt
column2: which extends outward from Neptune’s orbit
column3: is home to many dwarf planets
column4: comets
column5: and other small bodies left over from the formation of the solar system. Comets from the Kuiper Belt may have been responsible for delivering water and the basic building blocks of life to Earth billions of years ago.

column1: The new findings are observational evidence supporting the idea that icy bodies are also present in other planetary systems
column2: and have survived throughout the history of the star’s evolution.

column1: To study the white dwarf’s atmosphere
column2: the team used both Hubble and the W. M. Keck Observatory. The measurements of nitrogen
column3: carbon
column4: oxygen
column5: silicon
column6: sulfur
column7: iron
column8: nickel
column9: and hydrogen all come from Hubble
column10: while Keck provides the calcium
column11: magnesium
column12: and hydrogen. The ultraviolet vision of Hubble’s Cosmic Origins Spectrograph (COS) allowed the team to make measurements that are very difficult to do from the ground.

column1: This is the first object found outside our solar system that is akin to Halley’s Comet in composition. The team used the famous comet for comparison because it has been so well studied.
The white dwarf is roughly 170 light-years from Earth in the constellation Bootes
column2: the Herdsman. It was first recorded in 1974 and is part of a wide binary system
column3: with a companion star separated by 2
column4: 000 times the distance that the Earth is from the Sun.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/7a3d56fd31348d0e4f2a92a87693b191;2017-02-10;739.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/31975852484/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 32512582566.0;Starbirth with a chance of winds?;"The lesser-known constellation of Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs)
column2: is home to a variety of deep-sky objects — including this beautiful galaxy
column3: known as NGC 4861. Astronomers are still debating on how to classify it: While its physical properties — such as mass
column4: size and rotational velocity — indicate it to be a spiral galaxy
column5: its appearance looks more like a comet with its dense
column6: luminous “head” and dimmer “tail” trailing behind. Features more fitting with a dwarf irregular galaxy.

column1: Although small and messy
column2: galaxies like NGC 4861 provide astronomers with interesting opportunities for study. Small galaxies have lower gravitational potentials
column3: which simply means that it takes less energy to move stuff about inside them than it does in other galaxies. As a result
column4: moving in
column5: around
column6: and through such a tiny galaxy is quite easy to do
column7: making them far more likely to be suffused with streams and outflows of speedy charged particles known as galactic winds
column8: which can flood such galaxies with little effort.

column1: These galactic winds can be powered by the ongoing process of star formation
column2: which involves huge amounts of energy. New stars are springing into life within the bright
column3: colorful "head" of NGC 4861 and ejecting streams of high-speed particles as they do so
column4: which flood outwards to join the wider galactic wind. While NGC 4861 would be a perfect candidate to study such winds
column5: recent studies did not find any galactic winds in it.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/6f5e3ace1eeaa3f18ffb7947c3a683af;2017-01-23;833.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/32512582566/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4861

column1: 31873538413.0;The Calabash clash;"The Calabash Nebula
column2: pictured here — which has the technical name OH 231.8+04.2 — is a spectacular example of the death of a low-mass star like the Sun. This image taken by the Hubble Space Telescope shows the star going through a rapid transformation from a red giant to a planetary nebula
column3: during which it blows its outer layers of gas and dust out into the surrounding space. The recently ejected material is spat out in opposite directions with immense speed — the gas shown in yellow is moving close to a million kilometers an hour.

column1: Astronomers rarely capture a star in this phase of its evolution because it occurs within the blink of an eye — in astronomical terms. Over the next thousand years the nebula is expected to evolve into a fully fledged planetary nebula.
The nebula is also known as the Rotten Egg Nebula because it contains a lot of sulphur
column2: an element that
column3: when combined with other elements
column4: smells like a rotten egg — but luckily
column5: it resides over 5
column6: 000 light-years away in the constellation of Puppis (the Poop Deck).";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/69c5b1a8f61511c18f00ac63baa1ae53;2016-10-07;956.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/31873538413/in/album-72157667717916600;calabashnebula oh23184422

column1: 30927384014.0;Festive Nebulas Light Up Milky Way Galaxy Satellite;"NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope captured two festive-looking nebulas
column2: situated so as to appear as one. They reside in the Small Magellanic Cloud
column3: a dwarf galaxy that is a satellite of our Milky Way galaxy. Intense radiation from the brilliant central stars is heating hydrogen in each of the nebulas
column4: causing them to glow red.

column1: The nebulas
column2: together
column3: are called NGC 248. They were discovered in 1834 by the astronomer Sir John Herschel. NGC 248 is about 60 light-years long and 20 light-years wide. It is among a number of glowing hydrogen nebulas in the dwarf satellite galaxy
column4: which is located approximately 200
column5: 000 light-years away in the southern constellation Tucana.

column1: The image is part of a study called Small Magellanic Cloud Investigation of Dust and Gas Evolution (SMIDGE). Astronomers used Hubble to probe the Milky Way satellite to understand how dust is different in galaxies that have a far lower supply of heavy elements needed to create dust. The Small Magellanic Cloud has between a fifth and a tenth of the amount of heavy elements that the Milky Way does. Because it is so close
column2: astronomers can study its dust in great detail
column3: and learn about what dust was like earlier in the history of the universe.

column1: “It is important for understanding the history of our own galaxy
column2: too
column3: ” explained the study’s principal investigator
column4: Dr. Karin Sandstrom of the University of California
column5: San Diego. Most of the star formation happened earlier in the universe
column6: at a time where there was a much lower percentage of heavy elements than there is now. “Dust is a really critical part of how a galaxy works
column7: how it forms stars
column8: ” said Sandstrom.

column1: The data used in this image were taken with Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys in September 2015.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/d5bd691c0178e1c580d28639aad9ef52;2016-12-20;985.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/30927384014/in/album-72157667717916600;
28316228854.0;NASA's Hubble Spots a Lopsided Lynx;"This galaxy
column2: known as NGC 2337
column3: resides 25 million light-years away in the constellation of Lynx. NGC 2337 is an irregular galaxy
column4: meaning that it — along with a quarter of all galaxies in the Universe — lacks a distinct
column5: regular appearance. The galaxy  was discovered in 1877 by the French astronomer Édouard Stephan who
column6: in the same year
column7: discovered the galactic group Stephan’s Quintet.

column1: Although irregular galaxies may never win a beauty prize when competing with their more symmetrical spiral and elliptical peers
column2: astronomers consider them to be very important. Some irregular galaxies may have once fallen into one of the regular classes of the Hubble sequence
column3: but were warped and deformed by a passing cosmic companion. As such
column4: irregular galaxies provide astronomers with a valuable opportunity to learn more about galactic evolution and interaction.

column1: Despite the disruption
column2: gravitational interactions between galaxies can kick-start star formation activity within the affected galaxies
column3: which may explain the pockets of blue light scattered throughout NGC 2337. These patches and knots of blue signal the presence of young
column4: newly formed
column5: hot stars.

27748806010.0;Hubble Sweeps Scattered Stars in Sagittarius;"This colorful and star-studded view of the Milky Way galaxy was captured when the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope pointed its cameras towards the constellation of Sagittarius (The Archer). Blue stars can be seen scattered across the frame
column2: set against a distant backdrop of red-hued cosmic companions. This blue litter most likely formed at the same time from the same collapsing molecular cloud.

column1: The color of a star can reveal many of its secrets. Shades of red indicate a star much cooler than the sun
column2: so either at the end of its life
column3: or much less massive. These lower-mass stars are called red dwarfs and are thought to be the most common type of star in the Milky Way. Similarly
column4: brilliant blue hues indicate hot
column5: young
column6: or massive stars
column7: many times the mass of the sun.

column1: A star’s mass decides its fate; more massive stars burn brightly over a short lifespan
column2: and die young after only tens of millions of years. Stars like the sun typically have more sedentary lifestyles and live longer
column3: burning for approximately ten billion years. Smaller stars
column4: on the other hand
column5: live life in the slow lane and are predicted to exist for trillions of years
column6: well beyond the current age of the universe.

column1: 27411443544.0;Sinai Peninsula and the Dead Sea Rift;The astronauts on board the Space Shuttle Columbia took this 70mm picture featuring the Sinai Peninsula and the Dead Sea Rift. The left side of the view is dominated by the great triangle of the Sinai peninsula
column2: which is partly obscured by an unusual cloud mass on this day. The famous Monastery of St. Catherine lies in the very remote
column3: rugged mountains in the southern third of the peninsula (foreground). The Gulf of Aqaba is a finger of the Red Sea bottom center
column4: pointing north to the Dead Sea
column5: the small body of water near the center of the view. According to NASA scientists studying the STS-109 photo collection
column6: the gulf and the Dead Sea are northerly extensions of the same geological rift that resulted in the opening of the Red Sea . The Gulf of Suez appears in the lower left corner. Northwest Saudi Arabia occupies the lower right side of the view
column7: Jordan and Syria the right and top right
column8: and the Eastern Mediterranean Sea the top left. Thin white lines of cloud have formed along the coastal mountains of southern Turkey and stretch across the top of the view near the Earth's limb.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/4039fa8b4a0d369909967d4b5003105b;2016-07-01;6817.0;6817.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27411443544/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109

column4: completing mission STS-109 to service the Hubble Space Telescope. Wheel stop occurred on orbit 165 at 4:33:09 a.m. EST on March 12
column5: 2002 with mission elapsed time of 10 days
column6: 22 hours
column7: 11 minutes. Main gear touchdown occurred at 4:31:52 a.m. and nose wheel touchdown an 4:32:02. It was the 58th landing at KSC out of 108 missions in the history of the Shuttle program.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/b7841971086966817afc72e5ff45c280;2016-07-01;1979.0;3000.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27990736426/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109 columbia sm3b

column1: 28025338065.0;Florida;The astronauts on board the Space Shuttle Columbia took this 70mm picture featuring part of the eastern sea board in March 2002. The oblique view looks northward from South Florida to the southern Appalachians. Most of the southeastern United States appears in crisp
column2: clear air in the wake of a cold front that has pushed well off the mainland. column1: 27410005594.0;Lake Malawi (Lake Nyasa);This low-oblique
column2: southeast-looking photograph shows Lake Malawi
column3: one of many elongated lakes that form part of the Great Rift Valley of east Africa. The lake
column4: bounded by steep mountains on all sides except the southern end
column5: is approximately 360 miles (580 kilometers) long
column6: averages 25 miles (40 kilometers) in width
column7: and has a maximum depth of 2316 feet (706 meters). Lake Malawi is drained at the south end by the Shire River
column8: which eventually empties into the Zambezi River. The lake and its steep-sloped shoreline were created by faulting that caused a thrust upward as the valley floor subsided between the slopes. The darker area along the northwest coast of the lake is the Nyika Plateau
column9: which has several elevations more than 8000 feet (2440 meters) above sea level. Landlocked Malawi extends along the entire west coast of the lake. The large Luangwa River basin is visible as it drains to the southwest. Immediately west of the Luangwa River Valley stand the northeast-southwest-trending Muchinga Mountains with their dark ridgeline and maximum elevations reaching 6000 feet (1830 meters) above sea level. Northwest of this mountain range
column10: drainage is to the north and west into the much larger Zaire (Congo) River watershed.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/3c58035b66f622cf593f0e8bc6acd38d;2016-07-01;5248.0;5248.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27410005594/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

column1: 27410150633.0;Lake Chad;Lake Chad
column2: which belongs to the countries of Chad
column3: Cameroon
column4: Nigeria
column5: and Niger
column6: is a sedimentary basin that is controlled by climate and rainfall. The lake is divided into two basins—the south basin fed by the Chari River and the north basin fed by the Komadougou River. The south basin
column7: with its delta along the southern shore
column8: has a distinct advantage in that the Sahel (a transition zone between the true desert and the grasslands south of the desert) generally receives more precipitation than the region west of Lake Chad that provides recharge water for the north basin. The south basin’s water level has remained relatively constant during the decades of 1980s and 1990s
column9: while the north basin has shown little evidence of standing water since the late 1960s and early 1970s. Extensive sand dunes exist within the northern half of the south basin
column10: but there appears to be vegetation in this area. (Refer to STS-061-075-023 for a view of the north basin of Lake Chad.);https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/43c1baacfabf2025b8a4e64adc694390;2016-07-01;5266.0;5266.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27410150633/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

column1: 27415202964.0;Hubble Sees New Dark Spot on Neptune;"New images obtained on May 16
column3: by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope confirm the presence of a dark vortex in the atmosphere of Neptune. This full visible-light image shows that the dark feature resides near and below a patch of bright clouds in the planet's southern hemisphere. Though similar features were seen during the Voyager 2 flyby of Neptune in 1989 and by the Hubble Space Telescope in 1994
column4: this vortex is the first one observed on Neptune in the 21st century.

column1: Neptune's dark vortices are high-pressure systems and are usually accompanied by bright "companion clouds
column2: " which are also now visible on the distant planet. The bright clouds form when the flow of ambient air is perturbed and diverted upward over the dark vortex
column3: causing gases to likely freeze into methane ice crystals.

column1: Full news release and annotated images: Hubble Imagery Confirms New Dark Spot on Neptune
Image Credit: NASA
column2: ESA
column3: and M.H. Wong and J. Tollefson (UC Berkeley)

column1: 27925725012.0;Spiral Galaxy M83;"A photogenic and favorite target for amateur astronomers
column2: the full beauty of nearby spiral galaxy M83 is unveiled in all of its glory in this Hubble Space Telescope mosaic image. The vibrant magentas and blues reveal the galaxy is ablaze with star formation. The galaxy
column3: also known as the Southern Pinwheel
column4: lies 15 million light-years away in the constellation Hydra.

column1: The Hubble photograph captures thousands of star clusters
column2: hundreds of thousands of individual stars
column3: and "ghosts" of dead stars called supernova remnants. The galactic panorama unveils a tapestry of the drama of stellar birth and death spread across 50
column4: 000 light-years.

column1: The newest generations of stars are forming largely in clusters on the edges of the dark spiral dust lanes. These brilliant young stellar groupings
column2: only a few million years old
column3: produce huge amounts of ultraviolet light that is absorbed by surrounding diffuse gas clouds
column4: causing them to glow in pinkish hydrogen light.

column1: Gradually
column2: the fierce stellar winds from the youngest
column3: most massive stars blow away the gas
column4: revealing bright blue star clusters and giving a "Swiss cheese" appearance to the spiral arms. These youngest star clusters are about 1 million to 10 million years old. The populations of stars up to 100 million years or older appear yellow or orange by comparison because the young blue stars have already burned out.

column1: Interstellar "bubbles" produced by nearly 300 supernovas from massive stars have been found in this Hubble image. By studying these supernova remnants
column2: astronomers can better understand the nature of the stars that exploded and dispersed nuclear processed chemical elements back into the galaxy
column3: contributing to the next generation of new stars.

column1: This image was used to support a citizen science project titled STAR DATE: M83. The primary goal was to estimate ages for approximately 3
column2: 000 star clusters. STAR DATE: M83 was a joint collaborative effort between the Space Telescope Science Institute and Zooniverse
column3: creators of several citizen science projects including Galaxy Zoo
column4: Planet Hunters
column5: and the Andromeda Project (go to www.zooniverse.org to see the full list).

28049542001.0;Candid views of the STS-61 crew on the Endeavour's middeck;Astronaut Jeffrey A. Hoffman spends a moment of off-duty time aboard Endeavour to celebrate Hanukkah. A dreidel floats near the astronaut on the middeck. The veteran mission specialist spent eleven days in space with five other NASA astronauts and a payload specialist from the European Space Agency (ESA). Their primary mission was to service the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). Hoffman participated in three of five space walks associated with that servicing mission.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/69cdcbb5fd00fc27b3e46b9c3592a84f;2010-09-02;2796.0;4276.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28049542001/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

column1: 39530073405.0;Three Steps to the Hubble Constant;"This Hubble Space Telescope image showcases one of the 19 galaxies analyzed in a project to improve the precision of the universe's expansion rate
column2: a value known as the Hubble constant.

column1: The color-composite image shows NGC 3972
column2: located 65 million light-years from Earth. The galaxy contains pulsating stars called Cepheid variables. These stars blink at a rate matched closely by their intrinsic brightness
column3: making them ideal cosmic lighthouses for measuring accurate distances to relatively nearby galaxies.

column1: Another reliable milepost marker is a special class of exploding star called a Type Ia supernova. All of these supernovae peak at the same brightness and are brilliant enough to be seen over relatively longer distances. NGC 3972 also hosted a Type Ia supernova.

Astronomers search for Cepheid variables in nearby galaxies containing a Type Ia supernova so they can compare the true brightness of both types of stars. That brightness information is used to calibrate the luminosity of Type Ia supernovae in far-flung galaxies so that astronomers can calculate the galaxies' distances from Earth. Once astronomers know accurate distances to galaxies near and far
column2: they can determine and refine the universe's expansion rate.

column1: The observations for NGC 3972 were taken in 2015 using Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/037bf2f49bd788e3aee276529865208a;2018-02-22;750.0;1000.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/39530073405/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc3972

column2: left to right
column3: are astronauts Joseph R. Tanner
column4: Mark C. Lee and Gregory J. Harbaugh. Behind them
column5: left to right
column6: are astronauts Steven A. Hawley
column7: Kenneth D. Bowersox and Scott J. Horowitz. At the very back is astronaut Steven L. Smith. Each astronaut is wearing a shirt bearing an image of a planet or other celestial body photographed originally by the giant observatory.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/f7b00ed3acdfb83805e86d3da61aafcb;2016-07-01;1020.0;1536.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 2;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28023991715/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission servicingmission2 sts82

column1: 38956026775.0;A star's colourful final splash;The Hubble Space Telescope captured this beautiful image of NGC 6326
column2: a planetary nebula with glowing wisps of outpouring gas that are lit up by a central star nearing the end of its life. When a star ages and the red giant phase of its life comes to an end
column3: it starts to eject layers of gas from its surface leaving behind a hot and compact white dwarf. Sometimes this ejection results in elegantly symmetric patterns of glowing gas
column4: but NGC 6326 is much less structured. This object is located in the constellation of Ara
column5: the Altar
column6: about 11 000 light-years from Earth. Planetary nebulae are one of the main ways in which elements heavier than hydrogen and helium are dispersed into space after their creation in the hearts of stars. Eventually some of this outflung material may form new stars and planets. The vivid red and blue hues in this image come from the material glowing under the action of the fierce ultraviolet radiation from the still hot central star. This picture was created from images taken using the Hubble Space Telescope’s Wide Field Planetary Camera 2. The red light was captured through a filter letting through the glow from hydrogen gas (F658N). The blue glow comes from ionised oxygen and was recorded through a green filter (F502N). The green layer of the image
column7: which shows the stars well
column8: was taken through a broader yellow filter (F555W). The total exposure times were 1400 s
column9: 360 s and 260 s respectively. The field of view is about 30 arcseconds across.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/2abe255b88077299d211460bc82a64a5;2010-06-28;907.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/38956026775/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc6326

column1: 37357543070.0;Bubbles in space;"At a distance of just 160
column2: 000 light-years
column3: the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is one of the Milky Way’s closest companions. It is also home to one of the largest and most intense regions of active star formation known to exist anywhere in our galactic neighborhood — the Tarantula Nebula. This Hubble Space Telescope image shows both the spindly
column4: spidery filaments of gas that inspired the region’s name
column5: and the intriguing structure of stacked “bubbles” that forms the so-called Honeycomb Nebula (to the lower left).

column1: The Honeycomb Nebula was found serendipitously by astronomers using ESO’s New Technology Telescope to image the nearby SN1987A
column2: the closest observed supernova to Earth for over 400 years. The nebula’s strange bubble-like shape has baffled astronomers since its discovery in the early 1990s. Various theories have been proposed to explain its unique structure
column3: some more exotic than others.

column2: a group of astronomers studied the nebula and
column3: using advanced data analysis and computer modelling
column4: came to the conclusion that its unique appearance is likely due to the combined effect of two supernovae — a more recent explosion has pierced the expanding shell of material created by an older explosion. The nebula’s especially striking appearance is suspected to be due to a fortuitous viewing angle; the honeycomb effect of the circular shells may not be visible from another viewpoint.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/a1d4acf3e537a03cd09d666e04eafd43;2017-04-21;535.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/37357543070/in/album-72157667717916600;honeycombnebula

column1: 36397671846.0;M31;"Assembled from a total of 7
column2: 398 exposures taken over 411 individual pointings of the telescope
column3: this image of our nearest major galactic neighbor
column5: is the largest Hubble mosaic to date. The 1.5 billion pixels in the mosaic reveal over 100 million stars and thousands of star clusters embedded in a section of the pancake-shaped disk of M31
column6: also known as the Andromeda galaxy. Though the galaxy is over 2 million light-years away
column7: Hubble is powerful enough to resolve individual stars in this 61
column8: 000-light-year-long stretch of the disk. It’s like photographing a beach and resolving individual grains of sand.

column1: Hubble traces densely packed stars extending from the innermost hub of the galaxy
column2: seen at left. Moving out from this central galactic bulge
column3: the panorama sweeps across lanes of stars and dust to the sparser outer disk. Cooler
column4: yellowish stars dominate the center of the galaxy
column5: toward the lower left. The blue
column6: ring-like feature that wraps from the upper left to the lower right is a spiral arm with numerous clusters of young
column7: blue stars and star-forming regions. The dark silhouettes trace out complex dust structures.

column1: M31 is located in the constellation Andromeda and is best observed in November. Boasting an apparent magnitude of 3.1
column2: the galaxy can be seen with the naked eye
column3: even in areas with moderate light pollution. Because it is such an easily observed feature in the night sky
column4: it is impossible to say who discovered the Andromeda galaxy. However
column5: Persian astronomer Abd al-rahman al-Sufi’s The Book of Fixed Stars from the year 964 contains the first known report of the object.

column1: 23661262488.0;M105;"M105 is an elliptical galaxy 32 billion light-years away in the constellation Leo. It is the largest elliptical in the Messier catalog that is not a member of the Virgo cluster of galaxies. M105 does
column2: however
column3: belong to the M96 (or Leo I) Group
column4: which includes neighbors M95 and M96 as well as several other fainter galaxies. Charles Messier’s colleague Pierre Méchain discovered M105 in 1781 just a few days after locating M95 and M96. Yet M105 was not originally included in Messier’s catalog. It was added in 1947 after astronomer Helen S. Hogg found a letter written by Méchain describing the galaxy.

column1: This Hubble image of M105 was taken in near-infrared and visible light. Like most elliptical galaxies it appears rather featureless and inactive. However
column2: Hubble observations surprised astronomers by revealing young stars and star clusters in M105
column3: indicating that star formation is still taking place in what was thought to be a “dead” galaxy no longer capable of giving birth to new stars. Other Hubble observations measured the speeds of stars moving around the center of the galaxy
column4: which demonstrated that a supermassive black hole resides at M105’s core.

column1: Best observed in April
column2: M105 has an apparent magnitude of 10.2 and can be spotted with a small telescope. Large telescopes will uncover two fainter galaxies (NGC 3384 and NGC 3389) close to the bright elliptical.

column2: beautiful spiral galaxy situated in the Virgo cluster of galaxies. Located in the constellation Virgo
column3: this galaxy is approximately 59 million light-years away from Earth and has a magnitude of 9.5. M90 is believed to be breaking away from the rest of the galaxies in the Virgo cluster and is one of the few galaxies traveling toward our Milky Way galaxy
column4: not away.

column1: Charles Messier found M90 in 1781 while looking at other galaxies in the Virgo cluster. M90 contains approximately a trillion stars and a thousand globular clusters. With the exception of the inner disk region
column2: the galaxy's arms contain very little star formation. Interactions with neighboring galaxies likely stripped away the gas and material that M90 needs to have active star formation in its outer regions. In the future
column3: M90 is expected to evolve into a lenticular galaxy
column4: which is a galaxy that has qualities of both a spiral and an elliptical galaxy.

column1: This Hubble observation was taken in infrared
column2: ultraviolet
column3: and visible light with the telescope's Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2. Less than half of the galaxy is visible in this image. Astronomers used these Hubble observations to help study the properties of galactic bulges and the cores of nearby galaxies.

column1: The best time to view M90 is in May. It can be seen with binoculars in a clear
column2: dark sky
column3: and telescopes (especially larger ones) will begin to reveal more details of the galaxy
column4: such as its arms and bright core.

36316302582.0;M68;"Discovered by Charles Messier in 1780
column2: M68 is a dense collection of stars known as a globular cluster. Mutual gravitational attraction amongst the hundreds of thousands or even millions of stars in such a cluster keeps stellar members packed tightly together for many billions of years.

column1: Roughly 150 of these objects reside in our Milky Way galaxy. On a galactic scale
column2: globular clusters are relatively small. In M68’s case
column3: its constituent stars span a volume of space with a diameter of little more than a hundred light-years. The disk of the Milky Way
column4: on the other hand
column5: extends over 100
column6: 000 light-years.

column1: M68 is located 33
column2: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Hydra. It has an apparent magnitude of 8 and can be spotted with a pair of binoculars. The cluster is best observed during April.

column1: This Hubble image of the core of M68 was created using observations at visible and infrared wavelengths of light.

column1: 27946233281.0;STS031-152-0DL Hamersley Range
column2: Western Australia
column3: Australia April 1990;The entire Hamersley Range is visible in this synoptic view of northwestern Australia. This folded range of mountains (seen as a darker green-brown area in the center of the image) trends generally east-west and is bounded north and south by two river valleys (somewhat linear
column4: lighter colored areas). The Fortescue River is the relatively narrow valley north of the mountains and the broader valley south of the mountains is the Ashburton River. The Hamersley Range has peaks that reach 4000 feet (1200 meters) above sea level. A series of curving
column5: lower mountains
column6: that parallel the Hamersley can also be seen south of the Ashburton River. The Hamersley area is a major source of iron formations and the area north of the Hamersley contain some of the oldest rocks in the world
column7: dating back 3.5 billion years. The lighter color areas north of the Hamersley
column8: known as the Pilbara District
column9: contains huge granite plutons. The small bay (lower left) in the corner of the image is Exmouth Gulf.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/72dc6646beb8f693beb96f7a9f9b2986;2016-07-01;4000.0;5088.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Deployment;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27946233281/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa hubbledeployment sts31

column1: 27712254863.0;Hubble Space Telescope Assembly;"This photograph shows the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) flight article assembly with multilayer insulation
column2: high-gain antenna
column3: and solar arrays in a clean room of the Lockheed Missile and Space Company.

column1: Hubble was the first of NASA's great observatories and the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made. The purpose of Hubble is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit by placing the telescope in space
column2: enabling astronomers to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery (STS-31 mission) into Earth orbit in April 1990.

column1: The Marshall Space Flight Center had overall responsibility for design
column2: development
column3: and construction of the observatory. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury
column4: Connecticut
column5: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. The Lockheed Missile and Space Company
column6: Sunnyvale
column7: California
column8: produced the protective outer shroud and spacecraft systems
column9: and assembled and tested the finished telescope.

column1: Date Created: 1986-01-01";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/76bfc27173581f28ad1a8bd7adec6256;2007-10-23;3000.0;2395.0;CC BY;7.21576710092e+16;Hubble in Development;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27712254863/in/album-72157671009197500;hst hubble space telescope nasa hubblespacetelescope
30053763026.0;The hidden dark side of NGC 24;"This shining disk of a spiral galaxy sits approximately 25 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Sculptor. Named NGC 24
column2: the galaxy was discovered by British astronomer William Herschel in 1785 and measures some 40
column3: 000 light-years across.

column1: This picture was taken using the Hubble Space Telescope’s Advanced Camera for Surveys
column2: known as ACS for short. It shows NGC 24 in detail
column3: highlighting the blue bursts (young stars)
column4: dark lanes (cosmic dust)
column5: and red bubbles (hydrogen gas) of material peppered throughout the galaxy’s spiral arms. Numerous distant galaxies can also been seen hovering around NGC 24’s perimeter.

column1: However
column2: there may be more to this picture than first meets the eye. Astronomers suspect that spiral galaxies like NGC 24 and the Milky Way are surrounded by
column3: and contained within
column4: extended halos of dark matter. Dark matter is a mysterious substance that cannot be seen; instead
column5: it reveals itself via its gravitational interactions with surrounding material. Its existence was originally proposed to explain why the outer parts of galaxies
column6: including our own
column7: rotate unexpectedly fast
column8: but it is thought to also play an essential role in a galaxy’s formation and evolution. Most of NGC 24’s mass — a whopping 80% — is thought to be held within such a dark halo.

NASA Hubble Space Telescope

30595225640.0;A greedy giant;"NGC 1222
column2: seen in this image taken with the Wide Field Camera 3 on board the Hubble Space Telescope (HST)
column3: is a galaxy with a rather eventful story to tell. NGC 1222 has been described as a peculiar example of a type of galaxy known as a lenticular galaxy. Typically
column4: this kind of galaxy would present a rather smooth appearance on the sky and would consist mostly of old
column5: reddish stars. A bit dull
column6: perhaps.

column1: But NGC 1222 is certainly not a typical member of its class — and it’s anything but dull. Observations show the characteristic features of very recent star formation on a huge scale — an event known as a starburst. The reason for all this violent activity is caused by the fact that NGC 1222 is not alone. It actually contains three compact regions
column2: each of which appears to be the central nucleus of a galaxy. Astronomers think that NGC 1222 is in the process of swallowing up two much smaller dwarf galaxies that strayed too close to it. It is likely that the encounter was the trigger for the starburst in NGC 1222
column3: bringing in fresh supplies of gas that are now fueling the burst of star formation.

column1: Although its peculiarities were first seen in photographic images
column2: these were not able to reveal the level of fine detail that can be recovered by Hubble. The image taken by Hubble allows us to see an astonishing amount of structure in this galaxy
column3: emphasizing its colorful history. Against the smooth background of old stars that was the original lenticular galaxy
column4: we can clearly see dark filaments of dust and bright filaments of gas
column5: both associated with the powerful star formation process.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/e93137284a68d656a2cc09dc147df6a9;2016-11-07;815.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/30595225640/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc1222

column1: 29363426060.0;Into the storm;"This shot from the Hubble Space Telescope shows a maelstrom of glowing gas and dark dust within one of the Milky Way’s satellite galaxies
column2: the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC).

column1: This stormy scene shows a stellar nursery known as N159
column2: an HII region over 150 light-years across. N159 contains many hot young stars. These stars are emitting intense ultraviolet light
column3: which causes nearby hydrogen gas to glow
column4: and torrential stellar winds
column5: which are carving out ridges
column6: arcs
column7: and filaments from the surrounding material.

column1: At the heart of this cosmic cloud lies the Papillon Nebula
column2: a butterfly-shaped region of nebulosity. This small
column3: dense object is classified as a High-Excitation Blob
column4: and is thought to be tightly linked to the early stages of massive star formation.

column1: N159 is located over 160
column2: 000 light-years away. It resides just south of the Tarantula Nebula
column3: another massive star-forming complex within the LMC. It was previously imaged by Hubble’s Wide Field Planetary Camera 2
column4: which also resolved the Papillon Nebula for the first time.

column1: Credit: ESA/NASA

32516683650.0;A spiral in Andromeda;"Not to be confused with our neighboring Andromeda Galaxy
column2: the Andromeda constellation is one of the 88 modern constellations. More importantly for this image
column3: it is home to the pictured NGC 7640.

column1: Many different classifications are used to identify galaxies by shape and structure — NGC 7640 is a barred spiral type. These are recognizable by their spiral arms
column2: which fan out not from a circular core but from an elongated bar cutting through the galaxy’s center. Our home galaxy
column3: the Milky Way
column4: is also a barred spiral galaxy. NGC 7640 might not look much like a spiral in this image
column5: but this is due to the orientation of the galaxy with respect to Earth — or to Hubble
column6: which acted as photographer in this case! We often do not see galaxies face on
column7: which can make features such as spiral arms less obvious.

column1: There is evidence that NGC 7640 has experienced some kind of interaction in its past. Galaxies contain vast amounts of mass
column2: and therefore affect one another via gravity. Sometimes these interactions can be mild
column3: and sometimes hugely dramatic
column4: with two or more colliding and merging into a new
column5: bigger galaxy. Understanding the history of a galaxy

column2: mission specialist

column4: payload commander
