36975002626.0;From microwaves to megamasers;"Phenomena across the universe emit radiation spanning the entire electromagnetic spectrum — from high-energy gamma rays
column2: which stream out from the most energetic events in the cosmos
column3: to lower-energy microwaves and radio waves.

column1: Microwaves
column2: the very same radiation that can heat up your dinner
column3: are produced by a multitude of astrophysical sources
column4: including strong emitters known as masers (microwave lasers)
column5: even stronger emitters with the somewhat villainous name of megamasers
column6: and the centers of some galaxies. Especially intense and luminous galactic centers are known as active galactic nuclei. They are in turn thought to be driven by the presence of supermassive black holes
column7: which drag surrounding material inwards and spit out bright jets and radiation as they do so.

column1: The two galaxies shown here
column2: imaged by the Hubble Space Telescope
column3: are named MCG+01-38-004 (the upper
column4: red-tinted one) and MCG+01-38-005 (the lower
column5: blue-tinted one). MCG+01-38-005 is a special kind of megamaser; the galaxy’s active galactic nucleus pumps out huge amounts of energy
column6: which stimulates clouds of surrounding water. Water’s constituent atoms of hydrogen and oxygen are able to absorb some of this energy and re-emit it at specific wavelengths
column7: one of which falls within the microwave regime. MCG+01-38-005 is thus known as a water megamaser!

column1: Astronomers can use such objects to probe the fundamental properties of the universe. The microwave emissions from MCG+01-38-005 were used to calculate a refined value for the Hubble constant
column2: a measure of how fast the universe is expanding. This constant is named after the astronomer whose observations were responsible for the discovery of the expanding universe and after whom the Hubble Space Telescope was named
column3: Edwin Hubble.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/9e62d40a5d7d43405e8a1472ec3fca86;2016-11-07;610.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36975002626/in/album-72157667717916600;mcg0138004 mcg0138005

column1: 32657782773.0;Home to a hypergiant;"Light travels through space at just under 300
column2: 000 kilometers per second! This staggering speed is used to calculate astronomical distances; although often misinterpreted as a unit of time (due to its misleading name)
column3: a light-year is actually a unit of astronomical distance
column4: and is defined as the distance that light travels in a year. For reference
column5: a light-year is around nine trillion kilometers… but it’s a little tricky to visualize!

column1: With this in mind
column3: 000 light-years may sound like a truly huge distance
column4: but compared to the vastness of the cosmos
column5: it’s really quite nearby. In fact
column6: an object sitting 15
column7: 000 light-years away would not even be outside our home galaxy
column8: the Milky Way. This is roughly the distance between us and a young super star cluster known as Westerlund 1
column9: home to one of the largest stars ever discovered.

column1: Stars are classified according to their spectral type
column2: surface temperature
column3: and luminosity. While studying and classifying the cluster’s constituent stars
column4: astronomers discovered that Westerlund 1 is home to one of the largest stars ever discovered
column5: originally named Westerlund 1-26. It is a red supergiant (although sometimes classified as a hypergiant) with a radius over 1
column6: 500 times that of our Sun. If Westerlund 1-26 were placed where our Sun is in our solar system
column7: it would extend out beyond the orbit of Jupiter.

column1: Most of Westerlund 1’s stars are thought to have formed in the same burst of activity
column2: meaning that they have similar ages and compositions. The cluster is relatively young in astronomical terms — at around three million years old it is a baby compared to our own Sun
column3: which is some 4.6 billion years old.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/091bd1b1d69316e3b094337a99b0a049;2016-10-28;991.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/32657782773/in/album-72157667717916600;westerlund1

column1: 34485406621.0;Close encounter;"This image from the Hubble Space Telescope shows the unusual galaxy IRAS 06076-2139
column2: found in the constellation Lepus (the Hare). Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) and Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) instruments observed the galaxy from a distance of 500 million light-years.

column1: This particular object stands out from the crowd by actually being composed of two separate galaxies rushing past each other at about 2 million kilometers per hour. This speed is most likely too fast for them to merge and form a single galaxy. However
column2: because of their small separation of only about 20
column3: 000 light-years
column4: the galaxies will distort one another through the force of gravity while passing each other
column5: changing their structures on a grand scale.

column1: Such galactic interactions are a common sight for Hubble
column2: and have long been a field of study for astronomers. The intriguing behaviors of interacting galaxies take many forms; galactic cannibalism
column3: galaxy harassment and even galaxy collisions. The Milky Way itself will eventually fall victim to the latter
column4: merging with the Andromeda Galaxy in about 4.5 billion years. The fate of our galaxy shouldn’t be alarming though; whilst galaxies are populated by billions of stars
column5: the distances between individual stars are so large that hardly any stellar collisions will occur.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/75b20b84dfe6576ee5b010c3bc269c4e;2017-05-08;852.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/34485406621/in/album-72157667717916600;iras060762139

column1: 34190418941.0;A matter of distance;"In space
column2: being outshone is an occupational hazard. This Hubble Space Telescope image captures a galaxy named NGC 7250. Despite being remarkable in its own right — it has bright bursts of star formation and recorded supernova explosions — it blends into the background somewhat thanks to the gloriously bright star hogging the limelight next to it.

column1: This bright object is a single and little-studied star named TYC 3203-450-1
column2: located in the constellation of Lacerta (the Lizard)
column3: much closer than the much more distant galaxy. Only this way can a normal star outshine an entire galaxy
column4: consisting of billions of stars. Astronomers studying distant objects call these stars “foreground stars” and they are often not very happy about them
column5: as their bright light is contaminating the faint light from the more distant and interesting objects they actually want to study.

column1: In this case TYC 3203-450-1 million times closer than NGC 7250
column2: which lies over 45 million light-years away from us. Would the star be the same distance as NGC 7250
column3: it would hardly be visible in this image.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/fb505ee78e30a19393fbde4f38f6c490;2016-11-26;1041.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/34190418941/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc7250 tyc32034501

column1: 36224058765.0;A cosmic atlas;"This beautiful clump of glowing gas
column2: dark dust
column3: and glittering stars is the spiral galaxy NGC 4248
column4: located about 24 million light-years away in the constellation of Canes Venatici (The Hunting Dogs).

column1: This image was produced by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope as it embarked upon compiling the first Hubble ultraviolet “atlas”
column2: for which the telescope targeted 50 nearby star-forming galaxies. A sample spanning all kinds of different morphologies
column3: masses
column4: and structures. Studying this sample can help us to piece together the star-formation history of the Universe.

column1: By exploring how massive stars form and evolve within such galaxies
column2: astronomers can learn more about how
column3: when
column4: and where star formation occurs
column5: how star clusters change over time
column6: and how the process of forming new stars is related to the properties of both the host galaxy and the surrounding interstellar medium (the “stuff” that fills the space between individual stars). This image is formed of observations from Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/87b9a59820a72029c4b07442f5bf0cbd;2017-02-20;833.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36224058765/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4248

column1: 35447327380.0;Hubble Pushed Beyond the Limit for Sharpest-Ever View of Distant Galaxy;When the universe was young
column2: stars formed at a much higher rate than they do today. By peering across billions of light-years of space
column3: Hubble can study this early era. But at such distances
column4: galaxies shrink to smudges that hide key details. Astronomers have teased out those details in one distant galaxy by combining Hubble’s sharp vision with the natural magnifying power of a gravitational lens. The result is an image 10 times better than what Hubble could achieve on its own
column5: showing dense clusters of brilliant
column6: young stars.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/da3391ad1622952bf6779ef206754026;2017-07-06;1075.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35447327380/in/album-72157667717916600;sdssj11106459 sgasj11102006459508

column1: 27412543814.0;Training in the JSC Neutral Buoyancy Lab;"Astronauts Mike Massimino (right) and Mike Good
column2: STS-125 mission specialists

column1: 28503227340.0;A Hubble Sky Full of Stars;"Located approximately 22
column2: 000 light-years away in the constellation of Musca (the Fly)
column3: this tightly packed collection of stars — known as a globular cluster — goes by the name of NGC 4833. This Hubble Space Telescope image shows the dazzling stellar group in all its glory.

column1: NGC 4833 is one of the over 150 globular clusters known to reside within the Milky Way. These objects are thought to contain some of the oldest stars in our galaxy. Studying these ancient cosmic clusters can help astronomers to unravel how a galaxy formed and evolved
column2: and give an idea of the galaxy’s age.

column1: Globular clusters are responsible for some of the most striking sights in the cosmos
column2: with hundreds of thousands of stars congregating in the same region of space. Hubble has observed many of these clusters during its time in orbit around our planet
column3: each as breathtaking as the last.

column1: Image credit: ESA/Hubble and NASA
Text credit: European Space Agency

29251503662.0;An irregular island;"This image
column2: courtesy of the Hubble Space Telescope’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)
column3: captures the glow of distant stars within NGC 5264
column4: a dwarf galaxy located just over 15 million light-years away in the constellation of Hydra (the Sea Serpent).

column1: Dwarf galaxies like NGC 5264 typically possess around a billion stars — just one per cent of the number of stars found within the Milky Way. They are usually found orbiting other
column2: larger
column3: galaxies such as our own
column4: and are thought to form from the material left over from the messy formation of their larger cosmic relatives.

column1: NGC 5264 clearly possesses an irregular shape — unlike the more common spiral or elliptical galaxies — with knots of blue star formation. Astronomers believe that this is due to the gravitational interactions between NGC 5264 and other galaxies nearby. These past flirtations sparked the formation of new generations of stars
column2: which now glow in bright shades of blue.

column1: NASA image use policy.
NASA Hubble Space Telescope

column1: 35414921371.0;Surveying the cosmos;"The object in the middle of this image
column2: sitting alone within a star-studded cosmos
column3: is a galaxy known as ESO 486-21. ESO 486-21 is a spiral galaxy — albeit with a somewhat irregular and ill-defined structure — located some 30 million light-years from Earth.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope observed this object while performing a survey — the Legacy ExtraGalactic UV Survey (LEGUS) — of 50 nearby star-forming galaxies. The LEGUS sample was selected to cover a diverse range of galactic morphologies
column2: star formation rates
column3: galaxy masses
column4: and more. Astronomers use such data to understand how stars form and evolve within clusters
column5: and how these processes affect both their home galaxy and the wider universe. ESO 486-21 is an ideal candidate for inclusion in such a survey as it is known to be in the process of forming new stars
column6: which are created when large clouds of gas and dust (seen here in pink) within the galaxy crumple inwards upon themselves.

column1: LEGUS made use of Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) and Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS). The WFC3 obtained detailed observations of the target objects while the ACS obtained what are known as parallel fields — instead of leaving ACS idle
column2: it was instead trained on a small patch of sky just offset from the target field itself
column3: allowing it to gather additional valuable information while the primary target was being observed by WFC3. Parallel fields played an important role in Hubble’s Frontier Fields program
column4: which used the magnifying power of large galaxy clusters (via a phenomenon known as gravitational lensing) to explore objects in the distant universe.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/5062a74b9c11634543dfa1156e14998c;2016-12-09;556.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35414921371/in/album-72157667717916600;eso48621

column1: 36031715364.0;A double discovery;"NGC 178 may be small
column2: but it packs quite a punch. Measuring around 40
column3: 000 light-years across
column4: its diameter is less than half that of the Milky Way
column5: and it is accordingly classified as a dwarf galaxy. Despite its diminutive size
column6: NGC 178 is busy forming new stars. On average
column7: the galaxy forms stars totaling around half the mass of the Sun per year — enough to label it a starburst galaxy.

column1: The galaxy’s discovery is an interesting
column2: and somewhat confusing
column3: story. It was originally discovered by American astronomer Ormond Stone in 1885 and dubbed NGC 178
column4: but its position in the sky was recorded incorrectly — by accident the value for the galaxy’s right ascension (which can be thought of as the celestial equivalent of terrestrial longitude) was off by a considerable amount.

column1: In the years that followed NGC 178 was spotted again
column2: this time by French astronomer Stéphane Javelle. As no cataloged object occupied that position in the sky
column3: Javelle believed he had discovered a new galaxy and entered it into the expanded Index Catalogue under the name IC 39. Later
column4: American astronomer Herbert Howe also observed the object and corrected Stone’s initial mistake. Many years later
column5: astronomers finally noticed that NGC 178 and IC 39 were actually the same object!

column1: This image of NGC 178 comprises data gathered by the Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 aboard the Hubble Space Telescope.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/f1b691bddb2f5da49f1d4148d1ce09bb;2017-08-21;693.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36031715364/in/album-72157667717916600;ic39 ngc178

column1: 27950259851.0;Quadruple Saturn Moon Transit Snapped By Hubble;"On February 24
column3: the Hubble Space Telescope took a photo of four moons of Saturn passing in front of their parent planet. In this view
column4: the giant orange moon Titan casts a large shadow onto Saturn's north polar hood. Below Titan
column5: near the ring plane and to the left is the moon Mimas
column6: casting a much smaller shadow onto Saturn's equatorial cloud tops. Farther to the left
column7: and off Saturn's disk
column8: are the bright moon Dione and the fainter moon Enceladus.

column1: These rare moon transits only happen when the tilt of Saturn's ring plane is nearly "edge on" as seen from Earth. Saturn's rings were perfectly edge on to our line of sight on August 10
column3: and September 4
column4: 2009. This "ring plane crossing" occurs every 14-15 years. In 1995-96 Hubble witnessed the ring plane crossing event
column5: as well as many moon transits
column6: and even helped discover several new moons of Saturn.

column1: The banded structure in Saturn's atmosphere is similar to Jupiter's.
Early 2009 was a favorable time for viewers with small telescopes to watch moon and shadow transits crossing the face of Saturn. Titan
column2: Saturn's largest moon
column3: crossed Saturn on four separate occasions: January 24
column4: February 9
column5: February 24
column6: and March 12
column7: although not all events were visible from all locations on Earth.

column1: These pictures were taken with Hubble's Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 on February 24
column3: when Saturn was at a distance of roughly 775 million miles (1.25 billion kilometers) from Earth. Hubble can see details as small as 190 miles (300 km) across on Saturn. The dark band running across the face of the planet slightly above the rings is the shadow of the rings cast on the planet.

40396762852.0;The calm after the galactic storm;"The NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope has caught sight of a soft
column2: diffuse-looking galaxy that is probably the aftermath of a long-ago galactic collision. Two spiral galaxies
column3: each perhaps much like the Milky Way
column4: swirled together for millions of years.

column1: In such mergers
column2: the original galaxies are often stretched and pulled apart as they wrap around a common center of gravity. After a few back-and-forths
column3: this starry tempest settles down into a new
column4: round object. The now subdued celestial body
column5: cataloged as SDSS J162702.56+432833.9
column6: is technically known as an elliptical galaxy.

column1: When galaxies collide — a common event in the Universe — a fresh burst of star formation typically takes place as gas clouds mash together. At this point
column2: the galaxy has a blue hue
column3: but the color does not mean it is cold: it is a result of the intense heat of newly formed blue–white stars. Those stars do not last long
column4: and after a few billion years the reddish hues of aging smaller stars dominate an elliptical galaxy's spectrum. Hubble has helped astronomers learn of this sequence by observing galaxy mergers at all stages of the process.

column2: some ribbons of dust notably obscure parts of the conglomerated galaxy's central
column3: bluish region. Those dust lanes could be remnants of the spiral arms of the recently departed galaxies.

column1: This picture was snapped by the Wide Field Camera of Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys. The image was made through a red (F625W) and a blue (F438W) filter. The field of view is approximately 2.4 by 2.4 arcminutes.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/29ae5d8d010fddfe533713cd831a27ee;2011-11-28;1030.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/40396762852/in/album-72157667717916600;sdssj162702564328339
25981690618.0;Doing cartwheels to celebrate the end of an era;"This is an image of the Cartwheel Galaxy taken with the NASA/ESA (European Space Agency) Hubble Space Telescope.
The object was first spotted on wide-field images from the U.K. Schmidt telescope and then studied in detail using the Anglo-Australian Telescope.
Lying about 500 million light-years away in the constellation of Sculptor
column2: the cartwheel shape of this galaxy is the result of a violent galactic collision. A smaller galaxy has passed right through a large disk galaxy and produced shock waves that swept up gas and dust — much like the ripples produced when a stone is dropped into a lake — and sparked regions of intense star formation (appearing blue). The outermost ring of the galaxy
column3: which is 1.5 times the size of our Milky Way
column4: marks the shock wave’s leading edge. This object is one of the most dramatic examples of the small class of ring galaxies.

column1: This image is based on earlier Hubble data of the Cartwheel Galaxy that was reprocessed in 2010
column2: bringing out more detail in the image than seen before.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/64615f03470c34ee5b1962e5074ffbb5;2010-12-27;798.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/25981690618/in/album-72157667717916600;cartwheelgalaxy

27712254573.0;Hubble Space Telescope Assembly;"Engineers and technicians conduct a fit check of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) solar array flight article in a clean room of the Lockheed Missile and Space Company. The solar array is 40 feet (12.1 meters) long and 8.2 feet (2.5 meters) wide
column2: and provides power to the spacecraft.

column1: Hubble was the first of NASA's great observatories and the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made. The purpose of Hubble is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit by placing the telescope in space
column2: enabling astronomers to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere. Hubble was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery (STS-31 mission) into Earth orbit in April 1990.

column1: The Marshall Space Flight Center had overall responsibility for design
column2: development
column3: and construction of the observatory. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury
column4: Connecticut
column5: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. The Lockheed Missile and Space Company
column6: Sunnyvale
column7: California
column8: produced the protective outer shroud and spacecraft systems
column9: and assembled and tested the finished telescope.

column3: Hubble was designed to last approximately 15 years. The Marshall Space Flight Center had management responsibility for the development of Hubble and played a major role in ground tests and orbital checkout of the telescope. Hubble was launched April 24

column1: Photo credit: NASA";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/7ba41582c00e7aa0cc3a1de143de9460;2016-07-01;2622.0;4008.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Deployment;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27410013433/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa hubbledeployment sts31
36323480566.0;Charles Messier;"Although there are as many as one hundred billion comets in the outer regions of the solar system
column2: prior to 1995
column3: only around 900 had ever been discovered. This is because most comets are too dim to be detected without the proper astronomical equipment. Occasionally
column4: however
column5: a comet will sweep past the sun that is bright enough to be seen during the daytime with the naked eye.

column1: One such instance occurred in 1744. Comet Klinkenberg-Chéseaux
column2: discovered by three amateur astronomers in late 1743
column3: grew steadily brighter as it approached the sun. By the end of February 1744
column4: the comet had reached its peak brightness at an apparent magnitude of –7
column5: making it the brightest object in the sky except for the sun and moon. The comet’s brilliance captured the interest of professional and amateur astronomers alike
column6: including a young Charles Messier.

column1: Born in 1730 in Badonviller
column2: France
column3: Messier had to give up formal education at age 11 when his father died. Soon after
column4: he witnessed the spectacular Comet Klinkenberg-Chéseaux
column5: which ignited his passion for astronomy. At the age of 21
column6: Messier was hired as a draftsman for the French navy. He learned to use astronomical tools and became a skilled observer. For his efforts
column7: Messier was eventually promoted to the chief astronomer of the Marine Observatory in Paris
column8: where he pursued his interest in comets. He discovered over a dozen comets
column9: earning him the nickname “Comet Ferret” from King Louis XV.

column2: Messier was in the process of observing one such comet when he was distracted by a cloudy object in the constellation Taurus. Upon further observation
column3: he realized that the object could not be a comet because it was not moving across the sky. In an effort to prevent other astronomers from mistaking the object for a comet
column4: Messier took note of it and began to catalog other comet-like “objects to avoid.”

column1: This comet-like object that Messier observed was NGC 1952. Commonly known today as M1 (Messier 1) or the Crab Nebula
column2: it is the first object in Messier’s Catalog of Nebulae and Star Clusters. By the time of his death in 1817
column3: Messier had compiled a list of 103 objects in the night sky using his own observations with various telescopes and the discoveries of other astronomers. The catalog was revised in the 20th century and now contains 110 objects.

column1: The Messier catalog includes some of the most fascinating astronomical objects that can be observed from Earth’s Northern Hemisphere. Among them are deep-sky objects that can be viewed in stunning detail using larger telescopes but are also bright enough to be seen through a small telescope. This characteristic makes Messier objects extremely popular targets for amateur astronomers possessing all levels of experience and equipment. They are so popular
column2: in fact
column3: that they have inspired a special award from the Astronomical League (an organization for amateur astronomers) given to observers who are able to spot each of these objects. Those who succeed receive a certificate and are given the distinction of being in the Messier Club.

column1: While the Hubble Space Telescope has not produced images of every object in the Messier catalog
column2: it has observed 93 of them as of August 2017. Some of Hubble’s photographs offer views of a given object in its entirety
column3: but many focus on specific areas of interest. While Hubble is able to magnify objects very effectively
column4: it has a relatively small field of view. This means that
column5: in some cases
column6: Hubble would need to take many exposures to capture an entire object. Although this is not always an efficient use of its time
column7: as is the case for the widely spaced “open” star clusters in the Messier catalog
column8: many exposures are taken when the scientific value justifies the time spent. One of these objects is the Andromeda galaxy (designated M31 in Messier’s catalog). In order to create a mosaic image that depicts almost half of Andromeda
column9: Hubble has taken nearly 7
column10: 400 exposures of the galaxy.

column1: Unlike a digital camera that takes a single photograph in red
column2: green and blue light to create a single full-color image
column3: Hubble takes monochrome images at specific wavelengths of light. These specific wavelengths can reveal characteristics of an object that are of scientific interest
column4: such as the presence of a particular chemical element. Multiple observations at different wavelengths can be combined to form a single image that reveals all of these characteristics at once but doesn’t necessarily contain the full spectrum of visible light. In those cases
column5: colors are assigned to each wavelength to highlight the different characteristics
column6: offering a deeper understanding of the object’s properties.

column1: Additionally
column2: Hubble is equipped to take infrared and ultraviolet images
column3: which can reveal information that cannot be obtained using only visible light. Because infrared and ultraviolet light are not visible to human eyes
column4: these images need to be processed in such a way that makes them meaningful to observers. This is done by assigning colors that humans can perceive to the wavelengths that they cannot.

column1: Whether their tool of choice is a sophisticated ground-based telescope
column2: a decent pair of binoculars
column3: or simply their naked eyes
column4: observers hunting for Messier objects can use the data gathered from Hubble’s spectacular images to deepen their understanding of these 110 highlights of the night sky as they carry on the tradition of amateur astronomy.

column1: This album contains some of the best images from Hubble’s Messier catalog taken thus far.
Image Credit: R. Stoyan et al.

27514165564.0;Astronauts Akers and Thornton during installation of COSTAR on HST;Astronaut Thomas D. Akers maneuvers inside the bay which will house the Corrective Optics Space Telescope Axial Replacement (COSTAR) while assisting astronaut Kathryn C. Thornton with the installation of the 640-pound instrument. Thornton
column2: anchored on the end of the Remote Manipulator System (RMS) arm
column3: is partially visible as she prepares to install the COSTAR. The 70mm scene is backdropped against the blue and white Earth and the blackness of space. The two space walkers participated in the mission's second and fourth (of five) extravehicular activities (EVA) designed to service the giant telescope. This photograph was made with a handheld Hasselblad camera from the Space Shuttle Endeavour's cabin.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/0e717789d9b9db362d92b1f6f156d6e6;2012-01-19;640.0;618.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27514165564/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

28049523931.0;Southern Africa as seen from STS-61 Shuttle Endeavour;The entire southern tip of Africa is shown in this high altitude 50mm photograph. The center of the photograph is at approximately 28.0 degrees south and 24.0 degrees east Cape Columbine is at the upper right with Durban at the lower center. The Orange River is at the upper center of the frame. Cape Agulas is the southernmost part of the African continent and is visible toward the upper right corner with the great bays of South Africa trending toward the bottom right. Continuing clockwise along the coast
column2: Durban projects out into the Indian Ocean. The oceanic clouds on the right side of the photograph probably depict a current boundary. The Drakensberg Range on the east
column3: the great Karoo Range to the south and the Karas Mountains on the west surround the drier central plateau. The southern Kalahari Desert is at the upper left of the photograph.v;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/77c82d4ae05b1d6ec73904f1e8b3014b;2010-09-02;4729.0;4632.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28049523931/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

column1: 28223588012.0;View of Hubble after Being Released from the Shuttle Atlantis;An STS-125 crewmember aboard the Space Shuttle Atlantis captured this still image of the Hubble Space Telescope as the two spacecraft continued their relative separation on May 19
column3: after having been linked together for the better part of a week. During the week
column4: five spacewalks were performed to complete the final servicing mission for the orbital observatory. 28025362435.0;Training Session in the Space Vehicle Mockup Facility;An unidentified member of the STS-109 crew uses a device called a Sky genie to simulate rappelling from a troubled shuttle in a training session in the Space Vehicle Mockup Facility at the Johnson Space Center (JSC). The mockup is called the Full Fuselage Trainer (FFT). This exercise trains the crewmembers for procedures to follow in egressing a troubled shuttle on the ground. STS-109 will be the 108th shuttle flight and the fourth Hubble Space Telescope (HST) servicing mission.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/28d6be248e7e6a2fefcd49763b0052b4;2016-07-01;3865.0;2520.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28025362435/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109

column1: 35894531532.0;Hubble Tools on Display during NASA Social;"This case in the Space Telescope Operations Control Center displays hardware and tools used to repair the Hubble Space Telescope during Servicing Mission 4 in 2009.  All of the tools and hardware in this case were used to repair the Advanced Camera for Surveys
column2: which is one of Hubble's workhorse science instruments.

column1: More than 40 of NASA's followers on social media traveled from across the country to attend a NASA Social event on April 23
column3: in celebration of the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope. The day-long event began by attending the unveiling of a 25th anniversary image at a NASA press conference at the Newseum in Washington
column4: DC. The participants then traveled to NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center where they took part in behind-the-scenes tours of different laboratories
column5: ending with a viewing of the Hubble control center and a hands-on demonstration of the tools used during the Hubble servicing missions.

28023938542.0;Crew Insignia;"The mission insignia for NASA's STS-31 mission features the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) in its observing configuration against a background of the universe it will study. The cosmos includes a stylistic depiction of galaxies in recognition of the contribution made by Sir Edwin Hubble to our understanding of the nature of galaxies and the expansion of the universe. The STS-31 crew points out that it is in honor of Hubble?s work ?that this great observatory in space bears his name.? The depicted space shuttle trails a spectrum symbolic of both the red shift observations that were so important to Hubble?s work and new information which will be obtained with the HST. Encircling the artwork
column2: designed by the crew
column3: are the names of its members: Loren J. Shriver
column4: commander; Charles F. Bolden
column5: pilot; and Steven A. Hawley
column6: Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn D. Sullivan
column7: mission specialists.

column1: The NASA insignia design for space shuttle flights is reserved for use by the astronauts and for other official use as the NASA Administrator may authorize. Public availability has been approved only in the form of illustrations by the various news media. When and if there is any change in this policy
column2: which is not anticipated
column3: it will be publicly announced. Photo credit: NASA";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/4c9554b95874caf7f035afd29e8f1e50;2008-09-04;2650.0;3860.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Deployment;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28023938542/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa hubbledeployment sts31

36046793450.0;M51;"The graceful
column2: winding arms of the majestic spiral galaxy M51 appear like a grand spiral staircase sweeping through space. They are actually long lanes of stars and gas laced with dust. Such striking arms are a hallmark of so-called grand-design spiral galaxies. In M51
column3: also known as the Whirlpool galaxy
column4: these arms serve an important purpose: they are star-formation factories
column5: compressing hydrogen gas and creating clusters of new stars.

column1: Some astronomers think that the Whirlpool’s arms are particularly prominent because of the effects of a close encounter with NGC 5195
column2: the small
column3: yellowish galaxy at the outermost tip of one of the arms. The compact galaxy appears to be tugging on the arm
column4: the tidal forces from which trigger new star formation. Hubble’s clear view shows that NGC 5195 is passing behind M51. The small galaxy has been gliding past the Whirlpool for hundreds of millions of years.

column1: In Hubble’s captivating image of M51
column2: the red represents infrared light as well as hydrogen within giant star-forming regions. The blue color can be attributed to hot
column3: young stars while the yellow color is from older stars.

column1: Discovered by Charles Messier in 1773
column2: M51 is located 31 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Canes Venatici. It has an apparent magnitude of 8.4 and can be spotted with a small telescope most easily during May. The Whirlpool galaxy’s beautiful face-on view and closeness to Earth allow astronomers to study a classic spiral galaxy’s structure and star-forming processes.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M51

column1: 27993271906.0;Horsehead Nebula;"Unlike other celestial objects there is no question how the Horsehead Nebula got its name. This iconic silhouette of a horse's head and neck pokes up mysteriously from what look like whitecaps of interstellar foam. The nebula has graced astronomy books ever since its discovery over a century ago. But Hubble's infrared vision shows the horse in a new light.
The nebula
column2: shadowy in optical light
column3: appears transparent and ethereal when seen at infrared wavelengths. This pillar of tenuous hydrogen gas laced with dust is resisting being eroded away by the radiation from a nearby star. The nebula is a small part of a vast star-forming complex in the constellation Orion. The Horsehead will disintegrate in about 5 million years.

column1: As part of Hubble's 23rd anniversary Horsehead Nebula release
column2: amateur astronomers around the world were invited to send in their Horsehead Nebula photos. Visit the Hubble Heritage Horsehead Image Release (heritage.stsci.edu/2013/12/supplemental.html) to view the contributions via Flickr and Tumblr.

column1: 35608246754.0;M17;"Illuminated by ultraviolet radiation from young
column2: massive stars on the right side of this photograph
column4: also known as the Omega Nebula or Swan Nebula
column5: is one of the largest star-forming regions in the Milky Way galaxy. Hubble’s stunning image of a central portion of the nebula has been colorized to highlight certain wavelengths of light. Green represents oxygen while red reveals hydrogen and infrared light.

column1: The Omega Nebula was discovered in 1745 by the Swiss astronomer Jean-Philippe Loys de Chéseaux. It is located 5
column2: 500 light-years from Earth in the constellation Sagittarius. The nebula has an apparent magnitude of 6 and can be seen with a pair of binoculars. M17
column3: which appears near M16 and M18 in the sky
column4: is best viewed on clear nights in August.

column1: M17 contains one of our galaxy's youngest star clusters
column2: at only 1 million years old. However
column3: many of the young stars in this cluster are impossible to see because of the gas and dust that surrounds them. The powerful radiation from the young stars evaporates and erodes the dense clouds of cold gas in which new stars form. One such pocket of gas is seen at the center of the brightest region of the nebula (near the bottom of this image) and is about 10 times larger than our solar system. Other dense pockets of gas have formed the remarkable dark features jutting inward from the bottom left corner of the image.

column1: 36323997986.0;M13;"Like shiny flakes sparkling in a snow globe
column2: over 100
column3: 000 stars whirl within the globular cluster M13
column4: one of the brightest star clusters visible from the Northern Hemisphere. Located 25
column5: 000 light-years from Earth with an apparent magnitude of 5.8
column6: this glittering metropolis of stars in the constellation Hercules can be spotted with a pair of binoculars most easily in July.

column1: The English astronomer Edmond Halley
column2: best known for recognizing the periodicity of the comet that bears his name
column3: discovered M13 in 1714. When Charles Messier added M13 to his catalog in 1764
column4: he was convinced that the nebulous object did not contain any stars at all. Because they are so densely packed together
column5: the cluster’s individual stars were not resolved until 1779. Near the core of this cluster
column6: the density of the stellar population is about a hundred times greater than the density in the neighborhood of our sun. These stars are so crowded that they can
column7: at times
column8: run into each other and even form a new star. The resulting “blue stragglers” appear to be younger than the other stars in their immediate vicinity and are of great scientific interest to astronomers.

column1: Hubble’s composite image of this cluster’s core was created using observations taken between 1999 and 2006 in both visible and infrared wavelengths.
For more information about Hubble’s observations of M13

column1: 36467813655.0;M82;"M82 or the Cigar galaxy
column2: shines brightly at infrared wavelengths and is remarkable for its star formation activity. The Cigar galaxy experiences gravitational interactions with its galactic neighbor
column4: causing it to have an extraordinarily high rate of star formation — a starburst.

column1: Around the galaxy’s center
column2: young stars are being born 10 times faster than they are inside our entire Milky Way galaxy. Radiation and energetic particles from these newborn stars carve into the surrounding gas
column3: and the resulting galactic wind compresses enough gas to make millions of more stars. The rapid rate of star formation in this galaxy eventually will be self-limiting. When star formation becomes too vigorous
column4: it will consume or destroy the material needed to make more stars. The starburst will then subside
column5: probably in a few tens of millions of years.

column1: M82 was discovered
column2: along with its neighbor M81
column3: by the German astronomer Johann Elert Bode in 1774. Located 12 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Ursa Major
column4: M82 has an apparent magnitude of 8.4 and is best observed in April. Although it is visible as a patch of light with binoculars in the same field of view as M81
column5: larger telescopes are needed in order to resolve the galaxy’s core.

column1: This stunning Hubble image of M82 was assembled using observations at different wavelengths. The red in the image represents hydrogen and infrared light
column2: indicating starburst activity. The blue and greenish-yellow color represent visible wavelengths of light.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M82

column1: 36071385720.0;M104;"This stunning Hubble image of M104
column2: also known as the Sombrero galaxy
column3: is one of the largest mosaics ever assembled from Hubble observations. The hallmark of the nearly edge-on galaxy is a brilliant
column4: white
column5: bulbous core encircled by thick dust lanes comprising the spiral structure of the galaxy. This dust lane is the site of star formation in the galaxy. The center of M104 is thought to be home to a massive black hole.

column1: Hubble easily resolves the Sombrero galaxy’s rich system of globular clusters
column2: estimated to be nearly 2
column3: 000 in number — 10 times more than the number of globular clusters in our Milky Way galaxy. The ages of the clusters are similar to those in the Milky Way
column4: ranging from 10-13 billion years old. Embedded in the bright core of M104 is a smaller disk (not visible in the image)
column5: which is tilted relative to the large disk. X-ray emission suggests that there is material falling into the compact core
column6: where a one-billion-solar-mass black hole resides.

column1: With an apparent magnitude of 8
column2: the Sombrero galaxy is beyond the limit of naked-eye visibility but can be spotted through small telescopes most easily during May. M104 is located 28 million light-years away in the constellation Virgo
column3: and with a mass equal to 800 billion suns
column4: it is one of the most massive objects in the Virgo galaxy cluster.

column1: M104 was discovered in 1781 by the French astronomer and comet hunter Pierre Méchain
column2: one of Charles Messier’s colleagues.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observation of M104

35677890493.0;M92;"This Hubble image of M92’s core is a composite made using observations at visible and infrared wavelengths. Located 27
column2: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Hercules
column3: this globular cluster — a ball of stars that orbits our galaxy’s core like a satellite — was first discovered by the German astronomer Johann Elert Bode in 1777.

column1: With an apparent magnitude of 6.3
column2: M92 is one of the brightest globular clusters in the Milky Way and is visible to the naked eye under good observing conditions. It can be most easily spotted during the month of July. The cluster is very tightly packed with stars
column3: containing roughly 330
column4: 000 stars in total.

column1: As is characteristic of ancient globular clusters — of which M92 is one of the oldest — the predominant elements within M92 are hydrogen and helium
column2: with only traces of others
column3: so it belongs to a group of metal-poor clusters. To astronomers
column4: metals are all elements heavier than hydrogen and helium.

27411554403.0;Sun set over Java Sea;One of the astronauts aboard the Space Shuttle Columbia photographed this west-looking view featuring the profile of the atmosphere and the setting sun. The shuttle was located over the Java Sea to the south of Kalimantan (Borneo) in Indonesia when this image was acquired. Visible to the right of the setting sun are cloud tops from some thunderstorms. The sun's reflection (bright spot over the setting sun) can be seen off the upper layers of the earth's atmosphere.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/2349b577c07c54cc183f732a0eaa7288;2016-07-01;1960.0;2956.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27411554403/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109
35878911916.0;Just like home;"Discovered by British astronomer William Herschel over 200 years ago
column2: NGC 2500 lies about 30  million light-years away in the northern constellation of Lynx. As this Hubble Space Telescope image shows
column3: NGC 2500 is a particular kind of spiral galaxy known as a barred spiral
column4: its wispy arms swirling out from a bright
column5: elongated core.

column1: Barred spirals are actually more common than was once thought. Around two-thirds of all spiral galaxies — including the Milky Way — exhibit these straight bars cutting through their centers. These cosmic structures act as glowing nurseries for newborn stars
column2: and funnel material towards the active core of a galaxy. NGC 2500 is still actively forming new stars
column3: although this process appears to be occurring very unevenly. The upper half of the galaxy — where the spiral arms are slightly better defined — hosts many more star-forming regions than the lower half
column4: as indicated by the bright
column5: dotted islands of light.

column1: There is another similarity between NGC 2500 and our home galaxy. Together with Andromeda
column2: Triangulum
column3: and many smaller natural satellites
column4: the Milky Way is part of the Local Group of galaxies
column5: a gathering of over 50 galaxies all loosely held together by gravity. NGC 2500 forms a similar group with some of its nearby neighbors
column6: including NGC 2541
column7: NGC 2552
column8: NGC 2537
column9: and the bright
column10: Andromeda-like spiral NGC 2481 (known collectively as the NGC 2841 group).";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/53b03b86f1d4fc05295db33a8087cc91;2217-02-10;961.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35878911916/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc2500

column1: 35667298284.0;Small but significant;"The subject of this Hubble Space Telescope image is a dwarf galaxy named NGC 5949. Thanks to its proximity to Earth — it sits at a distance of around 44 million light-years from us
column2: placing it within the Milky Way’s cosmic neighborhood — NGC 5949 is a perfect target for astronomers to study dwarf galaxies.

column1: With a mass of about a hundredth that of the Milky Way
column2: NGC 5949 is a relatively bulky example of a dwarf galaxy. Its classification as a dwarf is due to its relatively small number of constituent stars
column3: but the galaxy’s loosely bound spiral arms also place it in the category of barred spirals. This structure is just visible in this image
column4: which shows the galaxy as a bright yet ill-defined pinwheel. Despite its small proportions
column5: NGC 5949’s proximity has meant that its light can be picked up by fairly small telescopes
column6: something that facilitated its discovery by the astronomer William Herschel in 1801.

column1: Astronomers have run into several cosmological quandaries when it comes to dwarf galaxies like NGC 5949. For example
column2: the distribution of dark matter within dwarfs is quite puzzling (the “cuspy halo” problem)
column3: and our simulations of the universe predict that there should be many more dwarf galaxies than we see around us (the “missing satellites” problem).";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/52324e17e6d018da32f8f13006b1f6e0;2017-02-21;543.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35667298284/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc5949

column1: 35447339160.0;Hubble’s Hidden Galaxy;"IC 342 is a challenging cosmic target. Although it is bright
column2: the galaxy sits near the equator of the Milky Way’s galactic disk
column3: where the sky is thick with glowing cosmic gas
column4: bright stars
column5: and dark
column6: obscuring dust. In order for astronomers to see the intricate spiral structure of IC 342
column7: they must gaze through a large amount of material contained within our own galaxy — no mean feat! As a result IC 342 is relatively difficult to spot and image
column8: giving rise to its intriguing nickname: the “Hidden Galaxy.”

column1: Located very close (in astronomical terms) to the Milky Way
column2: this sweeping spiral galaxy would be among the brightest in the sky were it not for its dust-obscured location. The galaxy is very active
column3: as indicated by the range of colors visible in this Hubble Space Telescope image
column4: depicting the very central region of the galaxy. A beautiful mixture of hot
column5: blue star-forming regions
column6: redder
column7: cooler regions of gas
column8: and dark lanes of opaque dust can be seen
column9: all swirling together around a bright core. In 2003
column10: astronomers confirmed this core to be a specific type of central region known as an HII nucleus — a name that indicates the presence of ionized hydrogen — that is likely to be creating many hot new stars.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/4a5a86d530e9693e8993de0f69dee821;2016-12-09;1053.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35447339160/in/album-72157667717916600;ic342

column1: 36066755825.0;Dim and diffuse;"Tucked away in the small northern constellation of Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs) is the galaxy NGC 4242
column2: shown here as seen by the Hubble Space Telescope. The galaxy lies some 30 million light-years from us. At this distance from Earth
column3: actually not all that far on a cosmic scale
column4: NGC 4242 is visible to anyone armed with even a basic telescope (as British astronomer William Herschel found when he discovered the galaxy in 1788).

column1: This image shows the galaxy’s bright center and the surrounding dimmer and more diffuse “fuzz.” Despite appearing to be relatively bright in this image
column2: studies have found that NGC 4242 is actually relatively dim (it has a moderate-to-low surface brightness and low luminosity) and also supports a low rate of star formation. The galaxy also seems to have a weak bar of stars cutting through its asymmetric center
column3: and a very faint and poorly defined spiral structure throughout its disk. But if NGC 4242 is not all that remarkable
column4: as with much of the universe
column5: it is still a beautiful and ethereal sight.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/5ddd3224156cfe85a6c839d2f319de72;2017-01-24;920.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36066755825/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4242

column2: the final frontier;"Celebrating its 50th anniversary in 2016
column3: the TV series "Star Trek" has captured the public’s imagination with the signature phrase
column4: "To boldly go where no one has gone before." NASA's Hubble Space Telescope doesn't "boldly go" deep into space
column5: but it is "boldly peering" deeper into the universe than ever before to explore the warping of space and time and uncover some of the farthest objects ever seen.

column1: When "Star Trek" was first broadcast in 1966
column2: the largest telescopes on Earth could only see about halfway across the universe - the rest was uncharted territory. But Hubble's powerful vision has carried us into the true "final frontier."

column1: This is epitomized in the latest Hubble image released today in time for the new motion picture "Star Trek Beyond." The Hubble image unveils a very cluttered-looking universe filled with galaxies near and far. Some are distorted like a funhouse mirror through a warping-of-space phenomenon first predicted by Einstein a century ago.
In the center of the image is the immense galaxy cluster Abell S1063
column2: located 4 billion light-years away
column3: and surrounded by magnified images of galaxies much farther.

column1: Thanks to Hubble's exquisite sharpness
column2: the photo unveils the effect of space warping due to gravity. The huge mass of the cluster distorts and magnifies the light from galaxies that lie far behind it due to an effect called gravitational lensing. This phenomenon allows Hubble to see galaxies that would otherwise be too small and faint to observe. This "warp field" makes it possible to get a peek at the very first generation of galaxies. Already
column3: an infant galaxy has been found in the field
column4: as it looked 1 billion years after the big bang.

column1: This frontier image provides a sneak peak of the early universe
column2: and gives us a taste of what the James Webb Space Telescope will be capable of seeing in greater detail when it launches in 2018.

column1: The cluster contains approximately 100 million-million solar masses
column2: and contains 51 confirmed galaxies and perhaps over 400 more.

column1: The Frontier Fields program is an ambitious three-year effort
column2: begun in 2013
column3: that teams Hubble with NASA's other Great Observatories - the Spitzer Space Telescope and the Chandra X-ray Observatory - to probe the early universe by studying large galaxy lusters. Identifying the magnified images of background galaxies within these clusters will help astronomers to improve their models of the distribution of both ordinary and dark matter in the galaxy cluster. This is key to understanding the mysterious nature of dark matter that comprises most of the mass of the universe.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope is a project of international cooperation between NASA and the European Space Agency. NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt
column2: Maryland
column3: manages the telescope. The Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore
column4: Maryland
column5: conducts Hubble science operations. STScI is operated for NASA by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy in Washington
column6: D.C.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/f847220033761f7518dc1363102086be;2016-07-21;784.0;700.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/24116318888/in/album-72157667717916600;abells1063

column1: 28075620959.0;Cosmic search for a missing limb;This new Picture of the Week
column2: taken by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope
column3: shows the dwarf galaxy NGC 4625
column4: located about 30 million light-years away in the constellation of Canes Venatici (The Hunting Dogs). The image
column5: acquired with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)
column6: reveals the single spiral arm of the galaxy
column7: which gives it an asymmetric appearance. But why is there only one spiral arm
column8: when spiral galaxies normally have at least two? Astronomers looked at NGC 4625 in different wavelengths in the hope of solving this cosmic mystery. Observations in the ultraviolet provided the first hint: in ultraviolet light the disc of the galaxy appears four times larger than on the image depicted here. An indication that there are a large number of very young and hot — hence mainly visible in the ultraviolet — stars forming in the outer regions of the galaxy. These young stars are only around one billion years old
column9: about 10 times younger than the stars seen in the optical centre. At first astronomers assumed that this high star formation rate was being triggered by the interaction with another
column10: nearby dwarf galaxy called NGC 4618. They speculated that NGC 4618 may be the culprit “harassing” NGC 4625
column11: causing it to lose all but one spiral arm. In 2004 astronomers found proof for this claim: The gas in the outermost regions of the dwarf galaxy NGC 4618 has been strongly affected by NGC 4625.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/1a4ec8c2df41160c221bebb858b61850;2017-06-09;555.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28075620959/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc4625

column1: 40137114932.0;The loneliest firework display;Roughly 50 million light-years away lies a somewhat overlooked little galaxy named NGC 1559. Pictured here by Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3
column2: this barred spiral lies in the little-observed southern constellation of Reticulum (The Reticule). NGC 1559 has massive spiral arms chock-full of star formation
column3: and is receding from us at a speed of about 1300 km/s. The galaxy contains the mass of around ten billion Suns — while this may sound like a lot
column4: that is almost 100 times less massive than the Milky Way. Although NGC 1559 appears to sit near one of our nearest neighbors in the sky — the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC)
column5: this is just a trick of perspective. In reality
column6: NGC 1559 is physically nowhere near the LMC in space — in fact
column7: it truly is a loner
column8: lacking the company of any nearby galaxies or membership of any galaxy cluster. Despite its lack of cosmic companions
column9: when this lonely galaxy has a telescope pointed in its direction
column10: it puts on quite a show! NGC 1559 has hosted a variety of spectacular exploding stars called supernovae
column11: four of which we have observed — in 1984
column18: with an unusually long plateau]). NGC 1559 may be alone in space
column19: but we are watching and admiring from far away.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/c901bebd90ab66c16bac8b216f59b9ce;2018-02-05;1020.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/40137114932/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc1559

column1: 39855008721.0;Explosive tendencies;Don’t be fooled! The subject of this Picture of the Week
column3: may seem tranquil and unassuming
column4: but this spiral galaxy actually displays some explosive tendencies. In October of 2011
column5: a cataclysmic burst of high-energy gamma-ray radiation — known as a gamma-ray burst
column6: or GRB — was detected coming from the region of sky containing ESO 580-49. Astronomers believe that the galaxy was the host of the GRB
column7: given that the chance of a coincidental alignment between the two is roughly 1 in 10 million. At a distance of around 185 million light-years from Earth
column8: it was the second-closest gamma-ray burst (GRB) ever detected. Gamma-ray bursts are among the brightest events in the cosmos
column9: occasionally outshining the combined gamma-ray output of the entire observable Universe for a few seconds. The exact cause of the GRB that probably occurred within this galaxy
column10: catalogued as GRB 111005A
column11: remains a mystery. Several events are known to lead to GRBs
column12: but none of these explanations appear to fit the bill in this case. Astronomers have therefore suggested that ESO 580-49 hosted a new type of GRB explosion — one that has not yet been characterised.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/176dc3123415224a62e5454df1fe95c3;2017-12-04;728.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/39855008721/in/album-72157667717916600;eso58049

column1: 36046884770.0;M60;"The Virgo cluster is a collection of more than 1
column2: 300 galaxies
column3: including the elliptical galaxy M60. Unlike spiral galaxies
column4: elliptical galaxies lack an organized structure and are nearly featureless
column5: resembling the core of a spiral galaxy. The Virgo cluster’s third brightest member
column6: M60 has a diameter of 120
column7: 000 light-years and is as massive as one trillion suns. At its center lies a huge black hole
column8: 4.5 billion times as massive as the sun — one of the most massive black holes ever found.

column1: In this stunning image
column2: which includes observations taken in infrared and visible wavelengths
column3: Hubble has captured M60 (the large
column4: diffuse galaxy at the center) along with the bluish spiral galaxy NGC 4647 (upper right). NGC 4647 is about two-thirds the size of M60 — or roughly the size of the Milky Way galaxy — and is much less massive. The two galaxies form a pair known as Arp 116.

column1: Astronomers have long tried to determine whether these two galaxies are actually interacting. Although from Earth they appear to overlap
column2: there is no evidence of new star formation
column3: which would be one of the clearest signs that the two galaxies are indeed interacting. However
column4: recent studies of very detailed Hubble images suggest the onset of some tidal interaction between the two.

column1: Discovered by the German astronomer Johann Gottfried Keohler in 1779
column2: M60 is located in the constellation Virgo roughly 54 million light-years from Earth. It has an apparent magnitude of 9.8
column3: and its central region can be seen through a small telescope most easily during May. A larger telescope can reveal NGC 4647 as well.

column1: 36046904880.0;M64;"Easily identified by the spectacular band of absorbing dust partially obscuring its bright nucleus
column3: or the Black Eye galaxy
column4: is characterized by its bizarre internal motion. The gas in the outer regions of this remarkable galaxy is rotating in the opposite direction from the gas and stars in its inner regions. This strange behavior can be attributed to a merger between M64 and a satellite galaxy over a billion years ago.

column1: New stars are forming in the region where the oppositely rotating gases collide
column2: are compressed
column3: and then contract. Particularly noticeable in this stunning Hubble image of the galaxy’s core are hot
column4: blue stars that have just formed
column5: along with pink clouds of glowing hydrogen gas that fluoresce when exposed to ultraviolet light from newly formed stars.

column1: M64 was discovered by the English astronomer Edward Pigott. It is located 17 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Coma Berenices and is best observed in May. With an apparent magnitude of 9.8
column2: the Black Eye galaxy can be spotted with a moderately sized telescope.

36314429332.0;M54;"This beautiful visible and infrared Hubble image shows what could be just another globular cluster
column2: but this dense group of stars known as M54 was the first globular cluster found outside our galaxy. M54 belongs to a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way called the Sagittarius Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy. When Charles Messier discovered M54 in 1778
column3: he did not know that the cluster belonged to another galaxy.

column1: Even though M54 is now understood to lie outside the Milky Way
column2: it will become part of our galaxy in the future. The strong gravitational pull of our large galaxy is slowly engulfing the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy
column3: which will eventually merge with the Milky Way to create one larger galaxy.

column1: M54 is located roughly 90
column2: 000 light-years from Earth. It has an apparent magnitude of 8.4 and can be spotted in the constellation Sagittarius most easily during August. Binoculars will resolve a small patch of light in the sky
column3: but larger telescopes are needed to resolve individual stars.

35608372164.0;M27;"Spotted by Charles Messier in 1764
column2: M27 was the first planetary nebula ever discovered. The term “planetary nebula” is a bit of a misnomer based on the nebula’s round
column3: planet-like appearance when viewed through smaller telescopes. The nebula is the result of an old star that has shed its outer layers in a glowing display of color. In Hubble’s image
column4: which shows a small portion of M27
column5: blue represents oxygen
column6: green represents hydrogen
column7: and red indicates sulfur and nitrogen.

column1: M27 hosts many knots of gas and dust. As depicted in Hubble’s image
column2: some look like fingers pointing at the central star
column3: located just off the upper left of the image; others are isolated clouds
column4: some with and some without tails. Their sizes typically range from 17 billion to 56 billion kilometers
column5: which is several times larger than the distance from the sun to Pluto. Each contains as much mass as three Earths.

column1: These dense knots of gas and dust seem to be a natural part of the evolution of planetary nebulas. They form when the stellar winds are not powerful enough to blow away a larger clump of matter but are able to blow away smaller particles
column2: creating a trail behind the clump. The shapes of these knots change as the nebula expands. Similar knots have been discovered in other nearby planetary nebulas that are all part of the same evolutionary scheme.

column1: Also known as the Dumbbell Nebula
column2: M27 resides more than 1
column3: 200 light-years away in the constellation Vulpecula. With an apparent magnitude of 7.5
column4: the nebula can be spotted with a small telescope most easily in September.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M27

36046656070.0;M32;"Hubble has captured nearly 8
column2: 000 blue stars swirling around the core of M32 like a blizzard of snowflakes. This elliptical galaxy is located 2.5 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Andromeda and is one of two satellite galaxies orbiting M31
column3: the Andromeda galaxy.

column1: The first ultraviolet observations of elliptical galaxies showed that they were surprisingly bright when viewed in ultraviolet light. This image of a part of M32 was created from ultraviolet observations with Hubble and provides evidence that the ultraviolet light comes from a population of extremely hot
column2: helium-burning stars at a late stage in their lives. Unlike the sun
column3: which burns hydrogen into helium
column4: these old stars exhausted their central hydrogen long ago and now burn helium into heavier elements.

column1: M32 was discovered by the French astronomer Guillaume Le Gentil in 1749 and is best observed in November. The galaxy has an apparent magnitude of 8.1
column2: and can be seen using a medium-sized telescope. It is relatively easy to locate
column3: as it falls in the same field of view as M31

column1: 36334232972.0;M28;"M28 is a globular cluster located 17
column2: 900 light-years away from Earth in the constellation Sagittarius. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. With an apparent magnitude of 7.7
column3: the cluster appears as a faint patch of light through a pair of binoculars. Large telescopes can resolve its individual stars more effectively. The month of August is the best time to view M28.

column1: The cluster is most notable for being the first of its kind known to contain a millisecond pulsar: PSR B1821–24. This dense neutron star rotates rapidly (about once every three milliseconds) and emits radiation from its poles
column2: which sweeps past Earth as the star spins
column3: much like a beam of light from a lighthouse. This makes it appear to be pulsing to observers on Earth. PSR B1821–24 was discovered in 1986 using a radio telescope in England called the Lovell Telescope.

column1: This Hubble image of M28’s center was assembled from observations taken at visible
column2: infrared and ultraviolet wavelengths.

column1: 36456205756.0;M49;"The elliptical galaxy M49 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1771. Not only was it the first object discovered in the Virgo Cluster of galaxies
column2: but it was also the first elliptical galaxy detected outside of the Milky Way’s Local Group. Unlike spiral galaxies that have well-defined structures and picturesque spiral arms
column3: elliptical galaxies are fairly featureless with little structure. The stars in elliptical galaxies are usually much older than those in spiral galaxies. M49 also contains a rich collection of globular star clusters — nearly 6

column1: This Hubble image of M49 was created using observations at infrared wavelengths. There is an X-ray source at the core of the galaxy
column2: indicating that a supermassive black hole lurks at the center of M49. The estimated mass of this supermassive black hole is roughly 565 million times the mass of our sun.

column1: M49 is located 60 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Virgo. It has an apparent magnitude of 9.4 and can be observed using a pair of binoculars. The best time to observe the galaxy is during the month of May.

column1: 36440418266.0;M99;"This Hubble image
column2: combining visible
column3: infrared and ultraviolet observations
column4: shows a detailed view of the spiral arms on one side of the galaxy M99. This galaxy is called a grand-design spiral
column5: with long
column6: large and clearly defined spiral arms — giving it a structure somewhat similar to our home galaxy
column7: the Milky Way.

column1: M99 was discovered by the French astronomer Pierre Méchain in 1781. The galaxy is located 55 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Coma Berenices and has an apparent magnitude of 10.4. It can be seen using a moderately sized telescope most easily in May.

A number of unexplained phenomena in M99 have been studied by astronomers. Among these is the nature of PTF 10fqs — one of the brighter stars in this image and visible as a yellow-orange star in the top-left corner. What is unusual about PTF 10fqs is that it has so far defied classification. When it was discovered in April 2010
column2: it appeared brighter than a nova (caused by an eruption on a star’s surface) but fainter than a supernova (the explosion that marks the end of life for a large star). Scientists have offered a number of possible explanations
column3: including the intriguing suggestion that the star’s increased brightness could have been caused by a giant planet plunging into its parent star.

column1: This Hubble image was made in June 2010
column2: during the period when the outburst from PTF 10fqs was fading
column3: so the star’s location could be pinpointed with great precision. These measurements will allow other telescopes to home in on the star in future
column4: even when the afterglow of the outburst has faded away completely.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M99

39878609565.0;M86;"Located in the constellation Virgo
column2: M86 is either an elliptical galaxy or a lenticular galaxy (a cross between an elliptical and spiral galaxy). This Hubble observation of M86 was taken in near-infrared and visible light using the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 and the Advanced Camera for Surveys. Featuring about half of the galaxy
column3: it shows the bright central nucleus and surrounding regions of light. The image also reveals globular clusters in M86 (shown as points of light) and an edge-on galaxy (found to the lower left of M86's core).

column1: M86 was discovered in 1781 by Charles Messier and is one of the brightest members of the Virgo cluster of galaxies. It contains approximately 3
column2: 800 globular clusters.

column1: While the majority of the Virgo cluster is receding from the Milky Way
column2: M86 is getting closer to our galaxy. This is because M86 is located on the far side of the Virgo cluster from us and is moving toward the center of the cluster. Of all the galaxies in Messier's catalog
column3: M86 is moving the fastest in our direction but is still approximately 52 million light-years away from Earth.

column1: The best time of the year to view M86 is during May. Having a magnitude of 9.2
column2: M86 can be seen near fellow galaxies in the Virgo cluster with binoculars and small telescopes
column3: with M84 often appearing alongside M86 in the field of view. Telescopes that are 8 inches or larger will reveal several other
column4: fainter galaxies in the same field of view.

column1: Hubble took these observations to help astronomers study the cores of early-type galaxies
column2: which are often old elliptical or lenticular galaxies found toward the centers of galaxy clusters. By studying the cores of these galaxies
column3: astronomers can determine their central structure and analyze both the history of the galaxy and the formation of its core.

column1: 36422343866.0;M96;"In this infrared and visible-light image from Hubble
column2: the spiral galaxy M96 resembles a giant maelstrom of glowing gas
column3: rippled with dark dust that swirls inward toward the nucleus. Its dust and gas are unevenly spread throughout its weak spiral arms
column4: which are asymmetrical because of its gravitational interaction with neighboring galaxies. M96 is also remarkable for the location of its core
column5: which is not exactly at the galactic center.

column1: Because it is gravitationally bound to nearby galaxies
column2: M96 is considered a member of a galaxy group. This collection of galaxies
column3: known as the M96 Group
column4: also includes the bright galaxies M105 and M95
column5: as well as a number of smaller and fainter members. It is the nearest group to Earth containing both bright spirals and a bright elliptical galaxy.

column1: M96 was discovered in 1781 by Charles Messier’s colleague Pierre Méchain. It is located 35 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Leo. The galaxy has an apparent magnitude of 10.1 and appears very dim in the sky. It can be observed using a medium-sized telescope most easily during April.

25902696767.0;M88;"Located approximately 47 million light-years away
column2: M88 is a spiral galaxy with well-defined and symmetrical arms. Although it is a member of the Virgo cluster of galaxies
column3: it appears in the neighboring constellation of Coma Berenices.

column1: M88 contains an active galactic nucleus
column2: meaning the central region of the galaxy is more luminous than the rest of the galaxy. At the galaxy's core resides a supermassive black hole estimated to be 100 million times more massive than our Sun. M88 contains around 400 billion stars and is traveling away from our galaxy.

column1: Charles Messier discovered M88 in 1781 on the same night that he discovered eight other Messier objects. Today
column2: it can be observed with binoculars under clear viewing conditions. Smaller telescopes will reveal an elongated object with a brighter core
column3: while larger telescopes will unveil further details
column4: such as a more defined core. M88 has a magnitude of 9.5 and is best observed in May.

column1: This Hubble observation was taken using the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 with a single visible-light filter. With Hubble
column2: observations in multiple filters are needed to produce color images
column3: so this image is in black and white only. Nearly half of the galaxy is shown in this Hubble view. Hubble took these observations as part of a survey of spiral galaxies to better assess the properties of spiral galaxies
column4: including their galactic cores
column5: their globular cluster populations
column6: and the occurrence of multiple and off-centered nuclei.

column1: 36330971981.0;M91;"The spiral galaxy M91 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1781. It was the last of the nine objects (M84—M92) that Messier added to his catalog on a single night in March. Located 60 million light-years from Earth with an apparent magnitude of only 11
column2: M91 is one of the faintest objects in Messier’s catalog. It can be spotted with medium-sized telescopes in the constellation Coma Berenices most easily during May.

column1: M91 is one of over a thousand galaxies that make up the Virgo cluster — a group of galaxies that are gravitationally bound to one another. It is an anemic galaxy
column2: meaning that it has a lower rate of star formation compared to other spiral galaxies.

column1: This image is composed of Hubble observations taken in visible and infrared light. It captures a small portion of M91
column2: highlighting the galaxy’s lack of red-colored star-forming regions. These regions of molecular hydrogen are common in other spiral galaxies.

column1: 39878610645.0;M98;"This image of M98 was taken in 1995 with Hubble's Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2. Its stair-step pattern results from the design of the camera. These observations were taken in infrared and visible light and feature a portion of the galaxy near the central core. Although it is a member of the Virgo cluster of galaxies
column2: M98 appears in the neighboring constellation of Coma Berenices. Hubble's observations of M98 were part of an examination of the cores of galaxies in the Virgo cluster.

column1: M98 contains about a trillion stars as well as an abundance of neutral hydrogen gas and interstellar dust. Because of the high amounts of gas and dust
column2: there are numerous star-forming regions in the galaxy
column3: especially in its nucleus and arms. The nucleus itself is "active
column4: " meaning that the center of the galaxy is more luminous than the rest of the galaxy. M98 is located approximately 44 million light-years away and is traveling toward our Milky Way galaxy.

column1: M98 was discovered in 1781 by Pierre Méchain
column2: a colleague of Charles Messier
column3: and is one of the faintest objects in Messier's catalog. It has a magnitude of 10.1
column4: and observers will need at least a medium-sized telescope to see M98 well. The best time to observe this galaxy is in May.
