27747555160.0;Butterfly Nebula;"This celestial object looks like a delicate butterfly. But it is far from serene.
What resemble dainty butterfly wings are actually roiling cauldrons of gas heated to more than 36
column2: 000 degrees Fahrenheit. The gas is tearing across space at more than 600
column3: 000 miles an hour – fast enough to travel from Earth to the Moon in 24 minutes!

column1: A dying star that was once about five times the mass of the Sun is at the center of this fury. It has ejected its envelope of gases and is now unleashing a stream of ultraviolet radiation that is making the cast-off material glow. This object is an example of a planetary nebula
column2: so-named because many of them have a round appearance resembling that of a planet when viewed through a small telescope.

column1: The Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) aboard NASA's Hubble Space Telescope snapped this image of the planetary nebula
column2: cataloged as NGC 6302
column3: but more popularly called the Bug Nebula or the Butterfly Nebula. WFC3 was installed by NASA astronauts in May 2009
column4: during the servicing mission to upgrade and repair the 19-year-old Hubble telescope.

column1: NGC 6302 lies within our Milky Way galaxy
column2: roughly 3
column3: 800 light-years away in the constellation Scorpius. The glowing gas is the star's outer layers
column4: expelled over about 2
column5: 200 years. The "butterfly" stretches for more than two light-years
column6: which is about half the distance from the Sun to the nearest star
column7: Alpha Centauri.

column1: 27950248711.0;2014 Hubble Image of the Pillars of Creation;"NASA's Hubble Space Telescope revisited the famous Pillars of Creation
column2: revealing a sharper and wider view of the structures in this visible-light image.

column1: Astronomers combined several Hubble exposures to assemble the wider view. The towering pillars are about 5 light-years tall. The dark
column2: finger-like feature at bottom right may be a smaller version of the giant pillars. The image was taken with Hubble's versatile and sharp-eyed Wide Field Camera 3.

column1: The pillars are bathed in the blistering ultraviolet light from a grouping of young
column2: massive stars located off the top of the image. Streamers of gas can be seen bleeding off the pillars as the intense radiation heats and evaporates it into space. Denser regions of the pillars are shadowing material beneath them from the powerful radiation. Stars are being born deep inside the pillars
column3: which are made of cold hydrogen gas laced with dust. The pillars are part of a small region of the Eagle Nebula (also known as Messier 16)
column4: a vast star-forming region 6
column5: 500 light-years from Earth.

column1: The colors in the image highlight emission from several chemical elements. Oxygen emission is blue
column2: sulfur is orange
column3: and hydrogen and nitrogen are green.

column1: 28248653761.0;STS-31 Mission Onboard Photograph-Hubble Space Telescope;In this photograph
column2: the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) was being deployed on April 25
column3: 1990. The photograph was taken by the IMAX Cargo Bay Camera (ICBC) mounted in a container on the port side of the Space Shuttle orbiter Discovery (STS-31 mission). The purpose of the HST
column4: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column5: is to study the cosmos from a low-Earth orbit for 15 years or more. The HST provides fine detail imaging
column6: produces ultraviolet images and spectra
column7: and detects very faint objects. Two months after its deployment in space
column8: scientists detected a 2-micron spherical aberration in the primary mirror of the HST that affected the telescope's ability to focus faint light sources into a precise point. This imperfection was very slight
column9: one-fiftieth of the width of a human hair. A scheduled Space Service servicing mission (STS-61) in 1993 permitted scientists to correct the problem. During four spacewalks
column10: new instruments were installed into the HST that had optical corrections. The Marshall Space Flight Center had responsibility for design
column11: development
column12: and construction of the HST. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation
column15: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. column1: 33568284956.0;Gravitational Wave Kicks Monster Black Hole Out of Galactic Core;"Astronomers have uncovered a supermassive black hole that has been propelled out of the center of a distant galaxy by what could be the awesome power of gravitational waves.
Though there have been several other suspected
column2: similarly booted black holes elsewhere
column3: none has been confirmed so far. Astronomers think this object
column4: detected by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope
column5: is a very strong case. Weighing more than 1 billion suns
column6: the rogue black hole is the most massive black hole ever detected to have been kicked out of its central home.

column1: Researchers estimate that it took the equivalent energy of 100 million supernovas exploding simultaneously to jettison the black hole. The most plausible explanation for this propulsive energy is that the monster object was given a kick by gravitational waves unleashed by the merger of two hefty black holes at the center of the host galaxy.
First predicted by Albert Einstein
column2: gravitational waves are ripples in space that are created when two massive objects collide. The ripples are similar to the concentric circles produced when a hefty rock is thrown into a pond. Last year
column3: the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) helped astronomers prove that gravitational waves exist by detecting them emanating from the union of two stellar-mass black holes
column4: which are several times more massive than the Sun.

column1: Hubble's observations of the wayward black hole surprised the research team. "When I first saw this
column2: I thought we were seeing something very peculiar
column3: " said team leader Marco Chiaberge of the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) and Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore
column4: Maryland. "When we combined observations from Hubble
column5: the Chandra X-ray Observatory
column6: and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey
column7: it all pointed towards the same scenario. The amount of data we collected
column8: from X-rays to ultraviolet to near-infrared light
column9: is definitely larger than for any of the other candidate rogue black holes."

column1: Hubble images taken in visible and near-infrared light provided the first clue that the galaxy was unusual. The images revealed a bright quasar
column2: the energetic signature of a black hole
column3: residing far from the galactic core. Black holes cannot be observed directly
column4: but they are the energy source at the heart of quasars — intense
column5: compact gushers of radiation that can outshine an entire galaxy. The quasar
column6: named 3C 186
column7: and its host galaxy reside 8 billion light-years away in a galaxy cluster. The team discovered the galaxy's peculiar features while conducting a Hubble survey of distant galaxies unleashing powerful blasts of radiation in the throes of galaxy mergers.

column1: "I was anticipating seeing a lot of merging galaxies
column2: and I was expecting to see messy host galaxies around the quasars
column3: but I wasn't really expecting to see a quasar that was clearly offset from the core of a regularly shaped galaxy
column4: " Chiaberge recalled. "Black holes reside in the center of galaxies
column5: so it's unusual to see a quasar not in the center."

column1: The team calculated the black hole's distance from the core by comparing the distribution of starlight in the host galaxy with that of a normal elliptical galaxy from a computer model. The black hole had traveled more than 35
column2: 000 light-years from the center
column3: which is more than the distance between the sun and the center of the Milky Way.

column1: Based on spectroscopic observations taken by Hubble and the Sloan survey
column2: the researchers estimated the black hole's mass and measured the speed of gas trapped near the behemoth object. Spectroscopy divides light into its component colors
column3: which can be used to measure velocities in space. "To our surprise
column4: we discovered that the gas around the black hole was flying away from the galaxy's center at 4.7 million miles an hour
column5: " said team member Justin Ely of STScI. This measurement is also a gauge of the black hole's velocity
column6: because the gas is gravitationally locked to the monster object.

column1: The astronomers calculated that the black hole is moving so fast it would travel from Earth to the moon in three minutes. That's fast enough for the black hole to escape the galaxy in 20 million years and roam through the universe forever.
The Hubble image revealed an interesting clue that helped explain the black hole's wayward location. The host galaxy has faint arc-shaped features called tidal tails
column2: produced by a gravitational tug between two colliding galaxies. This evidence suggests a possible union between the 3C 186 system and another galaxy
column3: each with central
column4: massive black holes that may have eventually merged.

column1: Based on this visible evidence
column2: along with theoretical work
column3: the researchers developed a scenario to describe how the behemoth black hole could be expelled from its central home. According to their theory
column4: two galaxies merge
column5: and their black holes settle into the center of the newly formed elliptical galaxy. As the black holes whirl around each other
column6: gravity waves are flung out like water from a lawn sprinkler. The hefty objects move closer to each other over time as they radiate away gravitational energy. If the two black holes do not have the same mass and rotation rate
column7: they emit gravitational waves more strongly along one direction. When the two black holes collide
column8: they stop producing gravitational waves. The newly merged black hole then recoils in the opposite direction of the strongest gravitational waves and shoots off like a rocket.

column1: The researchers are lucky to have caught this unique event because not every black-hole merger produces imbalanced gravitational waves that propel a black hole in the opposite direction. "This asymmetry depends on properties such as the mass and the relative orientation of the back holes' rotation axes before the merger
column2: " said team member Colin Norman of STScI and Johns Hopkins University. "That's why these objects are so rare."

column1: An alternative explanation for the offset quasar
column2: although unlikely
column3: proposes that the bright object does not reside within the galaxy. Instead
column4: the quasar is located behind the galaxy
column5: but the Hubble image gives the illusion that it is at the same distance as the galaxy. If this were the case
column6: the researchers should have detected a galaxy in the background hosting the quasar.

column1: If the researchers' interpretation is correct
column2: the observations may provide strong evidence that supermassive black holes can actually merge. Astronomers have evidence of black-hole collisions for stellar-mass black holes
column3: but the process regulating supermassive black holes is more complex and not completely understood.

column1: The team hopes to use Hubble again
column2: in combination with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) and other facilities
column3: to more accurately measure the speed of the black hole and its gas disk
column4: which may yield more insight into the nature of this bizarre object.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/6b83ab3fe1272a5a3f6b09f6adfc51c0;2017-03-22;1080.0;1920.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33568284956/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: Credit: NASA/Joel Kowsky";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/a36d723f6c7827f6c57e8b2838f1f096;2015-04-25;2651.0;1741.0;CC BY-NC-SA;7.21576841164e+16;Hubble 25th Anniversary Astronaut Panel;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/36121461186/in/album-72157684116421800;hubblespacetelescope25thanniversary nancycurrie stevenfudvarhazycenter spaceshuttlecolumbia servicingmission3b hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa astronaut
35155517525.0;Jackpot! Cosmic Magnifying-Glass Effect Captures Universe's Brightest Galaxies;"Boosted by natural magnifying lenses in space
column2: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has captured unique close-up views of the universe's brightest infrared galaxies
column3: which are as much as 10
column4: 000 times more luminous than our Milky Way.

column1: The galaxy images
column2: magnified through a phenomenon called gravitational lensing
column3: reveal a tangled web of misshapen objects punctuated by exotic patterns such as rings and arcs. The odd shapes are due largely to the foreground lensing galaxies' powerful gravity distorting the images of the background galaxies. The unusual forms also may have been produced by spectacular collisions between distant
column4: massive galaxies in a sort of cosmic demolition derby.

column1: "We have hit the jackpot of gravitational lenses
column2: " said lead researcher James Lowenthal of Smith College in Northampton
column3: Massachusetts. "These ultra-luminous
column4: massive
column5: starburst galaxies are very rare. Gravitational lensing magnifies them so that you can see small details that otherwise are unimaginable. We can see features as small as about 100 light-years or less across. We want to understand what's powering these monsters
column6: and gravitational lensing allows us to study them in greater detail."

column1: The galaxies are ablaze with runaway star formation
column2: pumping out more than 10
column3: 000 new stars a year. This unusually rapid star birth is occurring at the peak of the universe's star-making boom more than 8 billion years ago. The star-birth frenzy creates lots of dust
column4: which enshrouds the galaxies
column5: making them too faint to detect in visible light. But they glow fiercely in infrared light
column6: shining with the brilliance of 10 trillion to 100 trillion suns.

column1: Gravitational lenses occur when the intense gravity of a massive galaxy or cluster of galaxies magnifies the light of fainter
column2: more distant background sources. Previous observations of the galaxies
column3: discovered in far-infrared light by ground- and space-based observatories
column4: had hinted of gravitational lensing. But Hubble's keen vision confirmed the researchers' suspicion.

column1: Lowenthal presented his results June 6
column3: at the American Astronomical Society meeting in Austin
column4: Texas.

column1: According to the research team
column2: only a few dozen of these bright infrared galaxies exist in the universe
column3: scattered across the sky. They reside in unusually dense regions of space that somehow triggered rapid star formation in the early universe.

column1: The galaxies may hold clues to how galaxies formed billions of years ago. "There are so many unknowns about star and galaxy formation
column2: " Lowenthal explained. "We need to understand the extreme cases
column3: such as these galaxies
column4: as well as the average cases
column5: like our Milky Way
column6: in order to have a complete story about how galaxy and star formation happen."

column1: In studying these strange galaxies
column2: astronomers first must detangle the foreground lensing galaxies from the background ultra-bright galaxies. Seeing this effect is like looking at objects at the bottom of a swimming pool. The water distorts your view
column3: just as the lensing galaxies' gravity stretches the shapes of the distant galaxies. "We need to understand the nature and scale of those lensing effects to interpret properly what we're seeing in the distant
column4: early universe
column5: " Lowenthal said. "This applies not only to these brightest infrared galaxies
column6: but probably to most or maybe even all distant galaxies."

column1: Lowenthal's team is halfway through its Hubble survey of 22 galaxies. An international team of astronomers first discovered the galaxies in far-infrared light using survey data from the European Space Agency's (ESA) Planck space observatory
column2: and some clever sleuthing. The team then compared those sources to galaxies found in ESA's Herschel Space Observatory's catalog of far-infrared objects and to ground-based radio data taken by the Very Large Array in New Mexico. The researchers next used the Large Millimeter Telescope (LMT) in Mexico to measure their exact distances from Earth. The LMT's far-infrared images also revealed multiple objects
column3: hinting that the galaxies were being gravitationally lensed.

column1: These bright objects existed between 8 billion and 11.5 billion years ago
column2: when the universe was making stars more vigorously than it is today. The galaxies' star-birth production is 5
column4: 000 times higher than that of our Milky Way. However
column5: the ultra-bright galaxies are pumping out stars using only the same amount of gas contained in the Milky Way.

column1: So
column2: the nagging question is
column3: what is powering the prodigious star birth? "We've known for two decades that some of the most luminous galaxies in the universe are very dusty and massive
column4: and they're undergoing bursts of star formation
column5: " Lowenthal said. "But they've been very hard to study because the dust makes them practically impossible to observe in visible light. They're also very rare: they don't appear in any of Hubble's deep-field surveys. They are in random parts of the sky that nobody's looked at before in detail. That's why finding that they are gravitationally lensed is so important."

column1: These galaxies may be the brighter
column2: more distant cousins of the ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGS)
column3: hefty
column4: dust-cocooned
column5: starburst galaxies
column6: seen in the nearby universe. The ULIRGS' star-making output is stoked by the merger of two spiral galaxies
column7: which is one possibility for the stellar baby boom in their more-distant relatives. However
column8: Lowenthal said that computer simulations of the birth and growth of galaxies show that major mergers occur at a later epoch than the one in which these galaxies are seen.

column1: Another idea for the star-making surge is that lots of gas
column2: the material that makes stars
column3: is flooding into the faraway galaxies. "The early universe was denser
column4: so maybe gas is raining down on the galaxies
column5: or they are fed by some sort of channel or conduit
column6: which we have not figured out yet
column7: " Lowenthal said. "This is what theoreticians struggle with: How do you get all the gas into a galaxy fast enough to make it happen?"

column1: The research team plans to use Hubble and the Gemini Observatory in Hawaii to try to distinguish between the foreground and background galaxies so they can begin to analyze the details of the brilliant monster galaxies.
Future telescopes
column2: such as NASA's James Webb Space Telescope
column3: an infrared observatory scheduled to launch in 2018
column4: will measure the speed of the galaxies' stars so that astronomers can calculate the mass of these ultra-luminous objects.

column1: "The sky is covered with all kinds of galaxies
column2: including those that shine in far-infrared light
column3: " Lowenthal said. "What we're seeing here is the tip of the iceberg: the very brightest of all."";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/3f95f74c8482b8bebf18836dc61d1b04;2017-06-06;657.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35155517525/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 27989260726.0;Southwest Arabian Peninsula
column2: Saudi Arabia
column3: and Yemen;"This south-southwest-looking
column4: high-oblique photograph shows the southwestern Arabian Peninsula
column5: the Gulf of Aden
column6: the Red Sea
column7: northern Somalia
column8: the Afar Triangle
column9: and the Great Rift Valley of Ethiopia. The southwestern Arabian Peninsula
column10: most of which is in Yemen
column11: has a narrow coastal plain (Tihamah) along the Red Sea about 20 to 50 miles (30 to 80 kilometers) wide
column13: and mountains that descend to a great sandy desert. The coastal plain is hot and virtually rainless with high humidity
column14: alluvium and talus carried down from the highlands
column15: and little vegetation cover. The interior highlands
column16: a section of the uplifted Arabian Plateau rising more than 12 000 feet (660 meters)
column17: annually receive an average of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of precipitation
column18: most falling between the months of June and September. This area is the wettest part of the Arabian Peninsula with numerous wadis (valleys and/or watercourses); Wadi Hadhramaut (east of center) is the largest. The upper and middle highlands
column20: have alluvial soils and moisture from intermittent streams; the lower portions are uninhabited and extremely dry. The eastern and northern highlands
column21: which are in the rain shadow
column22: slope down into the great sandy expanse of the reddish southwestern Rub’ al Khali Desert with parallel northeast-southwest trending sand dunes. West and southwest of the Arabian Peninsula and the Red Sea is the Danakil Depression
column23: part of the Great African Rift Valley; south of the peninsula
column24: scattered clouds cover portions of the Gulf of Aden and the coastal ranges of northern Somalia.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/b1e28deb6339445a66c84ae8a30fd257;2016-07-01;5294.0;5294.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27989260726/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

or the Surfboard galaxy
column3: is located in the constellation Ursa Major approximately 46 million light-years away. It is called the Surfboard galaxy because
column4: when viewed with a telescope
column5: it is seen nearly edge-on with no apparent bulge or pronounced core.

column1: M108 was discovered by Pierre Méchain in 1781 three days after he discovered M97. Charles Messier's notes state that he observed the galaxy in 1781 but never took an accurate position of it or officially added it to his catalog. M108 was finally added to Messier's catalog in 1953 by astronomer Owen Gingerich.
There is little evidence of a well-defined spiral pattern in the galaxy
column2: but M108 is classified as a barred spiral galaxy with loosely wound spiral arms. Observations show young star clusters exposed against a mottled and detail-rich background. M108 also contains supershells
column3: which are shells of gas driven by bursts of star formation and resulting supernova explosions. The supershells could also be driven by stellar jets or an infall of gas from outside the galaxy.

column1: At the center of M108 is a supermassive black hole estimated to be 24 million times as massive as the Sun. The Chandra X-ray Observatory discovered multiple X-ray sources in M108
column2: with the brightest X-ray source suspected to be an intermediately sized black hole that is actively accreting material.

column1: M108 is one of the largest and brightest members of the Ursa Major cluster
column2: as well as part of the Virgo supercluster of galaxies. It has a magnitude of 10 and is located just under the bowl of the Big Dipper. M108 can be seen with small telescopes as an elliptical streak of light with a brighter core
column3: while telescopes 8 inches or larger will reveal more detail. The best time to observe M108 is in April
column4: but it can be seen throughout the year for those in the Northern Hemisphere.

column1: This Hubble image was taken using the Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 and features only a portion of the galaxy. Its stair-step appearance results from the design of the camera
column2: and because Hubble's observations were taken in only one filter
column3: it is in black and white. The observations were taken to help astronomers understand various features in the nuclei of nearby disk galaxies.

column1: 35660126003.0;M102;"Hubble’s sharp vision reveals a crisp dust lane dividing M102
column2: also known as the Spindle galaxy
column3: into two halves. This edge-on view of M102 highlights the galaxy’s structure: a subtle
column4: reddish bulge surrounding a bright nucleus
column5: a blue disk of stars running parallel to the dust lane
column6: and a transparent outer halo.

column1: M102’s dust lane is slightly warped compared to the disk of starlight. This warp indicates that the galaxy might have experienced gravitational tidal disturbances in the distant past. These disturbances were likely caused by an interaction with a nearby galaxy
column2: as M102 is the largest member of a small cluster of galaxies.

column1: Some faint
column2: wispy trails of dust can be seen meandering away from the disk out into the bulge and inner halo of the galaxy. The outer halo is dotted with numerous globular star clusters
column3: gravitationally bound clusters of nearly a million stars each. Background galaxies that are millions to billions of light-years farther away than M102 are also seen through its halo.

column1: Pierre Méchain
column2: a French astronomer and colleague of Charles Messier
column3: discovered the Spindle galaxy in 1781 — the same year that he discovered the first two of his eight comets. M102 is located 44 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Draco and has an apparent magnitude of 10.7. It can be observed using a small telescope and is most easily spotted during July.

column1: 27990746886.0;Astronauts John M. Grunsfeld and Richard M. Linnehan EVA;Barely visible within the Hubble Space Telescope's heavily shadowed shroud doors
column2: astronauts John M. Grunsfeld (left) and Richard M. Linnehan participate in the final space walk of the STS-109 mission. The crew of the space shuttle Columbia completed the last of its five ambitious space walks early on March 8
column4: with the successful installation of an experimental cooling system for Hubble’s Near-Infrared Camera and Multi-Object Spectrometer (NICMOS). The NICMOS has been dormant since January 1999 when its original coolant ran out. Astronauts Grunsfeld and Linnehan began their third spacewalk of the mission at 2:46 a.m. CST. Linnehan was given a ride on the shuttle’s robotic arm to the aft shroud doors by astronaut Nancy J. Currie
column5: working from the aft flight deck of Columbia. After the shroud doors were open
column6: Linnehan was moved back to Columbia’s payload bay to remove the NICMOS cryocooler from its carrier. Grunsfeld and Linnehan then installed the cryocooler inside the aft shroud and connected cables from its Electronics Support Module (ESM). That module was installed on March 7 during a spacewalk by astronauts James H. Newman and Michael J. Massimino.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/db4a09481a715cea16623628f5db8b16;2016-07-01;1964.0;2960.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 3B;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27990746886/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope servicingmission nasa servicingmission3b sts109

column2: mission specialist
column3: remains very near the controls for Columbia's Remote Manipulator System (out of frame) on the crew cabin's aft flight deck. On a week with one lengthy space walk per day

column1: 27415470133.0;Cloudy Days on Exoplanets May Hide Atmospheric Water;"Water is a hot topic in the study of exoplanets
column2: including "hot Jupiters
column3: " whose masses are similar to that of Jupiter
column4: but which are much closer to their parent star than Jupiter is to the Sun. They can reach a scorching 2
column5: 000 degrees Fahrenheit (1
column6: 100 degrees Celsius)
column7: meaning any water they host would take the form of water vapor.

column1: Astronomers have found many hot Jupiters with water in their atmospheres
column2: but others appear to have none. Scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (Pasadena
column3: California) wanted to find out what the atmospheres of these giant worlds have in common.

column1: Researchers focused on a collection of hot Jupiters studied by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. They found that the atmospheres of about half of the planets were blocked by clouds or haze.
"The motivation of our study was to see what these planets would be like if they were grouped together
column2: and to see whether they share any atmospheric properties
column3: " said Aishwarya Iyer
column4: a JPL intern and master's degree candidate at California State University
column5: Northridge
column6: who led the study.

column1: The new study
column2: published in the June 1
column4: issue of the Astrophysical Journal
column5: suggests that clouds or haze layers could be preventing a substantial amount of atmospheric water from being detected by space telescopes. The clouds themselves are likely not made of water
column6: as the planets in this sample are too hot for water-based clouds.

column1: "Clouds or haze seem to be on almost every planet we studied
column2: " Iyer said. "You have to be careful to take clouds or haze into account
column3: or else you could underestimate the amount of water in an exoplanet's atmosphere by a factor of two."

column1: In the study
column2: scientists looked at a set of 19 hot Jupiters previously observed by Hubble. The telescope's Wide Field Camera 3 had detected water vapor in the atmospheres of 10 of these planets
column3: and no water on the other nine. But that information was spread across more than a dozen studies. The methods of analyzing and interpretation varied because the studies were conducted separately. There had not been one overarching analysis of all these planets.

column1: To compare the planets and look for patterns
column2: the JPL team had to standardize the data. Researchers combined the datasets for all 19 hot Jupiters to create an average overall light spectrum for the group of planets. They then compared these data to models of clear
column3: cloud-free atmospheres and those with various cloud thicknesses.

column1: The scientists determined that
column2: for almost every planet they studied
column3: haze or clouds were blocking half of the atmosphere
column4: on average.

column1: "In some of these planets
column2: you can see water peeking its head up above the clouds or haze
column3: and there could still be more water below
column4: " Iyer said.

column1: Scientists do not yet know the nature of these clouds or hazes
column2: including what they are they made of.

column1: "Clouds or haze being on almost all these planets is pretty surprising
column2: " said Robert Zellem
column3: a postdoctoral fellow at JPL and co-author of the study.

column1: The implications of this result agree with findings published in the Dec. 14
column3: issue of the journal Nature. The Nature study used data from NASA's Hubble and Spitzer Space Telescopes to suggest that clouds or haze could be hiding undetected water in hot Jupiters. This new study uses exoplanet data from a single instrument on Hubble to uniformly characterize a larger group of hot Jupiters
column4: and is the first to quantify how much of the atmosphere would be shielded as a result of clouds or haze.

column1: The new research could have implications for follow-up studies with future space observatories
column2: such as NASA's James Webb Space Telescope. Exoplanets with thick cloud covers blocking the detection of water and other substances may be less desirable targets for more extensive study.

column1: These results are also important for figuring out how planets form
column2: scientists say.

column1: "Did these planets form in their current positions or migrate toward their host stars from farther out? Understanding the abundances of molecules such as water helps us answer those questions
column2: " Zellem said.

column1: "This paper is an exciting step forward for the study of exoplanets and comparing their properties
column2: " said Mark Swain
column3: study co-author and group supervisor for the exoplanet discovery and science group at JPL.

column1: Michael Line of the University of California
column2: Santa Cruz
column3: also contributed to the study. Other co-authors from JPL included Gael Roudier
column4: Graca Rocha and John Livingston.

column1: For more information about the Hubble Space Telescope

column2: located in the constellation Scorpius
column3: is a huge
column4: spherical collection of stars known as a globular cluster. Just 5
column5: 500 light-years away
column6: it is the closest globular cluster to Earth. Because of its apparent magnitude of 5.9 and proximity to Antares
column7: one of the brightest stars in the night sky
column8: M4 is relatively easy to find with a small telescope. The cluster is best spotted in July.

column1: M4 was discovered in 1746 by the Swiss astronomer Jean-Philippe Loys de Chéseaux. Home to more than 100
column2: 000 stars
column3: the cluster is predicted to contain up to 40
column4: 000 white dwarfs — the cores of ancient
column5: dead stars whose outer layers have drifted away into space. As white dwarfs age
column6: they grow cooler
column7: fainter
column8: and more difficult to detect. Therefore
column9: a globular cluster’s age can be inferred from the age of its faintest white dwarf. Because the stars in these clusters are some of the oldest in the universe
column10: up to 13 billion years old
column11: astronomers are able to use them to estimate the age of the universe.

column1: The white dwarfs in M4 are less than one-billionth the apparent brightness of the faintest stars that can be seen with the naked eye. Even the brightest of the detected white dwarfs are no more luminous than a 100-watt light bulb seen at the moon’s distance. The faintest are comparable to a 2.5-watt night-light at the same distance.

The ancient orbs comprising M4 were captured by Hubble in both visible and infrared light. The resulting image offers a view into the center of a cluster that is more than twice the age of our solar system.
For more information about Hubble’s observations of M4
column2: see:

column2: 000 light-years away in the constellation Ophiuchus
column3: M9 is one of the closest globular clusters to the center of our Milky Way galaxy. The stars in the globular cluster are gravitationally bound to each other
column4: with most of the stars concentrated at the cluster’s center. This large central mass pulls outer stars inward and causes globular clusters to have a spherical shape. M9’s proximity to the much greater mass at the center of the Milky Way has warped the cluster's shape
column5: though
column6: so it appears less spherical than other objects of its kind.

column1: M9 was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764. It has an apparent magnitude of 8.4 and can be observed using a small telescope. The best time of year to spot the cluster is during the month of July.
This Hubble image of M9’s core was created from exposures taken in visible
column2: infrared and ultraviolet light. The stars in the image have different colors based on their properties. Red stars have lower surface temperatures
column3: while blue stars are extremely hot.

column1: For more information on Hubble’s observations of M9

36105698290.0;M3;"The globular cluster M3 was the first object in the Messier catalog to be discovered by Charles Messier himself. Messier spotted the cluster in 1764
column2: mistaking it for a nebula without any stars. This misunderstanding of M3’s nature was corrected in 1784 when William Herschel was able to resolve the cluster’s individual stars. Today it is known to contain over 500
column3: 000 stars.

column1: M3 is notable for containing more variable stars than any other known cluster. The brightness of a variable star fluctuates with time. For some variable stars
column2: their period relates to their intrinsic luminosity
column3: so astronomers can use those stars’ brightness fluctuations to estimate their distances. This makes them extremely useful for measuring distances to deep-sky objects. M3 contains at least 274 variable stars.

column1: This image of M3’s core was constructed using Hubble observations in visible and infrared light. The cluster is located 34
column2: 000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Canes Venatici. It has an apparent magnitude of 6.2 and can be spotted using a pair of binoculars. The best time to observe M3 is during May.

column1: 27993305636.0;Hubble's Panoramic View of a Turbulent Star-making Region;"Several million young stars are vying for attention in this NASA Hubble Space Telescope image of a raucous stellar breeding ground in 30 Doradus
column2: located in  the heart of the Tarantula Nebula. Early astronomers nicknamed the nebula because  its glowing filaments resemble spider legs.

column1: 30 Doradus is the brightest star-forming region visible in a neighboring galaxy and home to the most massive stars ever seen. The nebula resides 170
column2: 000 light-years away in the Large Magellanic Cloud
column3: a small
column4: satellite galaxy of our Milky Way. No known star-forming region in our galaxy is as large or as prolific as 30 Doradus.

column1: The composite image comprises one of the largest mosaics ever assembled from Hubble photos and includes observations taken by Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3 and Advanced Camera for Surveys. The Hubble image is combined with ground-based data of the Tarantula Nebula
column2: taken with the European Southern Observatory's 2.2-meter  telescope in La Silla
column3: Chile. NASA and the Space Telescope Science Institute released the image to celebrate Hubble's 22nd anniversary.

column1: Collectively
column2: the stars in this image are millions of times more massive than our Sun. The image is roughly 650 light-years across and contains some rambunctious stars
column3: from one of the fastest rotating stars to the speediest and most massive  runaway star.

column1: The nebula is close enough to Earth that Hubble can resolve individual stars
column2: giving astronomers important information about the stars' birth and evolution. Many small galaxies have more spectacular starbursts
column3: but the Large Magellanic  Cloud's 30 Doradus is one of the only extragalactic star-forming regions that  astronomers can study in so much detail. The star-birthing frenzy in 30 Doradus  may be partly fueled by its close proximity to its companion galaxy
column4: the Small Magellanic Cloud.

column1: The image reveals the stages of star birth
column2: from embryonic stars a few thousand  years old still wrapped in cocoons of dark gas to behemoths that die young in supernova explosions. 30 Doradus is a star-forming factory
column3: churning out stars at a furious pace over millions of years. Hubble shows star clusters of various ages
column4: from about 2 million to about 25 million years old.

column1: The region's sparkling centerpiece is a giant
column2: young star cluster (left of center) named NGC 2070
column3: only 2 million years old. Its stellar inhabitants number roughly 500
column4: 000. The cluster is a hotbed for young
column5: massive stars. Its dense core
column6: known  as R136
column7: is packed with some of the heftiest stars found in the nearby universe
column8: weighing more than 100 times the mass of our Sun.

column1: The massive stars are carving deep cavities in the surrounding material by unleashing a torrent of ultraviolet light
column2: which is etching away the enveloping hydrogen gas cloud in which the stars were born. The image reveals a fantasy landscape of pillars
column3: ridges
column4: and valleys. Besides sculpting the gaseous terrain
column5: the brilliant stars also may be triggering a successive generation of offspring. When the radiation hits dense walls of gas
column6: it creates shocks
column7: which may be generating a new wave of star birth.

column1: The colors represent the hot gas that dominates regions of the image. Red signifies hydrogen gas and blue
column2: oxygen. Hubble imaged 30 separate fields
column3: 15 with each camera. Both cameras were making  observations at the same time. Hubble made the observations in October 2011.

column1: 31609992343.0;A slice of Sagittarius;"This stunning image
column2: captured by the Hubble Space Telescope’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)
column3: shows part of the sky in the constellation of Sagittarius (the Archer). The region is rendered in exquisite detail — deep red and bright blue stars are scattered across the frame
column4: set against a background of thousands of more distant stars and galaxies. Two features are particularly striking: the colors of the stars
column5: and the dramatic crosses that burst from the centers of the brightest bodies.

column1: While some of the colors in this frame have been enhanced and tweaked during the process of creating the image from the observational data
column2: different stars do indeed glow in different colors. Stars differ in color according to their surface temperature: very hot stars are blue or white
column3: while cooler stars are redder. They may be cooler because they are smaller
column4: or because they are very old and have entered the red giant phase
column5: when an old star expands and cools dramatically as its core collapses.

column1: The crosses are nothing to do with the stars themselves
column2: and
column3: because Hubble orbits above Earth’s atmosphere
column4: nor are they due to any kind of atmospheric disturbance. They are actually known as diffraction spikes
column5: and are caused by the structure of the telescope itself. Like all big modern telescopes
column6: Hubble uses mirrors to capture light and form images. Its secondary mirror is supported by struts
column7: called telescope spiders
column8: arranged in a cross formation
column9: and they diffract the incoming light. Diffraction is the slight bending of light as it passes near the edge of an object. Every cross in this image is due to a single set of struts within Hubble itself! Whilst the spikes are technically an inaccuracy
column10: many astrophotographers choose to emphasize and celebrate them as a beautiful feature of their images.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/1faeb723462c07dc74877f3e013d485a;2017-01-16;528.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/31609992343/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 33657856056.0;Defying cosmic convention;"Some galaxies are harder to classify than others. Here
column2: Hubble’s trusty Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) has captured a striking view of two interacting galaxies located some 60 million light-years away in the constellation of Leo (the Lion). The more diffuse and patchy blue glow covering the right side of the frame is known as NGC 3447 — sometimes NGC 3447B for clarity
column3: as the name NGC 3447 can apply to the overall duo. The smaller clump to the upper left is known as NGC 3447A.

column1: The trouble with space is that it is
column2: to state the obvious
column3: really
column4: really big. Astronomers have for hundreds of years been discovering and naming galaxies
column5: stars
column6: cosmic clouds and more. Unifying and regulating the conventions and classifications for everything ever observed is very difficult
column7: especially when you get an ambiguous object like NGC 3447
column8: which stubbornly defies easy categorization.

column1: Overall
column2: we know NGC 3447 comprises a couple of interacting galaxies
column3: but we’re unsure what each looked like before they began to tear one another apart. The two sit so close that they are strongly influenced and distorted by the gravitational forces between them
column4: causing the galaxies to twist themselves into the unusual and unique shapes seen here. NGC 3447A appears to display the remnants of a central bar structure and some disrupted spiral arms
column5: both properties characteristic of certain spiral galaxies. Some identify NGC 3447B as a former spiral galaxy
column6: while others categorize it as being an irregular galaxy.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/5a1b2ad76a4c13193bc40255f405b4ef;2017-03-20;891.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33657856056/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc3447

column1: 32080586632.0;When galaxies collide;"This delicate smudge in deep space is far more turbulent than it first appears. Known as IRAS 14348-1447 — a name  derived in part from that of its discoverer
column2: the Infrared Astronomical Satellite (IRAS for short) — this celestial object is actually a combination of two gas-rich spiral galaxies. This doomed duo approached one another too closely in the past
column3: gravity causing them to affect and tug at each other and slowly
column4: destructively
column5: merge into one. The image was taken by Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS).

column1: IRAS 14348-1447 is located over a billion light-years away from us. It is one of the most gas-rich examples known of an ultraluminous infrared galaxy
column2: a class of cosmic objects that shine characteristically — and incredibly — brightly in the infrared part of the spectrum. Almost 95% of the energy emitted by IRAS 14348-1447 is in the far-infrared!

column1: The huge amount of molecular gas within IRAS 14348-1447 fuels its emission
column2: and undergoes a number of dynamical processes as it interacts and moves around; these very same mechanisms are responsible for IRAS 14348-1447’s own whirling and ethereal appearance
column3: creating prominent tails and wisps extending away from the main body of the galaxy.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/850cf85fd326c967d615a1b65420abc7;2016-07-08;756.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/32080586632/in/album-72157667717916600;iras143481447

column1: 33227734285.0;A remarkable galactic hybrid;"This Hubble Space Telescope image showcases the remarkable galaxy UGC 12591. Classified as an S0/Sa galaxy
column2: UGC 12591 sits somewhere between a lenticular and a spiral. It lies just under 400 million light-years away from us in the westernmost region of the Pisces–Perseus Supercluster
column3: a long chain of galaxy clusters that stretches out for hundreds of light-years — one of the largest known structures in the cosmos.

column1: The galaxy itself is also extraordinary: it is incredibly massive. The galaxy and its halo together contain several hundred billion times the mass of the Sun; four times the mass of the Milky Way. It also whirls round extremely quickly
column2: rotating at speeds of up to 1.8 million kilometers per hour!

column1: Observations with Hubble are helping astronomers to understand the mass of UGC 1259
column2: and to determine whether the galaxy simply formed and grew slowly over time
column3: or whether it might have grown unusually massive by colliding and merging with another large galaxy at some point in its past.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/255bef006127b3d4caab6f9da863c7dc;2017-02-27;867.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33227734285/in/album-72157667717916600;leda71392 ugc12591

column1: 29879117305.0;Orbiting Stars;"(Artist's Depiction)
Two's company
column2: but three might not always be a crowd — at least in space.

column1: Astronomers using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope
column2: and a trick of nature
column3: have confirmed the existence of a planet orbiting two stars in the system OGLE-2007-BLG-349
column4: located 8
column5: 000 light-years away towards the center of our galaxy.

column1: The planet orbits roughly 300 million miles from the stellar duo
column2: about the distance from the asteroid belt to our Sun. It completes an orbit around both stars roughly every seven years. The two red dwarf stars are a mere 7 million miles apart
column3: or 14 times the diameter of the Moon's orbit around Earth.

column1: 28127831195.0;Northern Chile and Andes Mountains seen from STS-61 Shuttle Endeavour;This color photograph is a spectacular
column2: panoramic (southeastern view) shot that features the northern half of the country of Chile and the Andes Mountains of South America. The Atacama Desert
column3: one of the driest regions on earth
column4: is clearly visible along the northern Chilean coast. This desert extends from roughly Arica in the north to the city of Caldera in the south
column5: a distance of six hundred miles. Some parts of this very arid region go for more than twenty years without measurable precipitation. It is an area of dramatic and abrupt elevation changes. For example
column6: from the waters edge there is an escarpment of the coastal plateau that rises like an unbroken wall two or three thousand feet above the Pacific Ocean. From the coastal plateau
column7: there is an even more dramatic increase in elevation -- from two thousand feet above sea level to an average elevation of thirteen thousand feet above sea level in the Bolivian Altiplano. This elevation change occurs within a one hundred to two hundred mile distance from the Pacific Ocean. The north-south trending spine of the Andes Mountains can be seen on this photograph. Several of the volcanic peaks in this mountain chain exceed 20
column8: 000 feet above sea level. Interspersed with these volcanic peaks
column9: numerous dry lake beds (salars) can be seen as highly reflective surfaces. The largest of these salars (Salar de Uyuni) is visible at the edge of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). Offshore
column10: the cold Peruvian current produces low stratus clouds that can be found along this coastline at certain times of the year. This is the same type of meteorological phenomena that is found along the southern California coast and the Skeleton coast of southwestern Africa.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/0766d9d1fbb517c12cd944b3dbd42aed;2010-09-02;4656.0;4660.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28127831195/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

column1: 28051096071.0;Astronauts Thornton and Akers during installation of COSTAR on HST;Astronaut Kathryn C. Thornton lifts the Corrective Optics Space Telescope Axial Replacement (COSTAR) prior to its installation on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). Thornton is anchored to a foot restraint on the end of the Remote Manipulator System (RMS) arm. Astronaut Thomas D. Akers
column2: who assisted in the COSTAR installation
column3: is at lower left. The two space walkers participated in the mission's second and fourth (of five) extravehicular activities (EVA) designed to service the giant telescope. This photograph was made with a handheld Hasselblad camera from the Space Shuttle Endeavour's cabin.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/4b772de65333d934524e7dcb365f5a9a;2012-01-19;640.0;618.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 1;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28051096071/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa servicingmission servicingmission1 sts61

column1: 36028853911.0;Astronaut Bruce McCandless Speaks at Hubble 25th Anniversary Event at Smithsonian Udvar-Hazy Center;"Former NASA astronaut Bruce McCandless speaks during a panel discussion as part of an event celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Hubble Space Telescope on Saturday
column2: April 25
column4: at the Smithsonian's Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center in Chantilly
column5: Virginia. McCandless flew as a mission specialist aboard space shuttle Discovery on STS-31 in 1990
column6: the mission that deployed Hubble.

27993302656.0;Hubble Ultra Deep Field 2014;"Astronomers using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope have assembled a comprehensive picture of the evolving universe – among the most colorful deep space images ever captured by the telescope.
Researchers say the image
column2: from a study called the Ultraviolet Coverage of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field
column3: provides the missing link in star formation. The Hubble Ultra Deep Field 2014 image is a composite of separate exposures taken in 2002 to 2012 with Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys and Wide Field Camera 3.

column1: Astronomers previously studied the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (HUDF) in visible and near-infrared light in a series of images captured from 2003 to 2009. The HUDF shows a small section of space in the southern-hemisphere constellation Fornax. Now
column2: using ultraviolet light
column3: astronomers have combined the full range of colors available to Hubble
column4: stretching all the way from ultraviolet to near-infrared light. The resulting image – made from 841 orbits of telescope viewing time – contains approximately 10
column5: 000 galaxies
column6: extending back in time to within a few hundred million years of the big bang.

column1: Prior to the Ultraviolet Coverage of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field study of the universe
column2: astronomers were in a curious position. Missions such as NASA's Galaxy Evolution Explorer (GALEX) observatory
column3: which operated from 2003 to 2013
column4: provided significant knowledge of star formation in nearby galaxies. Using Hubble's near-infrared capability
column5: researchers also studied star birth in the most distant galaxies
column6: which appear to us in their most primitive stages due to the significant amount of time required for the light of distant stars to travel into a visible range. But for the period in between
column7: when most of the stars in the universe were born – a distance extending from about 5 billion to 10 billion light-years – they did not have enough data.

column1: "The lack of information from ultraviolet light made studying galaxies in the HUDF like trying to understand the history of families without knowing about the grade-school children
column2: " said principal investigator Harry Teplitz of Caltech in Pasadena
column3: California. "The addition of the ultraviolet fills in this missing range."

column1: Ultraviolet light comes from the hottest
column2: largest
column3: and youngest stars. By observing at these wavelengths
column4: researchers get a direct look at which galaxies are forming stars and where the stars are forming within those galaxies.

column1: Studying the ultraviolet images of galaxies in this intermediate time period enables astronomers to understand how galaxies grew in size by forming small collections of very hot stars. Because Earth's atmosphere filters most ultraviolet light
column2: this work can only be accomplished with a space-based telescope.

column1: "Ultraviolet surveys like this one using the unique capability of Hubble are incredibly important in planning for NASA's James Webb Space Telescope
column2: " said team member Rogier Windhorst of Arizona State University in Tempe. "Hubble provides an invaluable ultraviolet-light dataset that researchers will need to combine with infrared data from Webb. This is the first really deep ultraviolet image to show the power of that combination."

column1: 28152436400.0;NASA’s Hubble Telescope Makes First Atmospheric Study of Earth-Sized Exoplanets;"Using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope
column2: astronomers have conducted the first search for atmospheres around temperate
column3: Earth-sized planets beyond our solar system and found indications that increase the chances of habitability on two exoplanets.

column1: Specifically
column2: they discovered that the exoplanets TRAPPIST-1b and TRAPPIST-1c
column3: approximately 40 light-years away
column4: are unlikely to have puffy
column5: hydrogen-dominated atmospheres usually found on gaseous worlds.

column1: “The lack of a smothering hydrogen-helium envelope increases the chances for habitability on these planets
column2: ” said team member Nikole Lewis of the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore. “If they had a significant hydrogen-helium envelope
column3: there is no chance that either one of them could potentially support life because the dense atmosphere would act like a greenhouse.”

column1: Julien de Wit of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge
column2: Massachusetts
column3: led a team of scientists to observe the planets in near-infrared light using Hubble’s Wide Field Camera 3. They used spectroscopy to decode the light and reveal clues to the chemical makeup of an atmosphere. While the content of the atmospheres is unknown and will have to await further observations
column4: the low concentration of hydrogen and helium has scientists excited about the implications.

column1: “These initial Hubble observations are a promising first step in learning more about these nearby worlds
column2: whether they could be rocky like Earth
column3: and whether they could sustain life
column4: ” says Geoff Yoder
column5: acting associate administrator for NASA’s Science Mission Directorate in Washington. “This is an exciting time for NASA and exoplanet research.”

column1: The planets orbit a red dwarf star at least 500 million years old
column2: in the constellation of Aquarius. They were discovered in late 2015 through a series of observations by the TRAnsiting Planets and PlanetesImals Small Telescope (TRAPPIST)
column3: a Belgian robotic telescope located at ESA’s (European Space Agency’s) La Silla Observatory in Chile.

column1: TRAPPIST-1b completes a circuit around its red dwarf star in 1.5 days and TRAPPIST-1c in 2.4 days. The planets are between 20 and 100 times closer to their star than the Earth is to the sun. Because their star is so much fainter than our sun
column2: researchers think that at least one of the planets
column3: TRAPPIST-1c
column4: may be within the star’s habitable zone
column5: where moderate temperatures could allow for liquid water to pool.

column1: On May 4
column2: astronomers took advantage of a rare simultaneous transit
column3: when both planets crossed the face of their star within minutes of each other
column4: to measure starlight as it filtered through any existing atmosphere. This double-transit
column5: which occurs only every two years
column6: provided a combined signal that offered simultaneous indicators of the atmospheric characters of the planets.

column1: The researchers hope to use Hubble to conduct follow-up observations to search for thinner atmospheres
column2: composed of elements heavier than hydrogen
column3: like those of Earth and Venus.

column1: “With more data
column2: we could perhaps detect methane or see water features in the atmospheres
column3: which would give us estimates of the depth of the atmospheres
column4: ” said Hannah Wakeford
column5: the paper’s second author
column6: at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt
column7: Maryland.

column1: Observations from future telescopes
column2: including NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope
column3: will help determine the full composition of these atmospheres and hunt for potential biosignatures
column4: such as carbon dioxide and ozone
column5: in addition to water vapor and methane. Webb also will analyze a planet’s temperature and surface pressure – key factors in assessing its habitability.

column1: “These Earth-sized planets are the first worlds that astronomers can study in detail with current and planned telescopes to determine whether they are suitable for life
column2: ” said de Wit. “Hubble has the facility to play the central atmospheric pre-screening role to tell astronomers which of these Earth-sized planets are prime candidates for more detailed study with the Webb telescope.”

column1: The results of the study appear in the July 20
column3: issue of the journal Nature.

28191313911.0;NASA's Hubble Captures the Beating Heart of the Crab Nebula;"Peering deep into the core of the Crab Nebula
column2: this close-up image reveals the beating heart of one of the most historic and intensively studied remnants of a supernova
column3: an exploding star. The inner region sends out clock-like pulses of radiation and tsunamis of charged particles embedded in magnetic fields.

column1: The neutron star at the very center of the Crab Nebula has about the same mass as the sun but compressed into an incredibly dense sphere that is only a few miles across. Spinning 30 times a second
column2: the neutron star shoots out detectable beams of energy that make it look like it's pulsating.

column1: The NASA Hubble Space Telescope snapshot is centered on the region around the neutron star (the rightmost of the two bright stars near the center of this image) and the expanding
column2: tattered
column3: filamentary debris surrounding it. Hubble's sharp view captures the intricate details of glowing gas
column4: shown in red
column5: that forms a swirling medley of cavities and filaments. Inside this shell is a ghostly blue glow that is radiation given off by electrons spiraling at nearly the speed of light in the powerful magnetic field around the crushed stellar core.

column1: The neutron star is a showcase for extreme physical processes and unimaginable cosmic violence. Bright wisps are moving outward from the neutron star at half the speed of light to form an expanding ring. It is thought that these wisps originate from a shock wave that turns the high-speed wind from the neutron star into extremely energetic particles.
When this "heartbeat" radiation signature was first discovered in 1968
column2: astronomers realized they had discovered a new type of astronomical object. Now astronomers know it's the archetype of a class of supernova remnants called pulsars - or rapidly spinning neutron stars. These interstellar "lighthouse beacons" are invaluable for doing observational experiments on a variety of astronomical phenomena
column3: including measuring gravity waves.

column1: Observations of the Crab supernova were recorded by Chinese astronomers in 1054 A.D. The nebula
column2: bright enough to be visible in amateur telescopes
column3: is located 6
column4: 500 light-years away in the constellation Taurus.

column1: 27747570680.0;"A ""Rose"" Made of Galaxies Highlighted Hubble's 21st Anniversary";"In celebration of the 21st anniversary of the Hubble Space Telescope's  deployment into space
column2: astronomers pointed Hubble's eye to an especially  photogenic group of interacting galaxies called Arp 273.

column1: The larger of the spiral galaxies
column2: known as UGC 1810
column3: has a disk that is tidally distorted into a rose-like shape by the gravitational tidal pull of the companion galaxy below it
column4: known as UGC 1813. A swath of blue jewels across the top is the combined light from clusters of intensely bright and hot young blue stars. These massive stars glow fiercely in  ultraviolet light.

column1: The smaller
column2: nearly edge-on companion shows distinct signs of intense star formation at its nucleus
column3: perhaps triggered by the encounter with the companion galaxy.

column1: A series of uncommon spiral patterns in the large galaxy is a tell-tale sign of interaction. The large
column2: outer arm appears partially as a ring
column3: a feature seen when interacting galaxies actually pass through one another. This suggests that the smaller companion actually dived deep
column4: but off-center
column5: through UGC 1810. The inner set of spiral arms is highly  warped out of the plane with one of the arms going behind the bulge and coming back out the other side. How these two spiral patterns connect is still not precisely known.

column1: A possible mini-spiral may be visible in the spiral arms of UGC 1810 to the upper right. It is noticeable how the outermost spiral arm changes character as it passes this third galaxy
column2: from smooth with lots of old  stars (reddish in color) on one side to clumpy and extremely blue on the other. The fairly regular spacing of the blue star-forming knots fits with what is seen in the spiral arms of other galaxies and is predictable  based on instabilities in the gas contained within the arm.

column1: The larger galaxy in the UGC 1810 - UGC 1813 pair has a mass that is about five times that of the smaller galaxy. In unequal pairs such as this
column2: the relatively rapid passage of a companion galaxy produces the lopsided or asymmetric structure in the main spiral. Also in such encounters
column3: the starburst activity typically begins in the minor galaxies earlier than in the major galaxies. These effects could be due to the fact that the smaller galaxies have consumed less of the gas present in  their nucleus
column4: from which new stars are born.

column1: Arp 273 lies in the constellation Andromeda and is roughly 300 million light-years away from Earth. The image shows a tenuous tidal bridge of material between the two galaxies that are separated by tens of thousands of light-years from each other.
The interaction was imaged on December 17
column3: with Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3).

column1: This Hubble image is a composite of data taken with three separate filters on WFC3 that allow a broad range of wavelengths covering the ultraviolet
column2: blue
column3: and red portions of the spectrum.

column1: 40382081612.0;Three Steps to the Hubble Constant;"These Hubble Space Telescope images showcase 2 of the 19 galaxies analyzed in a project to improve the precision of the universe's expansion rate
column2: a value known as the Hubble constant.

column1: The color-composite images show NGC 3972 (left) and NGC 1015 (right)
column2: located 65 million light-years and 118 million light-years
column3: respectively
column4: from Earth. The yellow circles in each galaxy represent the locations of pulsating stars called Cepheid variables. These stars blink at a rate matched closely by their intrinsic brightness
column5: making them ideal cosmic lighthouses for measuring accurate distances to relatively nearby galaxies.

column1: Another reliable milepost marker is a special class of exploding star called a Type Ia supernova. All of these supernovae peak at the same brightness and are brilliant enough to be seen over relatively longer distances. The small cross-shaped feature in each galaxy denotes the location of a Type Ia supernova.

Astronomers search for Cepheid variables in nearby galaxies containing a Type Ia supernova so they can compare the true brightness of both types of stars. That brightness information is used to calibrate the luminosity of Type Ia supernovae in far-flung galaxies so that astronomers can calculate the galaxies' distances from Earth. Once astronomers know accurate distances to galaxies near and far
column2: they can determine and refine the universe's expansion rate.

column1: The observations for NGC 3972 were taken in 2015; for NGC 1015 in 2013. Both galaxies were observed by Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/1be3d375194ea7b77e1d0d1d516fe329;2018-02-22;2000.0;1731.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/40382081612/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc1015

25839437357.0;Hubble's Galaxy Full of Cosmic Lighthouses;"This enchanting spiral galaxy can be found in the constellation of Ursa Major (the Great Bear). Star-studded NGC 3972 lies about 65 million light-years away from Earth
column2: meaning that the light that we see now left it 65 million years ago
column3: just when the dinosaurs became extinct.

column1: NGC 3972 has had its fair share of dramatic events. In 2011 astronomers observed the explosion of a Type Ia supernova in the galaxy (not visible in this image). These dazzling objects all peak at the same brightness
column2: and are brilliant enough to be seen over large distances.

column1: NGC 3972 also contains many pulsating stars called Cepheid variables. These stars change their brightness at a rate matched closely to their intrinsic luminosity
column2: making them ideal cosmic lighthouses for measuring accurate distances to relatively nearby galaxies.

column1: Astronomers search for Cepheid variables in nearby galaxies that also contain a Type Ia supernova so they can compare the true brightness of both types of stars. That brightness information is used to calibrate the luminosity of Type Ia supernovae in far-flung galaxies so that astronomers can calculate the galaxies' distances from Earth. Once astronomers know accurate distances to galaxies near and far
column2: they can determine and refine the expansion rate of the universe.

column1: This image was taken in 2015 with Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3
column2: as part of a project to improve the precision of the Hubble constant — a figure that describes the expansion rate of the universe.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/7174969860f0293dc9f3130eeada65e6;2018-03-09;781.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/25839437357/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 37005565640.0;More than meets the eye;"Despite the advances made in past decades
column2: the process of galaxy formation remains an open question in astronomy. Various theories have been suggested
column3: but since galaxies come in all shapes and sizes — including elliptical
column4: spiral
column5: and irregular — no single theory has so far been able to satisfactorily explain the origins of all the galaxies we see throughout the universe.

column1: To determine which formation model is correct (if any)
column2: astronomers hunt for the telltale signs of various physical processes. One example of this is galactic coronas
column3: which are huge
column4: invisible regions of hot gas that surround a galaxy’s visible bulk
column5: forming a spheroidal shape. They are so hot that they can be detected by their X-ray emission
column6: far beyond  the optical radius of the galaxy. Because they are so wispy
column7: these coronas are extremely difficult to detect. In 2013
column8: astronomers highlighted NGC 6753
column9: imaged here by the Hubble Space Telescope
column10: as one of only two known spiral galaxies that were both massive enough and close enough to permit detailed observations of their coronas. Of course
column11: NGC 6753 is only close in astronomical terms — the galaxy is nearly 150 million light-years from Earth.

column1: NGC 6753 is a whirl of color in this image — the bursts of blue throughout the spiral arms are regions filled with young stars glowing brightly in ultraviolet light
column2: while redder areas are filled with older stars emitting in the cooler near-infrared.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/991ef5fcf4864eef039f793ac8042eaa;2017-06-09;1039.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/37005565640/in/album-72157667717916600;ngc6753

column1: 38110232482.0;Abell’s richest cluster;"The Universe contains some truly massive objects. Although we are still unsure how such gigantic things come to be
column2: the current leading theory is known as hierarchical clustering
column3: whereby small clumps of matter collide and merge to grow ever larger. The 14-billion-year history of the Universe has seen the formation of some enormous cosmic structures
column4: including galaxy groups
column5: clusters
column6: and superclusters — the largest known structures in the cosmos!

column1: This particular cluster is called Abell 665. It was named after its discoverer
column2: George O. Abell
column3: who included it in his seminal 1958 cluster catalogue. Abell 665 is located in the well-known northern constellation of Ursa Major (The Great Bear). This incredible image combines visible and infrared light gathered by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope using two of its cameras: the Advanced Camera for Surveys and the Wide Field Camera 3.

column1: Abell 665 is the only galaxy cluster in Abell’s entire catalogue to be given a richness class of 5
column2: indicating that the cluster contains at least 300 individual galaxies. Because of this richness
column3: the cluster has been studied extensively at all wavelengths
column4: resulting in a number of fascinating discoveries — among other research
column5: Abell 665 has been found to host a giant radio halo
column6: powerful shockwaves
column7: and has been used to calculate an updated value for the Hubble constant (a measure of how fast the Universe is expanding).";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/0c786b7d19e25e79c361072229b80c07;2017-06-09;1034.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/38110232482/in/album-72157667717916600;abell665

column1: 37513876751.0;Hubble Uncovers Tiny Galaxies Bursting with Star Birth in Early Universe;"Using its near-infrared vision to peer 9 billion years back in time
column2: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has uncovered an extraordinary population of tiny
column3: young galaxies that are brimming with star formation. The galaxies are typically a hundred times less massive than the Milky Way galaxy
column4: yet they churn out stars at such a furious pace that their stellar content would double in just 10 million years. By comparison
column5: the Milky Way would take a thousand times longer to double its population.

column1: The observations were part of the Cosmic Assembly Near-infrared Deep Extragalactic Legacy Survey (CANDELS)
column2: an ambitious three-year survey to analyze the most distant galaxies in the universe. CANDELS is the census of dwarf galaxies at such an early epoch in the universe's history.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/3824f9ced53aa977fe40a13f5d1efc01;2017-10-05;532.0;1000.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/37513876751/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 36046681240.0;M42;"Believed to be the cosmic fire of creation by the Maya of Mesoamerica
column2: M42 blazes brightly in the constellation Orion. Popularly called the Orion Nebula
column3: this stellar nursery has been known to many different cultures throughout human history. The nebula is only 1
column4: 500 light-years away
column5: making it the closest large star-forming region to Earth and giving it a relatively bright apparent magnitude of 4. Because of its brightness and prominent location just below Orion’s belt
column6: M42 can be spotted with the naked eye
column7: while offering an excellent peek at stellar birth for those with telescopes. It is best observed during January.

column1: The Mayan culture’s likening of the Orion Nebula to a cosmic fire of creation is very apt. The nebula is an enormous cloud of dust and gas where vast numbers of new stars are being forged. Its bright
column2: central region is the home of four massive
column3: young stars that shape the nebula. The four hefty stars are called the Trapezium because they are arranged in a trapezoidal pattern. Ultraviolet light unleashed by these stars is carving a cavity in the nebula and disrupting the growth of hundreds of smaller stars.

column1: This stunning Hubble image offers the sharpest view of the Orion Nebula ever obtained. Created using 520 different Hubble exposures taken in multiple wavelengths of light
column2: this mosaic contains over one billion pixels. Hubble imaged most of the nebula
column3: but ground-based images were used to fill in the gaps in its observations. The orange color in the image can be attributed to hydrogen
column4: green represents oxygen
column5: and the red represents both sulfur and observations made in infrared light.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M42
column2: see:

column1: 36199960282.0;M8;"Commonly known as the Lagoon Nebula
column2: M8 was discovered in 1654 by the Italian astronomer Giovanni Battista Hodierna
column3: who
column4: like Charles Messier
column5: sought to catalog nebulous objects in the night sky so they would not be mistaken for comets. This star-forming cloud of interstellar gas is located in the constellation Sagittarius and its apparent magnitude of 6 makes it faintly visible to the naked eye in dark skies. The best time to observe M8 is during August.

column1: Located 5
column2: 200 light-years from Earth
column3: M8 is home to its own star cluster: NGC 6530 (not visible in the image above). The massive stars embedded within the nebula give off enormous amounts of ultraviolet radiation
column4: ionizing the gas and causing it to shine.

column1: In Hubble’s image of the center of the Lagoon Nebula
column2: dust masks most of the objects within. This image maps the emission from the nebula’s ionized gas. Hydrogen is colored red and nitrogen is green. The blue-white flare at the upper left of the image is scattered light from a bright star just outside the field of view.

column1: For more information on Hubble’s observations of M8

column1: 36443504095.0;M42;"Resembling an interstellar Frisbee
column2: the dark feature in these two Hubble images is a protoplanetary disk of dust seen edge-on around a newborn star in M42. The two images show the disk through two different sets of filters: one to probe the disk’s chemical composition (left) and another to reduce the brightness of the nebula
column3: revealing brighter regions above and below the disk that betray the presence of the star (right). Because the disk is edge-on
column4: its star is largely hidden
column5: but the disk may be an embryonic planetary system in the making. Our solar system probably formed out of such a disk 4.5 billion years ago.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M42

column1: 36085975910.0;M56;"Charles Messier discovered the globular cluster M56 in 1779. The cluster is located 33
column2: 000 light-years away from Earth in the constellation Lyra. It has an apparent magnitude of 8.3 and can be observed with a small telescope most easily in August.

column1: This beautiful Hubble image of M56 was constructed using both visible and infrared observations. Using various observations by Hubble
column2: astronomers have been able to study the chemical composition of the cluster. M56 has relatively few elements heavier than hydrogen and helium
column3: which is a sign that its stars were born early in the universe’s history before many of the elements in existence today were formed in significant quantities.

column1: Astronomers have found that most of clusters with this type of chemical makeup lie along a plane in the Milky Way’s halo. This suggests that such clusters were captured from a satellite galaxy
column2: rather than being the oldest members of the Milky Way’s globular cluster system as astronomers had previously thought.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M56
column2: see:

column1: www.spacetelescope.org/images/potw1234a/
