36422272576.0;M83;"This beautiful Hubble image captures hundreds of thousands of individual stars
column2: thousands of star clusters and hundreds of supernova remnants in the spiral galaxy M83. Also known as the Southern Pinwheel
column3: this galaxy is located 15 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Hydra. It was discovered in 1752 by the French astronomer Nicolas Louis de Lacaille. With an apparent magnitude of 7.5
column4: M83 is one of the brightest spiral galaxies in the night sky. It can be observed using a pair of binoculars most easily in May.

column1: Hubble’s image reveals interstellar “bubbles” produced by nearly 300 supernovas. By studying these supernova remnants
column2: astronomers can better understand the nature of the stars that exploded and dispersed their nuclear processed chemical elements back into the galaxy
column3: contributing to the next generation of new stars.

column1: The newest generations of stars in M83 are forming largely in clusters on the edges of the dark
column2: spiraling dust lanes. These brilliant
column3: young stellar groupings are only a few million years old and produce huge amounts of ultraviolet light. That light is absorbed by the surrounding diffuse gas clouds
column4: causing them to glow in pinkish hydrogen light.

column1: For more information about Hubble’s observations of M83
column2: see:

column1: 25902697067.0;M59;"M59 is one of the largest elliptical galaxies in the Virgo galaxy cluster. However
column2: it is still considerably less massive
column3: and at a magnitude of 9.8
column4: less luminous than other elliptical galaxies in the cluster.

column1: A supermassive black hole around 270 million times as massive as the Sun resides at the center of M59. The galaxy also has an inner disk of stars and around 2
column2: 200 globular clusters
column3: an exceptionally high number of such clusters. The central region of the galaxy
column4: the inner 200 light-years
column5: rotates in the opposite direction than the rest of the galaxy and is the smallest region in a galaxy known to exhibit this behavior.

column1: Approximately 60 million light-years from Earth
column2: M59 can be found near M58 and M60 in the constellation Virgo. It is best seen in May. Small telescopes might reveal an ellipsoidal shape with a bright center
column3: but even larger scopes do not reveal much detail.

column1: German astronomer Johann Gottfried Koehler discovered M59 and the nearby galaxy M60 in the spring of 1779 when observing the comet of that year (Comet Bode). While observing that same comet
column2: Charles Messier observed and added M59
column4: and the neighboring M58 to his catalog.

column1: Both Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys and Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 contributed to this view
column2: producing a multi-wavelength image in ultraviolet
column3: near-infrared
column4: and visible light. About half of M59 can be seen in this image
column5: as well as some of the galaxy's globular clusters (appearing as bright points of light). Several background galaxies also make an appearance. Hubble took these observations to study early-type galaxies
column6: which are often elliptical galaxies found near the centers of galaxy clusters. By looking at these galaxies with Hubble
column7: astronomers can determine the galaxies' structure and study the history of galaxy and cluster formation.

column1: 27712253493.0;Hubble Space Telescope Primary Mirror;"This photograph shows the Hubble Space Telescope's primary mirror being ground at the Perkin-Elmer Corporation's large optics fabrication facility. After the 8-foot diameter mirror was ground to shape and polished
column2: the glass surface was coated with a reflective layer of aluminum and a protective layer of magnesium fluoride
column3: 0.1- and 0.025-micrometers thick
column4: respectively.

column1: The purpose of Hubble
column2: the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made
column3: is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit. By placing the telescope in space

28046214380.0;Hubble Space Telescope in Cargo Bay;"This photograph shows the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) installed in the cargo bay of the Space Shuttle Orbiter Discovery for the STS-31 mission at the Kennedy Space Center prior to launch on April 24
column2: 1990. Hubble was the first of NASA's great observatories and the most complex and sensitive optical telescope ever made. The purpose of Hubble is to study the cosmos from a low Earth orbit by placing the telescope in space
column3: enabling astronomers to collect data that is free of Earth's atmosphere.

column1: The Marshall Space Flight Center had overall responsibility for design
column2: development
column3: and construction of the observatory. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury

column5: developed the optical system and guidance sensors. The Lockheed Missile and Space Company
column6: Sunnyvale
column7: California
column8: produced the protective outer shroud and spacecraft systems
column9: and assembled and tested the finished telescope.

28315964764.0;Hubble Uncovers a Galaxy Pair Coming in from the Wilderness;"NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has uncovered two tiny dwarf galaxies that have wandered from a vast cosmic wilderness into a nearby “big city” packed with galaxies. After being quiescent for billions of years
column2: they are ready to party by starting a firestorm of star birth.

column1: “These Hubble images may be snapshots of what present-day dwarf galaxies may have been like at earlier epochs
column2: ” said lead researcher Erik Tollerud of the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore
column3: Maryland. “Studying these and other similar galaxies can provide further clues to dwarf galaxy formation and evolution.”

column1: The Hubble observations suggest that the galaxies
column2: called Pisces A and B
column3: are late bloomers because they have spent most of their existence in the Local Void
column4: a region of the universe sparsely populated with galaxies. The Local Void is roughly 150 million light-years across.

column1: Under the steady pull of gravity from the galactic big city
column2: the loner dwarf galaxies have at last entered a crowded region that is denser in intergalactic gas. In this gas-rich environment
column3: star birth may have been triggered by gas raining down on the galaxies as they plow through the denser region. Another idea is that the duo may have encountered a gaseous filament
column4: which compresses gas in the galaxies and stokes star birth. Tollerud’s team determined that the objects are at the edge of a nearby filament of dense gas. Each galaxy contains only about 10 million stars.

column1: Dwarf galaxies are the building blocks from which larger galaxies were formed billions of years ago in the early universe. Inhabiting a sparse desert of largely empty space for most of the universe’s history
column2: these two galaxies avoided that busy construction period.

column1: “These galaxies may have spent most of their history in the void
column2: ” Tollerud explained. “If this is true
column3: the void environment would have slowed their evolution. Evidence for the galaxies’ void address is that their hydrogen content is somewhat high relative to similar galaxies. In the past
column4: galaxies contained higher concentrations of hydrogen
column5: the fuel needed to make stars. But these galaxies seem to retain that more primitive composition
column6: rather than the enriched composition of contemporary galaxies
column7: due to a less vigorous history of star formation. The galaxies also are quite compact relative to the typical star-forming galaxies in our galactic neighborhood.”

column1: The dwarf galaxies are small and faint
column2: so finding them is extremely difficult. Astronomers spotted them by using radio telescopes in a unique survey to measure the hydrogen content in our Milky Way. The observations captured thousands of small blobs of dense hydrogen gas. Most of them are gas clouds within our galaxy
column3: but astronomers identified 30 to 50 of those blobs as possible galaxies. The researchers used the WIYN telescope in Arizona to study 15 of the most promising candidates in visible light. Based on those observations
column4: Tollerud’s team selected the two that are the most likely candidates to be nearby galaxies and analyzed them with Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys. Hubble’s sharp vision helped the astronomers confirm that both of them
column5: Pisces A and B
column6: are dwarf galaxies.

column1: The Hubble telescope is aptly suited to study nearby
column2: dim dwarf galaxies because its sharp vision can resolve individual stars and help astronomers estimate the galaxies’ distances. Distance is important for determining a galaxy’s brightness
column3: and
column4: in these Hubble observations
column5: for calculating how far away the galaxies are from nearby voids. Pisces A is about 19 million light-years from Earth and Pisces B roughly 30 million light-years away. Based on the galaxies’ locations
column6: an analysis of the stars’ colors allowed the astronomers to trace the star formation history of both galaxies. Each galaxy contains about 20 to 30 bright blue stars
column7: a sign that they are very young
column8: less than 100 million years old. Tollerud’s team estimates that less than 100 million years ago
column9: the galaxies doubled their star-formation rate. Eventually
column10: the star formation may slow down again if the galaxies become satellites of a much larger galaxy.

column1: “The galaxies could even probably stop forming stars altogether
column2: because they will stop getting new gas to make stars
column3: ” Tollerud said. “So they will use up their existing gas. But it’s hard to tell right now exactly when that would happen
column4: so it’s a reasonable guess that the star formation will ramp up at least for a while.”

column1: Tollerud’s team hopes to observe other similar galaxies with Hubble. He also plans to scour the Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System survey (PanSTARRS) for potential dwarf galaxies. Future wide-survey telescopes
column2: such as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) in Chile and the large radio telescope in China
column3: should be able to find many of these puny galactic neighbors.

column1: The team’s results appeared in the Aug. 11
column3: issue of The Astrophysical Journal.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope is a project of international cooperation between NASA and the European Space Agency. NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt
column2: Maryland
column3: manages the telescope. The Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore
column4: Maryland
column5: conducts Hubble science operations. STScI is operated for NASA by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy in Washington
column6: D.C.

column1: 27414027304.0;NGC 2174;"In celebration of the 24th anniversary of the launch of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope (on April 24
column2: 1990) astronomers took an infrared-light portrait of a roiling region of starbirth located 6
column3: 400 light-years away.

column1: The Hubble mosaic unveils a collection of carved knots of gas and dust in a small portion of the Monkey Head Nebula (also known as NGC 2174 and Sharpless Sh2-252). The nebula is a star-forming region that hosts dusky dust clouds silhouetted against glowing gas.
Massive
column2: newly formed stars near the center of the nebula (and toward the right in this image) are blasting away at dust within the nebula. Ultraviolet light from these bright stars helps carve the dust into giant pillars. The nebula is mostly composed of hydrogen gas
column3: which becomes ionized by the ultraviolet radiation.

column1: As the interstellar dust particles are warmed from the radiation from the stars in the center of the nebula
column2: they heat up and begin to glow at infrared wavelengths. The image demonstrates Hubble's powerful infrared vision and offers a tantalizing hint of what scientists can expect from the upcoming James Webb Space Telescope.

column1: Observations of NGC 2174 were taken in February 2014.
For more information
column2: visit:

column1: hubblesite.org/news_release/news/2014-18
Credit: NASA
column2: ESA
column3: and the Hubble Heritage Team (STScI/AURA)";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/f0a1ce70a575ffc9d3458ffdda0417fc;2016-07-01;1858.0;1858.0;CC BY;7.21576698597e+16;Hubble Highlights;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27414027304/in/album-72157669859734000;hubblespacetelescope hubble nasa space astronomy ngc2174 monkeyheadnebula sharplesssh2252 nebula starformation

27743542260.0;The Florida Peninsula;The Florida peninsula and smog over the northeastern U.S. coast are featured in this image photographed by a Space Shuttle Discovery crewmember during STS-31 mission. According to scientists
column2: a mass of aerosol haze stretches across the top of the entire view. Meteorological
column3: visibility and sulfate-content data showed that the haze was indeed industrial smog haze
column4: rather than cloud. The air mass was transported west to east (left to right) around the north limb of a high pressure cell. It moved offshore for at least 1500 kilometers reaching the Atlantic islands of Bermuda. The leading edge of the haze mass can be detected far to the south
column5: near the Bahamas--indicating that aerosols from the industrial Northeast were transported around the high
column6: back directly toward the large population centers of Florida.;https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/42dd9319d74fd0a3849bd008e66a36e4;2016-07-01;3629.0;4697.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Deployment;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/27743542260/in/album-72157670398668500;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa hubbledeployment sts31

column1: 33791303270.0;A New Angle on Two Spiral Galaxies for Hubble's 27th Birthday;"In celebration of the 27th anniversary of the launch of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope on April 24
column3: astronomers used the legendary telescope to take a portrait of a stunning pair of spiral galaxies. This starry pair offers a glimpse of what our Milky Way galaxy would look like to an outside observer.

column1: The edge-on galaxy is called NGC 4302
column2: and the tilted galaxy is NGC 4298. These galaxies look quite different because we see them angled at different positions on the sky. They are actually very similar in terms of their structure and contents.

column1: From our view on Earth
column2: researchers report an inclination of 90 degrees for NGC 4302
column3: which is exactly edge on. NGC 4298 is tilted 70 degrees.

column1: In NGC 4298
column2: the telltale
column3: pinwheel-like structure is visible
column4: but it's not as prominent as in some other spiral galaxies. In the edge-on NGC 4302
column5: dust in the disk is silhouetted against rich lanes of stars. Absorption by dust makes the galaxy appear darker and redder than its companion. A large blue patch appears to be a giant region of recent star formation.

column1: Both galaxies are approximately 55 million light-years away. They reside in the constellation Coma Berenices in the Virgo Cluster of nearly 2
column2: 000 galaxies. Both were discovered in 1784 by astronomer William Herschel. Such objects were first simply called "spiral nebulas
column3: " because it wasn't known how far away they were. In the early 20th century
column4: Edwin Hubble discovered that galaxies are other island cities of stars far outside our Milky Way.

column1: A typical spiral galaxy has arms of young stars that wind outward from its center. The bright arms are regions of intense star formation. Such galaxies have a central bulge and are surrounded by a faint halo of stars. Many spiral galaxies also have bars that extend from the central bulge to the arms.
The edge-on NGC 4302 is about 87
column2: 000 light-years in diameter
column3: which is about 60 percent the size of the Milky Way. It is about 110 billion solar masses
column4: approximately one-tenth of the Milky Way's mass.

column1: The tilted NGC 4298 is about 45
column2: 000 light-years in diameter
column3: about one-third the size of the Milky Way. At 17 billion solar masses
column4: it is less than 2 percent of the Milky Way galaxy's 1 trillion solar masses.

column1: The Hubble observations were taken between January 2 and January 22
column3: with the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) instrument in three visible light bands.

column1: The Hubble Space Telescope was launched aboard the Space Shuttle Discovery on April 24
column3: and deployed into low Earth orbit the next day. From its perch high above the distorting effects of Earth's atmosphere
column4: Hubble observes the universe in near-ultraviolet
column5: visible
column6: and near-infrared light. Over the past 27 years
column7: the space telescope's breakthrough discoveries have revolutionized the fields of astronomy and astrophysics.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/02b87fd16c3f738e793083b1d4adcb77;2017-04-20;1140.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33791303270/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 33655588633.0;A Lot of Galaxies Need Guarding in this NASA Hubble View;"Much like the eclectic group of space rebels in the film Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2
column2: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has some amazing superpowers
column3: specifically when it comes to observing innumerable galaxies flung across time and space.

column1: A stunning example is a galaxy cluster called Abell 370 that contains an astounding assortment of several hundred galaxies tied together by the mutual pull of gravity. That’s a lot of galaxies to be guarding
column2: and just in this one cluster!

column1: Photographed in a combination of visible and near-infrared light
column2: the immense cluster is a rich mix of a variety of galaxy shapes. The brightest and largest galaxies in the cluster are the yellow-white
column3: massive
column4: elliptical galaxies containing many hundreds of billions of stars each. Spiral galaxies — like our Milky Way — have younger populations of stars and are bluish.

column1: Entangled among the galaxies are mysterious-looking arcs of blue light. These are actually distorted images of remote galaxies behind the cluster. These far-flung galaxies are too faint for Hubble to see directly. Instead
column2: the cluster acts as a huge lens in space that magnifies and stretches images of background galaxies like a funhouse mirror. The massive gravitational field of the foreground cluster produces this phenomenon. The collective gravity of all the stars and other matter trapped inside the cluster warps space and affects light traveling through the cluster
column3: toward Earth.

column1: Nearly a hundred distant galaxies have multiple images caused by the lensing effect. The most stunning example is “the Dragon
column2: ” an extended feature that is probably several duplicated images of a single background spiral galaxy stretched along an arc.

column1: Astronomers chose Abell 370 as a target for Hubble because its gravitational lensing effects can be used for probing remote galaxies that inhabited the early universe.
Abell 370 is located approximately 4 billion light-years away in the constellation Cetus
column2: the Sea Monster. It is the last of six galaxy clusters imaged in the recently concluded Frontier Fields project. This ambitious
column3: community-developed collaboration among NASA’s Great Observatories and other telescopes harnessed the power of massive galaxy clusters and probed the earliest stages of galaxy development. The program reveals galaxies that are 10 to 100 times fainter than any previously observed.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/e2160ca60af475ea243cfcf0bbecd971;2017-05-05;1096.0;985.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/33655588633/in/album-72157667717916600;

column1: 35304216950.0;What’s in a name?;"Not all galaxies have the luxury of possessing a simple moniker or quirky nickname. The subject of this Hubble Space Telescope image was one of the unlucky ones
column2: and goes by the rather unpoetic name of 2XMM J143450.5+033843.

column1: Such a name may seem like a random jumble of numbers and letters
column2: but like all galactic epithets it has a distinct meaning. This galaxy
column3: for example
column4: was detected and observed as part of the second X-ray sky survey performed by ESA’s XMM-Newton Observatory. Its celestial coordinates form the rest of the bulky name
column5: following the “J”: a right ascension value of 14h 34m 50.5s (this can be likened to terrestrial longitude)
column6: and a declination of +03d 38m 43s (this can be likened to terrestrial latitude). The other fuzzy object in the frame was named in the same way — it is a bright galaxy named 2XMM J143448.3+033749.

column1: 2XMM J143450.5+033843 lies nearly 400 million light-years away from Earth. It is a Seyfert galaxy that is dominated by something known as an Active Galactic Nucleus — its core is thought to contain a supermassive black hole that is emitting huge amounts of radiation
column2: pouring energetic X-rays out into the universe.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/2e38cb664cad4e0b7469107d59dc7ff6;2017-06-28;903.0;1041.0;CC BY;7.21576677179e+16;Hubble's Latest;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/35304216950/in/album-72157667717916600;2xmmj1434505033843

column1: 28136831252.0;Launch of Space Shuttle Atlantis on STS-125 Mission;"Space Shuttle Atlantis and its seven-member STS-125 crew head toward Earth orbit and rendezvous with NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. Liftoff was on time at 2:01 p.m. EDT on May 11
column3: from Launch Pad 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center.

column1: Onboard were astronauts Scott Altman
column2: commander; Gregory C. Johnson
column3: pilot; Michael Good
column4: Megan McArthur
column5: John Grunsfeld
column6: Mike Massimino and Andrew Feustel
column7: all mission specialists.

column1: Atlantis' 12-day flight included five spacewalks that refurbished and upgraded the telescope with state-of-the-art science instruments that expanded Hubble's capabilities and extended its operational lifespan. The payload included the Wide Field Camera 3
column2: a fine guidance sensor and the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph.";https://www.datastro.eu/api/v2/catalog/datasets/nasahubble/files/161282ce5c2111e59dd1df200b38d171;2009-06-02;3000.0;1968.0;CC BY;7.21576703987e+16;Hubble Servicing Mission 4;https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasahubble/28136831252/in/album-72157670398668400;hubble hubblespacetelescope nasa sts125 servicingmission4 hubbleservicingmission shuttlemission spaceshuttle launch kennedyspacecenter spaceshuttleatlantis
